reviewText:
I did not think that with 2HG and customisation, they could make this worse than Duels 2015.

Once again, I have underestimated Stainless.


Chat has been entirely removed from the game.
That's right. 2HG is back, but now you can't talk with your team-mate.

Lobbies have been entirely removed from the game.
Yep. 2HG is back but you have to remake the game, and find players, every single game. This makes it prone to network errors like never before. We all know Duels 2013 & 2014 had network problems. Now get ready for that, but about 5 times more than before. Not exaggerating.

Organising a 2HG game with just 1 friend is a complete and utter trainwreck. Try to play 4 games of 2HG with 1 friend; you will give up before you make it to 4. Now try with 3 friends. You'll want to stick forks in your eyes.

This is how bad it is:
* Sometimes you finally manage to start the game and your friend has been put on the opposite team.
* Sometimes you finish a game only to realise your friend hasn't finished. .... You weren't even in the same game, and you didn't know.

Wait.

What?

Yes.

Really.

How is that possible? How can you play a whole game and not realise your teammate is AI?

That's how bad it is! Because here's the utter brilliance of Stainless Steel's game design: they didn't just remove chat entirely, they also removed AI names upon AI takeover, so if someone's not a human, you can't tell. At all.

And the beautiful part is that you don't even know. How many games have you played with a random human teammate?

Now.... how many of those games were actually using an AI teammate? You don't know, do you?

It gets better.

In 2HG, if someone leaves, a message appears to tell you, then disappears. This message disappears automatically, and very quickly. So let's say you look out the window for 2 seconds, and someone leaves.

You have no way of knowing.

But wait. Let's say you look out the window for 2 seconds and someone _doesn't_ leave.

You still have no way of knowing.

And then it dawns on you. If you ever, for a second, look away from the screen in 2HG, you're done. You're in the dark for the rest of the game. You honestly, no-lie, can not tell if players are human or AI. You are completely cut off; there's no way you can communicate anything to figure out if you're even having a game with a human. Years later, you still won't know.

So why aren't people making more of a stink about this? Because they can't tell it's happening. It's that legit. The only way I discovered that this happens is through Steam. If I'm playing with a random teammate, I will simply never know.

And now I'm telling you, in 2016, this has still happened twice in one night. Scary, isn't it? This is literally starting to sound like a conspiracy theory, it's that idiotic.

The next 2HG game you play, you will wonder. And once you start wondering, you will realise just how bad it is. You have no way of knowing. You will never know.


3 & 4 player FFA, gone.
Hold priority, gone.
AI takeover toggle, gone.

Un-confirming attackers or blockers if your teammate changes his attackers or blockers, also gone. Yeah that's never useful is it, especially when you can't even chat. If your teammate has already confirmed, you can't tell unless you confirm, and then it's too late.



Like many others have said. Wizards, get rid of Stainless. Get some college team to do a better job than their crap, which just sheds features every year to the point where I feel like Will Ferrell saying I'm not even mad
date:
that's amazing!"


Because when I just now had a game where I couldn't chat to my team-mate in order to ask him if he was a human or not... I had to laugh. Stainless

reviewText:
When this game was released the developers promised to keep up with the expansions of the MTGCCG. They did NOT do that, they have missed every expansion release.

When Stainless (the developers) missed out the MTG expansion 'Oath of the Gatewatch' completely (it wasn't late, they actually missed it), they tried to pass it off, they said instead of releasing this expansion, they would work on all the bugs and problems in the game, and then bundle that expansion with the next expansion 'Shadows Over Innistrad'.

Now that Shadows Over Innistrad is here, we are all very disappointed,  the game has become almost unplayable.

MTG has TWO main phases, if you have abilities on the board and/or instants in your hand, this client REMOVES both of your main phases. THIS IS NO LONGER Magic The Gathering.

The developers knew about this problem as the game expansion was released and they chose to release it anyway, they even detailed this problem in the release notes. This is the FIRST and ONLY time that Stainless has managed to release the game on time, and it is nearly unplayable.

MTG is complex, you have to play around your opponent, now, you have to play around the game client as well.

As I type this, the Reddit Forum for this game is an orchestra of complaints.

I love MTG - I want to love Duels, but, in its current state - I cannot recommend MTG Duels

reviewText:
General Impressions:
Update 23/10/15: Just published a video review/letsplay/rant about the game also that can be viewed here, for anyone curious: https://youtu.be/XJrmefG17aw

Free to play Magic: The Gathering presented in the style of the earlier 'Duels of the Planeswalkers' games.  No exclusive content that can't be earned with in game currency. The game uses a selection of cards from the latest 'Origins' set.

Magic Duels is plagued with bugs, ranging from inexplicable launch errors preventing many from playing the game, to infinite loading screens and some instances of cards not following the rules.  There is also an unreasonable DX 11 hardware requirement which is plain sloppy programming, Duels could easily be software rendered.

Playing Duels online can really push my patience to its limits sometimes.  Matchmaking fails most of the time, I often have to search 5+ times before finding an opponent, and getting into a match of 2HG has been 100% impossible.  Players can avoid losing rank from losses very easily, making the whole mode a joke.  Also, people playing this better enjoy battling poor AI opponents, since whenever you play a person in any mode, if there's a slight connection hiccup of any kind or the server acts up, your opponent gets replaced with the AI.

I can't in good conscience recommend the game to anyone in its current state, it is simply not release ready and I'd strongly discourage anyone from spending real money in the game until drastic measures are taken by the developers to improve just about all aspects of the game.  Those desperate for a decent F2P MtG experience (such as myself) may be willing to forgive a lot of the shortcomings and problems this game suffers.  It is frustrating, there's potential for a lot of good MtG cardslinging with this release, but it needs SO much work to be considered a good game.

Unfortunately I have little faith of Magic Duels recieving any of these much needed improvements simply because of the track record of the developer, Stainless Games, which despite imaginative boasts on their website are responsible for a lot of bad releases, from the recently released Carmageddon game which is a complete wreck (in all the wrong ways) to all the previous 'DotP' iterations, which ALL have had bugs and problems of varying magnitude that were never fixed.  The amateurish online functionality in particular is something that has plagued all the earlier versions of 'DotP' and never seen improvements.


The Good Stuff:
Free to play MtG is in itself a very good thing.

Tutorials, while annoying for experts, do a good job of teaching the basics of MtG for new players and also provide a quick shot of ingame currency for booster packs.

Inviting interface, easy to play with either mouse or a controller.

While you typically face certain easy to make deck types in online matches, the card selection is varied enough to allow for many diverse decks.

Very fair monetization.  Collecting currency for booster packs is easy, and there are no direct advantages offered by paying real money, other than saving yourself time.
The Bad Stuff:
Bugs, bugs, bugs.  Cards become invisible, graphical glitches making either the table or your cards turn invisible or black, bugged cards that don't follow the rules.  Many can not launch the game, instead greeted with black screen or a crash.  Interface bugs, not allowing menu elements to be used, or making them flash up nonstop.

The online functionality is a complete mess.  The worst I have seen in a long time.  1v1 ranked matches often take 5-10 attempts before successfully finding and loading a match with an opponent, and getting a match of the popular 2 Headed Giant mode is even worse.  In a couple hours of repeatedly trying to play the mode I have not managed to get a single damn match going.  When I do get a 1v1 match going there are often lag spikes or constant lag, which can make you misplay cards or not be able to pause at critical moments to use instant abilities.  Servers are, still, very unstable and it is common to see your opponent get dropped from a game, very obvious when they suddenly drop out when they're just about to beat you.

In online matches, a bad AI takes over whenever opponents either get dropped, quit or concede from a match.  This is an insult, if my opponent scoops out I shouldn't have to keep fighting a second opponent, the match should be over.  No excuses for this.  Defenders say it is to prevent exploiting ingame currency farming but .. no.  Just, no.  It is extremely dull to so often have to battle the AI, and feels like the winner of the match is the one getting punished when the opponent quits.  Not to mention if the AI pulls a miracle and does a comeback and wins the match, the remaining player also loses gold and rank, an extra slap in the face considering the very real possibility the opponent quit the game with an exploit to prevent himself losing rank.

The online ranked structure itself is a complete joke.  Players start at rank 0 and climb/drop 1 rank per match. Rank 40 is max.  That's it.  So little thought went into the online structure it would be comical, if it wasn't so sad.  The ease of exploiting to save yourself from losing ranks further remove any semblance of accomlishment or prestige from climbing the ranked ladder.

Very unreasonable hardware requirements.  Magic Duels requires both a DirectX 11 compatible video card, and a sound card to run, for no logical reason.  This is lazy programming for a simple looking turn based card game that could easily be programmed to be 100% cpu rendered.  The sound is also something many will just turn off, requiring a sound card to run the game is.. really weird.  On top of that the game lists as being Vista compatible, which it has been proven to absolutely not be.  (Vista users might want to think about updating soon, tho, just saying)

Duels can be played on PC, Xbox One and Iphone/pad, but has no cross platform multiplayer, and not even a way to use the same account between the platforms.


But Couchfighter, why do you have so many hours on this game, or even play it right now if you don't like it? You silly goose!
I'm so glad you asked, here's two reasons!

1.  I still wanted to complete the current card set, and gather up some coins for the next release, in the small hope that Duels recieves the many improvements it needs.

2.  In those cases when you actually get a working match without lag/bugs/crashes, Duels can be rather enjoyable indeed for a casual MtG enthusiast such as myself.

Does that make up for the myriad of big problems the game has, that some like to pretend don't exist? No, I'm afraid it doesn't.  If and when Duels gets the many fixes it needs I will be the first to turn that review thumb pointing the other way but until that happens, as a whole, I do not recommend Duels.

reviewText:
Credentials: I have been playing and collecting Magic the Gathering since the mid 1990s, this is the first revision of my review for this game, the original was written at 51.2 hours and this one at 953. I cannot recommend this game either now, or when I first reviewed it.

IMPORTANT N.B : This game, as of the latest patch(April 2016 - Shadows Over Innistrad) is borderline unplayable, due a severe bug having been introduced concerning the way that priority and turn progression are handled in game(the game will automatically skip main phases, if you only have instant speed plays available). The bug in question has broken many of the game's available cards and mechanics. Players with some prior experience with Magic The Gathering might find the following links particularly interesting, as well as new players who are keen on learning how to play Magic :-

- Wizards Announcement about Priority Bug

- Devs--this is why your new priority system does not work.

- Hold Priority Bug Is TOP PRIORITY bug fix guys!

- New Priority Passing was a design decision

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DCNrlVjzBfk
Please take a moment to contact Wizards directly by email and report this bug to them( wizardscusthelp@wizards.com ), Facebook( https://www.facebook.com/magicduels ) and Twitter( https://twitter.com/magic_duels ). Please also contribute to the debate on Duels' Subreddit and here in Duels' Steam discussion group. Thanks.

--------------------------------------------------

Major Problems I have encountered with this game so far :-

After using my gold to buy boosters to complete sets, I was not given the boosters I paid for. This was made worse by the fact that I paid for my gold with real money.

Numerous cards have been bugged or broken with each release and have been left unfixed for 3 or more months, which has been the frequency thus far, at which the developers release patches.

The game has a tendency to randomly hang mid-turn when playing vs matches against human opponents online, requiring you to either concede and lose rank, or terminate the game's process and restart the game.

The game on occasion prevents you from stopping the phase transition clock, which can prevent you from casting spells.

After the last patch(April 2016 - Shadows Over Innistrad), they broke all decks players had built prior to update, in such a way that would leave the game hanging indefinitely whilst loading solo A.I. matches. This required players to delete all their decks and rebuild them all from scratch.

Trying to connect to a vs match against somebody online usually takes between 5 and 15 minutes, with the game either repeatedly disconnecting for no reason, or hanging in an unrecoverable way that requires the player to terminate the game's process and restart the game.

Anti-aliasing and shadow casting in the game has been broken since launch. This makes the edges in game geometry(e.g. cards) jagged and shadows appear as solid black blocks.

There are also many minor problems the game either has, or has had that are too numerous to list here.

--------------------------------------------------

This game's development and release cycle thus far :-

They released the game at the end of July 2015. The game was due to receive the Battle For Zendikar update late September, Wizards announced on release day that the update had been delayed indefinitely, they didn't provide a future date. The Battle For Zendikar update was eventually released late November, they didn't announce its release, they simply announced the game was going into extended maintenance and went ahead and did it. The game was due to receive the Oath Of The Gatewatch update mid to late January, but the update was delayed until April to coincide with the Shadows Over Innistrad release, the game received no bug patches between November and April either. Both the Oath Of The Gatewatch and Shadows Over Innistrad updates were released early April, this update introduced more bugs than it fixed.

--------------------------------------------------

Further Analysis :-

Almost every update released for this game has been delayed, bug patches have been infrequent and low impact.

This game violates multiple rules of paper Magic The Gathering. Turn phases do not work the same way, there is no upkeep phase for example, which renders some spells less effective. The game does not permit 4 of any non basic land card to be played in a deck as per constructed rules, instead, card count is restricted by rarity. 1x Mythic, 2x Rare, 3x Uncommon, 4x Common. This causes severe balancing issues to occur, because all of the cards featured in this game, are designed and play tested around the common rule that up to 4 copies of any card may be played.

Set releases are incomplete, they do not release every card in each set, with between a third and a half of each set excluded, this further causes balancing issues and substantially reduces the quality of the content this game has to offer, as many fun, low impact cards are excluded, as well as some of the more popular cards each set has to offer.

The game features a collection of starter box cards from many past and present sets and because these cards have not been balanced, or developed alongside recent set releases; which consist mostly of current Standard legal cards, they can and have caused severe balancing issues that are left unfixed for months on end between updates, this can make the game tedious and repetitive to play. This problem would be substantially less severe, if they invested more time into analyzing the impact the cards in question are likely to have on the format and/or if they more frequently patched the game.

Wizards of the Coast, who own the Magic The Gathering franchise, are notoriously averse to investing in or committing to products that deviate from their core business, which is paper Magic The Gathering. Because of this, Magic Duels does not presently have the resources either financial, human or otherwise to become the successful, feature rich digital trading card game that long term players such as myself know it can be, and until this changes, this game will not fulfill its potential.

There have been recent indications(2015 / 2016) that their attitude towards digitizing their game may be evolving to a degree, but as things presently stand, this game seems to have only minimal support of its owners ergo, its long term future looks bleak, which should be foremost on your mind if you intend to buy content or invest substantial amounts of your time into collecting cards and building decks.

--------------------------------------------------

Conclusion :-

Having devoted nearly a thousand hours of my time to this game, I am regretfully going to have to walk away from it, at least until they fix the Hold Priority bug introduced in the latest update(April 2016 - Shadows Over Innistrad), which has caused widespread malfunction throughout its cards and mechanics.

On the whole, I cannot recommend this game, either to players who are new to Magic The Gathering, or to experienced long term players. I would especially advise players looking to use Magic Duels to learn how to play paper Magic The Gathering to steer clear, because the two are significantly different.

Bottom line... Keep an eye on this game, its owners may well get behind it at some point in the future and if they do, it'll become truly great, but right now(2016) your time would be better invested elsewhere.

reviewText: By some miracle of ineptitude, Magic Duels somehow manages to be worse than DotP 2015 across the board. In terms of game design, gameplay content, the cash shop, and even down to the card selection, this is by far the worst work by Stainless Games yet. Wizards need to seriously re-evaluate their digital presence and either needs to find a new studio to work on these games or stop making them altogether.\n\nGone are the extra game modes, challenges, and even campaign deck construction of previous years. Instead, we have a 20 mission campaign (with unadjustable difficulty) with tutorials sprinkled throughout that can only be played with uneditable decks that get upgraded" after completing missions. How are they upgraded? It's hard to tell
date: since most of them are very bad from the start and the game doesn't tell you what changes it makes to your deck. Gideon's deck is the most playable and even that is just dumping your hand and turning everything sideways. I get the feeling that they thought that cramming the challenges of old DotP games into this game's campaign would be a good idea but it really doesn't work. This campaign is (once again!) a terrible introduction to MTG for new players since it ignores deck construction
hoursPlayed: and has many purposefully unbalanced fights.\n\nOnce you finish the very short singleplayer content
voteText: you have the incredibly deep and rewarding online play to look forward to. 2-Headed Giant is back! ...But you can't get coin rewards from it. There's a ladder system and matchmaking system finally! ...But server/game crashes and disconnects will give you no rewards. You can quickly play games through Steam invites with your friends! ...But there's no rewards. Playing MTG is fun and all but its frustrating when everyone is playing with the same trash and new boosters are hard to come by because of the stingy cash shop system. Even if you do decide to sink some cash into this game

reviewText:
From what I've experienced so far:

Pros:
- Free to play
- Somewhat reasonable pricing of cards.
- Interesting lore about the planeswalkers
- Two-Headed Giant comeback.
- Nice tutorial voicing

Cons:
- Fails to bring anything new and innovating to the franchise
- The cards implemented are generally tedious (personal opinion, mind you)
- Buggy mess (lots and lots of bugs and crashes)
- Unskippable tutorial (and really long and boring)
- Chapter ending animations are from the last century.
- Often suffers from connection issues
- You can only progress from the campaign and gain gold while online.

2012 had archenemy, 2013 had planechase. Since then it's been going downhill. True, you couldn't make your own deck from scratch; but atleast some of the cards implemented were interesting. The most interesting thing I could find in this game was thopter spy-network, imo, and even then.. I dunno, to me it just seems like the games are starting to lose the point of what I thought about was fun about mtg in the first place.

I have a deck in physical form, which, among other things, contain the card Mindmoil and the card Niv-Mizzet the Firemind. This basically means that I cycle through my entire deck, casting random spells and deal dmg all over the place to enemies in all directions. Odd combos like these are what makes magic fun and interesting to me.
Duels 2012 had some of the same aspects. I remember equipping Basillisk Collar onto a pestilence demon, accidentally clearing the entire board and gain over 100 hp in the process. Events like these seem neigh impossible with the current cards implemented. It's all just very... Tedious...

Does this mean you won't appreciate the game?
If you can enjoy competitive play no matter what kind of deck you're playing and if you can actually get the game working, sure why not?

But I can't recommend this to you.

reviewText:
While the game shows some promise, a number of steps would need to be taken before I could recommend that anyone spend money in-game:

Major Issues:

-Connectivity issues.  There are a lot of drops when trying to connect with an opponent, which is quite annoying.  I have not encountered, but have seen reported, a slew of other connectivity concerns,
-In game bugs.  While somewhat consistent, there are times when the game bugs out pretty severely.  I had an issue where I got locked into a zoom in on a card which caused me to lose a game.
-While I have not encountered this issue, there have been reports that cards have disappeared from collections, including from purchased packs.

Annoyances (less major issues):

-Opponent concessions.  When your opponent concedes the game, they are then replaced with an AI opponent.  If you happen to lose to that opponent, you receive a loss and drop in rank.  When an opponent concedes, this should be treated as if you have won the match.
-Daily quests.  All the quests I have encountered reward 40 coins, which is a fine reward for most quests.  However, some quests require twice the number of wins as other quests, sometimes with the same parameters.  For example, yesterday I had two quests that both rewarded 40 coins.  On required me to win 2 games with a Blue Red deck, while the other required me to win 4.  The coin reward for these more time consuming quests should be greater.
-Archetype" quests.  Quests ask you to win with archetype decks.  However
date: these decks cannot be entirely of your own design.  Instead
recommended: you have to work your way through the aided deck construction generator which
hoursPlayed: while great for beginners
voteText: is pretty limiting for experienced players.  This is especially the case due to the fact that this deck generation only works on the cards you already own.  So
helpfulPercent: if you have a quest for a color combination for which you lack strong cards
votesHelpful: you're in a bad spot.  I would rather these quests allow all the cards you own and individual deck creation or pull from additional cards that you do not yet own that make these archetype decks a bit more consistent.\n-Deck construction UI.  Minor concern
votesTotal: but it is a pain to make decks in the advanced deck creation UI.  The inability to sort cards once they've been added to the deck is annoying.  I'd like to be able to lay my deck out
votesFunny: or at least get more statistics about my deck before I finalize it.\n-Land selection. Another minor concern
commentsCount: but the art on your lands are essentially randomly assigned.  If you'd like to have only one design on your lands
column16: you're out of luck.\n\nLike I said at the top
column17: there is a lot of potential in this game
column18: but I don't think it's worth spending any real money on just yet."

reviewText:
This iteration of Magic improves in many ways but still leaves a bit to be desired.

Features:
2-Headed Giant  (2vs2 game mode)
Full deckbuilding
100% Free Earnable content through gameplay
Improved UI
Fully Voiced Tutorial Divided into individual modules greatly helps learning the game for new players.
New Storytelling method has the player play through the stories of 5 planeswalkers
No more yearly iterations of the game (instead developers intend to add new cards as sets come out to this version).
Ranked 1vs1 Game Mode
256 Unique-playable cards at the time of release (counting lands)
*Rarity restrictions in place (1 mythic, 2 rare, 3 uncommon, 4 commons per deck)

Drawbacks:
**Coins capped at 400 gold per day (roughly 2 and 1/3 packs of cards)
Only 6 cards per pack opened
Cannot earn currency in 2HG or when playing against an invited opponent
Some bugs, disconnects, and instability
FFA mode removed (only has 2HG, Story, and 1vs1 modes)

*In the limited format of Magic Duels rarity restrictions are a positive as limiting Mythics and Rares allows for greater diversity among competitive decks (you wouldn't want *every* deck to be packed with the same 2 or 3 mythics every game, would you?). Also, a player will never receive more copies of a card then can be used in a single deck, so farming for the last couple of rares will be quick and painless.
**The daily coin cap doesn't apply to coins earned from story mode, quests, or tutorials.

The biggest drawback is that the rate of unlocking cards is a bit too slow (15G per win against the hardest AI results in 6 cards every 10 wins), a problem exasperated by the inability to earn daily currency from playing against friends. I assume this too-slow rate is intentional as to encourage micro-transactions.

Overall, still a positive experience and I will certainly keep playing. The game has a lot of potential if these cons are addressed and regular updates are provided.

reviewText:
A lot of unpolished elements.  As is would not recommend at all.  Some examples:

UI:
--  UI is laggy.  When leaving a menu you have to wait several seconds before you can actually click anything.
--  When popups with choices come up, like those for Desecration Demon, the selection screen blocks the play area, and there is no way to move it aside or peek at your board.  Once you make your choice there's no going back.
--  No voice acting or sound in the cutscenes.  Very awkward.
--  Clicking the text for an option does not work.  It has been standard in games for years now, that clicking the text also clicks the box.  You don't realize how annoying not having this is, until you play a game like this one where it's gone.
--  You can't separate the opponent's land to see which ones they have.

Gameplay:
--  The AI is bad.  It will do stuff like Languish it's own board when you have no creatures.
--  They want to charge for cards, but the deck restrictions aren't the same as magic.
--  There's no way to see what's in your deck when you start a story mission.  Very annoying.
--  The reaction interface is very bad.  Most games let you skip to next turn, skip to next main phase, etc.  This one has a 5 second timer and then it plows ahead.  It's not clear whether or not you are reacting or if you're in one of the main phases.  The order battles are resolved is arbitrary instead of standard magic rules.
--  Large AI slowdowns for seemingly simple play states.  Not sure why sometimes it takes the computer 30s to decide what to play on turn 2.

Graphics:
--  Very ugly presentation.  Small cards on a large bland playmat.  No colors or customization options.
--  Minimal interface, but no unifying theme or artistic direction.

Overall a very poor implementaiton of Magic.  I'd recommend the official MTG client over this.  Or, better yet, any of the alternate clients like XMAGE.

Compuer specs:
Intel i5 4690k @ 4.2 GHz
16GB DDR3 RAM
240GB SSD
NVIDIA GTX 680

reviewText:
This is a review written 2 days after launch so alot of the cons may have been ironed out by the time you read it.

The pros:
- Reasonable F2P business model: 400 gold cap per day, enough gold for around 8 packs from the campaign, 150 gold for a booster of 6 cards, you will never open duplicates that you don't need, ~72 boosters to fully unlock the current card pool, this equates to 720 wins against the difficult AI (or 540 wins vs players) with out any questing or free gold. Almost all dual lands are given to you at the start and foiling all copies of a card only costs 5 gold (regardless of rarity). Buying boosters costs around 1-2$ per pack depending on the rate and exchange ratio.
- Expect decent content updates: it's promised that this version of the game will be constantly updated with around 70-80% of the cards from each new block of card releases (every 3 months).
- AI has access to every card so there is / will be massive variety even with single player play, and the AI's deck you play against are randomized every time you play.
- AI is proficiently programmed in regards to most keywords (more on that below).
- Two-Headed Giant is back.
- Full deck building: Want to make that Penta-colour deck filled with bombs and flavor of the month? Now you can!
- A very good tutorial system: The tutorial teaches you the basics through game play, when new keywords pop up during a campaign, you are often given the choice of jumping into a short tutorial scenario (half a minute to a minute) for the keyword to earn some free gold, or you can just skip them all together.

The ambiguous:
- Rarity restrictions: 4 commons, 3 uncommons, 2 rares, 1 Mythic. This restricts the potential power and consistency of decks and requires different planning of cards, but also in a way reduces the potential Mythic bombs and makes the disadvantage for newcomers smaller.
- Two-Headed Giant and duels with friends grants no gold, understandable from a F2P perspective.
- AI takes over for players if someone concedes.
- A basic campaign that's atleast better than most I've seen from online tcg's, with a story, custom artwork, and a cutscene at the end.
- UI is mostly functional but also lack customization options.
- 30 deck slots.

The cons:
- Attrocious launch, disconnects, and bugs for alot of people.
- No trading.
- No cross-play between platforms.
- Always-online requirements.
- Chatting is gone (though some might consider this a positive).
- Lobbies are gone.
- No FFA / 3v3 / 4v4 / additional formats.
- You have to finish the game against the AI after someone concedes if you want the gold reward.
- The AI programming is flawed when it comes to dropping creatures on second main phase even if it has an ability that impacts the board prior to combat phase.
- The deck builder could be improved upon with more sort and filter options.

All in all I see alot of potential in this title as the card pool increases and bugs get ironed out. For me the full deck building aspect, decent amount of card slots, decent solo experience, and the F2P model was enough to sway me over to bear with the launch server problems and other bugs. Worth checking out once the launch issues are resolved.

reviewText:
Always online functionality - check!
Servers don't work - check
Lots of outdated filler cards - check
UI and graphics from 2001 - check

Let's ship that game!


Blizzard must be laughing their a**es off.


Edit March 2016:

Still cannot recommend the game.

While the server difficulties are solved, the game is still lacking in many ways.

There are annoying card bugs that have been there since the launch. Stainless stay true to themselves and don't bother fixing even the most annoying bugs. (They have done the same in all their past Magic games, for example they have not and will never fix some glaring bugs in 2012 and 2013 editions, one of which makes a whole (paid DLC!) deck unplayable, others make some cards useless. So there is no reason to think this will improve.)

The card selection is overall better now, but the game is still dominated by only about 3-4 standard decks. Add this to the very slow gameplay with very long timers and it makes for boring and frustrating play.
There are of course still a lot of useless filler cards, but overall it's doable to unlock all cards with reasonable effort, but this gets harder and harder for new players, so I'm not sure how the playerbase is supposed to grow.
Ranking mode is pretty useless, the levels don't really reflect your skill as there is no ELO system.
No chat, no lobbies, no 3 or 4 player, no archenemy.

Simply not fun in this state.

I hope Wizard pulls the plug on this one and lets a better studio have a go.

reviewText:
Okay first off, this game has a lot of potential and the devs say they are going to update this game often so a lot of this could be fixed but until then i do not recommend this game, even though i do enjoy it at times, you can enjoy this game even though it's not in a good state at all, especially with friends even if you can't play all the multiplayer modes together, more on that below.

The campaign isn't great, but it's not bad either but it is really short, like 3 hours short. A short campaign in this game is fine in my opinion but if you want some sort of replayable long campaign, this is not the game. Also after your first run it does not give you anymore coins making it a waste of time, if you could still get some sort of income from it, i would of replayed it a few times. Some of the individual stories are good, and the charactors actions make sense and i can see someone reacting that way to the situation, but some parts seem a little random/forced and it's obvious they didnt put too much thought into them, but i don't think anyone plays magic for the campaign/story so that's not too bad. Also during one of the stages of the elf campaign there are cards that are in the game but you cant see or unlock them any where else meaning they are holding back content from launch, which is something that literally anyone, ANYONE would tell you that is a really bad thing to do that no one likes, but because of the lack of cards this could be due to balance as those cards are OP compared to all the current cards ingame, but seeing as how they were in past games if they just had all the cards from those games they wouldn't be OP beacuse they were balanced in those.

On to the Multiplayer, the removal of lobbies is one of the worst things they have done to the Magic games, it makes 2v2s with a friend almost impossible, either one person gets an error or both do or an endless loading screen. Now when i say they removed lobbies, that's not exactly what they did, they made it so you don't have an option of hosting a game, or joining one and it just instantly starts. If it makes you host one (happens beyond rarely) it works 95% of the time, the other 5% you are on other teams (how does that even happen?) and when it tries to make you join a game the person you invited will have to reselect his deck and somehow that breaks it and he can no longer join, and the person who invited him either gets a loading screen for 20+ seconds that ends with an error or he gets put in a game with a random person on your team that you are either forced to play with or dodge the game and make him play with a AI (which makes me feel bad doing that) talking about playing with a random person in 2v2s, you can't see their deck before the game starts so you have no idea if you guys will be a good match together until the game starts (No chat doesnt help either), and if you aren't it's too late. Also because theres no true lobby, there is no way to rematch someone which is bad in a versus game based on RNG, some people would like to play the same person again because they lost cause of a bad draw, and wants to see if their deck is actually better in a larger sample size. In the older games you could change your deck and fight the same person again which was also great. Another thing is there is no chat box. I can understand not having voice chat, but no chat box? Having no communication in a multiplayer game like this is beyond silly, especially in 2v2s, talking to your teammate is a really good thing this game should have, the multiplayer is so incomplete and bugged. I don't understand why they didn't think to add those features and how those bugs even got pass one day of testing.

So 2v2s are impossible to play over 95% of the time, this is so broken i have no idea how they did that, seriously.
The 1v1s are perfectly fine and work as it should, so atleast thats something.

Now we'll talk about unlocking cards and content ingeneral.
I really, really don't like the lock on how many coins you can get a day, it's a really hard cap too. Instead of having a cap they should have had a lesser percentage for the day based on how many coins you have gotten, i'd rather them have
nothing but they wont do that cause they need to make money somehow (boosters), they are a business so you can't expect them to not have some sort of money grab in a f2p game. Speaking of boosters, i feel like they should have color themed Boosters but i can see how that wouldn't be necessary as of right now due to the lack of cards which is a bad thing, moving onto that...
I don't like how most of the cards in the previous games aren't in this one, i don't get why they would do that, but intime im pretty sure they will all be back, but until then that's a huge, HUGE thing that's horrible, game's should not remove core content from previous games, it's devolving and just not right. Now the gameplay is great, if you like the way magic works, you'll like it, it's simple really, it's a shame the rest of the game isn't good enough to match the perfectly good gameplay, it would make this the best sorce of playing Magic.

Also a little bug that i think is worth mentioning cause i really hate it when games do this, if you have lowered the in-game sound it does not change the opening game sounds and keeps them at full, this is very, very annoying as it is really loud compared to other sound sorces on my PC when im just on it doing my regular stuff. (teamspeak, twitch, background music)

Conclusion, this game can be, and hopefully will be good. But as it is, it's way too buggy and missing a lot of things for me to recommend it to anyone unless they understand what they are getting into. I'm going to rate the game itself and the gameplay differently, cause the gameplay is so much better compared to the rest of the game that it would raise the rating of the whole game overall but i don't think it should because it's so broken, and if i rated it too low it wouldn't be fair to the gameplay.

Magic Duels: Origins - 2/10,  Way too broken, and a pretty bad economy with removed content from previous games, and missing a lot of features that have become standard in most games, i would not play it AT ALL if it was not for the core gameplay.

Gameplay: 8/10, Would be perfect if not for the lack of cards or when you are alt-tabbed the timer bar gets frozen and that no one knows that they should turn off battle effects (Please turn them off, it makes the game smoother and quicker making the gameplay overall a better experience) and that the game has poor controller support, which is weird seeing as how it's on console too.

reviewText:
Intro
Hello gamers. I am a very good and experienced magic online player and I have over 300 hours of gameplay in this particular free magic variant so my review will be a critique as opposed to a casual opinion. After 300 hours of gameplay, I decided to write the longest review I've ever made about my experienced opinion as I have strong feelings that my review is 100% accurate. If you disagree with anything I have said, leave a comment before you rate and I will happily counter discuss with you.

Review
This card game is functional versus the AI and one online player but fails to be consistent in 2 headed giant mode[2HG]; the most prominent part of the game for many gamers where up to 4 players are supported. This is because match-making in this game (and all previous magic games) is utterly terrible with endless error messages and a host system which doesn't work 50%~ of the time. Teaming up with a friend is a nightmare; half the time you don't get a friendly match made or your friend is on the opposing team which causes lots of players to leave out of frustration, thereby ruining this game mode.

I don't recommend this game if you like playing with a friend on your team as it's a big hassle endlessly inviting friends in the hope that you will get a game eventually. However, if Stainless hire more competent programmers, they can potentially have a good multiplayer experience card game but as it stands.....the 2-headed giant multiplayer experience is a nightmare and it really shouldn't be.

This is the main reason why I don't recommend this game to everyone, especially those who enjoy playing with friends like I do.

Assuming there are no error messages in this game (which is rare), many other aspects of this game work fine outside of 2HG.

Pros
1) Free magic card experience
2) Decently good card sets
3) Nice card art
4) Decently good single player experience
5) Most card interactions work as they should

Cons
1) 2HG matchmaking system.
2) 2HG host system, error messages and network errors.
3) Earning coins to buy booster packs is a long and tedious grind.
4) No rewards for 2HG. How pathetic... Fixed.
5) Minimizing or tabbing out of a 2HG game will force other players to leave after a small amount of time which forces you to play versus the AI which is utterly stupid.
6) Unfair advantages can be gained by anyone who buys coins to get better cards and therefore better decks. I'm not saying this is a pay to win game but it certainly helps the buying player.
7) Deck organisation is terrible; it should be a 1 click process to pick a deck...
8) The AI frequently makes very silly decisions which reduces the difficulty for advanced players like myself.
9) No ranked 2-Headed Giant game mode.
10) No 1v1 or 2HG leaderboards. (If you do implement it, at least make it work this time please)

Conclusion
Stainless Games simply have bad programmers! This problem has been going on for too long and the game developers need to address this massive problem as soon as possible if they want to keep their fan base.

Wizards & Stainless Games could have a great card game if they addressed these aforementioned problems in my review but as it stands, it's severely bugged and suboptimal. A better name for their company, given their track record of highly bugged games would be Stainless Magic Bugs!

11 May 2016 BUGGED CARDS Review Update
1) Jace, Vryn's Prodigy does not exile cards on -3 ability.
2) Kozilek's Return will deal 5 damage to all creature even if you press no..
3) Abbot Of Keral Keep does not let you cast from exile many of the new cards.
4) Disciple Of The Ring's tap ability does not work.
5) Fevered Visions deals 2 damage to opponent's planeswalkers ?
6) Abbot land casting will not work if you don't have a land to play in your hand or your partner has nothing to play.

reviewText:
I think I was one of the people who didn't have a problem running the game... I also played through the tutorial and got my first story quest/mission done. I really liked the heartstone vibe they gave the game. I have some cool information I was able to gather while I played and can share with those waiting for the game to be fixed:

- When you start the game you can get a free starter pack at the store that gives you 20/22 cards of each color to make your own decks and lands to go along with them.

- Right now there are 18 pages of 12 cards each ingame... so around 216 cards to collect and make decks at launch.

- First Boosters are called Origins Boosters and are priced as follows: 1x150g, 2x300g, 8x1200g, 20x3000g. Each booster has 6 cards.

- You can foil cards for 5G and it foils all cards of that type you have.

- You can get Gs ingame... first tutorial quest gives you 30g and first full main story campaign gives 150G (that's the only one I have unlocked sorry)...

- You can get Gs online by playing against other players or against bots: 5g vs easy, 10g vs medium or 15g vs hard. (I couldn't play against other players)

- The game has an option to play with a fully custom made deck or it has a deck wizard that helps you make the kind of deck you want with the cards you have (that I found quite good)

- Pricing for Gs on the store is as follows: 150g x 2us$ (1 booster), 500g x 5us$, 1250g x 10us$, 3750g x 25us$ or 7500g x 40us$.

I never played too much Magic before but I really liked what I saw here... not too flashy animation wise but functional... I hope game gets fixed as soon as possible so all can try it. Right now I can recommend this game, it looked fun and  free... gold didn't seem that difficult to get too and there are lots of carts to start.

reviewText:
If you want to play Magic casually, I'd say this is your best option. Doesn't matter if you are a new player who wants to try MTG or an old ex-player trying to scratch that MTG itch.

GOOD
+ It's free. You get a set of basic cards and earn gold for playing campaign missions, duels against the AI or online against other players. You can buy gold for real money to speed up the process of getting cards but it's not necessary.

+ The tutorial is very good. First it teaches you the basics so you can start playing the game as soon as possible. Then while playing the campaign, every time a new mechanic appears the game pauses and asks you if you want to play a mini-tutorial about that mechanic or skip it.

+ Deck creation: You can make your own decks using any cards you may have, unlike old Magic games on Steam where creating new decks was very limited.

+ Growing pool of cards. When the game was launched the card pool was very limited, but now with 3 expansions in addition to the original set the pool is getting big.

MEH
~ Deck creation interface: With the card pool getting bigger and bigger, creating a new deck takes more time than it should. The deck creation interface needs a rework.

~ No chat. Would be nice to be able to talk to the other player. But then again you avoid the flames and you can always talk through Steam when playing with friends.

~ Game won't run on some (old?) integrated graphic cards. Black screen on my old laptop, seems to be a common problem looking at the forums.

BAD
- The latest major patch (April 2016) introduced a change on how the priority system works. The devs have explained it's to make the game faster and easier to understand to newcomers, but it doesn't make any sense: the game won't hold priority for instants and automatically skip phases. This means if you only have instants the game won't allow to play them in certaion situations where you should be able. This doesn't make the game simpler for newbies, exactly the opposite, they won't understand what the f*ck is happening. EVEN WORSE; this change breaks the amazing interactive tutorial in a way that some parts of the tutorial can't even be completed anymore. The game is still worth it and I recommend it but hopefully this change will be reverted sooner than later.

reviewText:
With a heavy heart I can not recommend this game and I'll keep this review short.  I dislike ones that are long winded.

First off, I love Magic the Gathering even tho I'm far from running on the pro circuit.

I'll start with the positive:

The game is fun, and a lot of enjoyment for someone that is not playing with $200 decks for paper cards.  There are some good cards in game for the casual player that work well off each other.  If you play Magic on the kitchen table with some friends, then there are fun matches to be had.

The cons:

It's a grind and wasted time.  The booster packs you can buy with coins (in-game money) cost 150 coins and you get only six cards per pack.  I believe the pack break down is three commons, two uncommon and one rare.  Early in the game you can earn some boosters to add to your collection after running through the story mode and the free cards they give, I have only 254 cards.

Once the story mode is completed the main way to earn more coins is playing against other random players and if you win you will earn 20 coins.  I'm fine with that, the game is free so I don't expect to earn coins too quickly.  Here is the kicker, if you lose then you earn nothing.  I've played two matches online and between both of them I spent an over an hour and earned zero coins because I lost.

You can also play against the AI with three difficulty setting easy (5 coins), medium (10 coins) and hard (15 coins).  So this is even a slower way to earn coins.

Lastly there are quest" to complete.  They are things like "attack with five creatures at a time
date: five different times" or "counter 20 spells."  for what I've seen they net 20-40 coins each.  But the quest may be for deck you don't enjoy playing
recommended:
so you may not enjoy the game when running certian quest.

Also you can buy coins for real money and here is the break down in how much money will get you coins to buy a certain amount of packs and the cost of each pack.  That's a hard read but there it goes:

$1.99 = 150 coins = 1 pack = each pack cost $1.99
$4.99 = 500 coins = 3 packs = each pack cost $1.67
$9.99 = 1250 coins = 8 packs = each pack cost $1.25
$24.99 = 3750 coins = 25 packs = each pack cost $1.00
$39.99 = 7500 coins = 50 packs = each pack cost $0.80

And there are no trading or selling of cards in the game.

If  you want to learn Magic
hoursPlayed: the game does that very well.  If you are a causal player
voteText: there is some fun.  If you are an experienced player this will not be the game for you."

reviewText:
You have to be impressed with how Wizards of the Coast manage to find a way to screw up the implementation of what remains a great collectible card game.

This is an always online game that requires you to be connected to progress in the single player campaign, which gives you the in-game coin to build an online deck, and the game regularly bugs out and disconnects, erasing the progress and coin you've made. Any game that requires me to be online and then punishes me because the developers don't know how to program gets an automatically downvote.

When the game works, it isn't as bad as the last Duel of the Planeswalkers. The UI is no longer designed by someone who hates people. The cash shop, if the game gives you credit for the games you win, doesn't seem as money-grabbing as the last DotP.  A few single player campaign matchups still seem to be designed to frustrate. (The black sacrifice deck with no creatures with power more than 2 against a green deck built around getting counters by other creatures dying seems like a very odd choice to introduce new players to Magic.) I still prefer the straightforwardness of the first few DotPs, but you can tell there's still a good card game underneath the braindead implementation.

reviewText:
As someone who does not have the time nor the money to get heavily involved with actual Magic cards I found Magic Duels to be a great way to scratch that itch.

Let me put this simply:

If you are looking for a digital Magic experience that is as rich as playing the actual cardboard version of Magic and you adamantly refuse to settle for anything less, then Magic Duels is not for you.

Why?
You will likely find the truncated card selection irritating and will miss many of the social aspects of real life playing that is not present in Magic Duels at the moment. In truth I doubt any digital version of Magic will ever completely replicate all the nuances that people enjoy about the physical version

However,

If you are like me and are looking for a fun way to get into (or back into) playing Magic with out the hassle and expense of cardboard magic then look no further.

Why?
While the card selection is not 100% complete, it is certainly more than decent enough for many interesting deck building possibilities and the F2P business model for acquiring the cards seems very generous relative to other digital cardgames *cough*Hearthstone*cough*.

There are guides on the forums which can help newbies create viable starter decks out of the free cards that are initially granted after the first set of tutorials and the rest of the card selection can be unlocked at a fair pace for free by playing the AI and other players (I probably got the currency for half my boosters just by testing the various decks I've built against the AI). Still, don't expect to unlock all the cards in one day with out laying down some cash; though it can be done in about a month completely for free if you are an avid player.

A few notes:

-The game has had server issues, though they seem mostly cleared up at this point. I haven't run into any trouble playing in the past week or so.

-Some people report bugs with certain hardware configurations, I've had none. Your mileage may vary.

-Some complain about the lack of features, I agree. More features are always better however the developers have said they are committed to adding more cards/features and refining the interface in the future. Specifically, new cards are suppose to be added on the same time table as they are released for the physical card game, so that is cool.

-Some people complain about a lack of in-game chat and other interface qualms, personally I can do without it during matches. Though an in-game lobby would be cool to discuss the current metagame and strats etc...
If the devs and Wizards tend to the investment they have in this piece of software then I am sure things like this are on the horizon as they would better flesh out the already enjoyable experience that this game offers.

-Personally I wish there were more cosmetic things available to purchase in the store (avatar pictures, card table backdrops and stuff like that.) As of right now it is just booster packs and it seems like a waste to me to spend more than a few actual dollars on them as if you play regularly you will eventually unlock them all in pretty short order anyways. *shrug*

reviewText:
This is without a doubt the worst game that I have ever played. Don't take such a statement lightly; this is no hyperbole.

Firstly, the launch was outright pathetic. On release, roughly half of the people who wanted to play it could not due to two different crashing errors on startup. Additionally, there was major server instability. This had two major consequences:
since all progress requires a connection to their server, it was impossible to gain and keep gold.
despite 1, the game still checks for local data when it doesn't have a connection. Accidentally choosing to use local data (the consequences of which are not explained to the player) will overwrite all of your data on their server.So, within the first week many people could hardly play and/or were losing all of their gold/packs. People who didn't fit into this category couldn't even boot up the game successfully. Once the servers became more stable, the game was still riddled with hundreds (probably thousands) of bugs. Here's a short summary of a few:
If your opponent leaves while searching their library, the replacement AI never picks anything and you essentially softlock.
Sometimes opponents cast spells that they simply don't have the mana for. Whether this is hacking or a bug is sometimes hard to discern, but the devs don't seem worried about it either way.
There are a number of cards that straight up don't work in the way that they read. Under very different circumstances this would be more reasonable considering the complexity of MTG.
Two-Headed Giant, the whole reason I wanted to play this game, is all kinds of bugged out. More often than not it will just fail to work and you'll have to retry. Sometimes it will try to load five people into the game and kick your partner as a result. Sometimes you'll start the game and your partner will be on the opposing team. I'd say about 1 in every 30 connection attempts is a successful one.
There is a limit on gold earned per day, this is fine. What is not is that its reset seems to be dependent upon a way in which you talk with the server in an unrelated way. As in, it's fairly unpredictable. Sometimes I'll log on after a week of not playing and see that I've just hit the cap.
There are a lot of minor bugs that I'm either unaware of or I don't have time to explain in this already-lengthy review. Trust me, even these pile up whilst playing.Worst of all, the communication with the community" has been completely awful. More than a week after release someone finally said a fix for the crash on startup error was in the works. This is the first we heard the devs even hint that they were WORKING on such a fix!  Fast forward a few days later
date: and the same person reported that the fix would take longer than expected. LOL!  Some other game-breaking bugs haven't even been acknowledged by the devs. As for all the other bugs

reviewText:
In my first 5 booster packs, I got an Outland Colossus and I built a deck specifically to use it. I got a couple of wins versus the AI with it and I was ready to take the deck into matchmaking. I was really enjoying the game, so much so that I was thinking about buying cards for real money. However, there was some networking issue when I tried matchmaking, and so I restarted the game to try to fix it. It said there was desync between my local game and the cloud when the game started, and so I allowed the game to sync with the cloud. Basically, it took one of my booster packs I opened, and did not refund me the 150 gold I spent on it. Of course, it was the booster pack that had my Outland Colossus in it.

GAME RUINED FOR ME. FIX YOUR ♥♥♥♥. NOT BUYING CARDS FROM YOU WITH REAL MONEY.

Edit: Been playing 2v2 matchmaking games recently, and it takes several failed matchmaking attempts to get into a real game. The game is just all around buggy, but still fun. I'll change my review to positive if the bugs get fixed. I really want to buy cards, but still can't justify doing so yet. Awaiting fix...

Edit: Matchmaking is breaking SO much. It is really hard to get into a two-headed giant game with my friend. We find that if you wait 35s before clicking random opponent it seems to work 50% of the time instead of 2% though.

Edit: I wish there was a reward for doing two headed giant
voteText: 44 of 61 people (72%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Whilst this game has potential, especially when it expands with the release of subsequent Magic sets, the game it currently not in a fit state to be reliably played online, with near constant disconnect issues. Since acquiring new cards relies on a currency that must be earned whilst online this makes advancing exceptionally frustrating, difficult and sometimes impossible; A VERY poorly handled launch.
Like I said, I'm sure it will improve in time and I will revise this review, but for now if you want a frustration free experience... give it some time.

Pros:
- Deck building with complete control
- More interesting cards than Duels 2015
- 2HG (which shouldn't have been removed in the first place so... this is *just* a pro.)
- An ever expanding card pool in a permanent client (proof coming in October with Battle for Zendikar)

Cons:
- Very limited card pool (for now)
- Monotonous singleplayer experience (obviously I guess... but no puzzles and annoying AI)
- Horrific and in some cases game breaking connectivity issues due to unstable servers (again, for now...)

Summary:
Give it a couple of weeks for them to sort their act out and it'll be the most accessible digital MTG experience to date. If they leave it as it is, it'll flat line and die. Wake up and smell the Hearthstone Wizards! (I don't even like Hearthstone...)

reviewText:
My Review of the game so far,

Pros: -> Magic the Gathering free to play.
-> Introducing the final set of magic cards.
-> Back of the two-headed giants.
-> Good grind of coins (ease of acquiring gold)
-> Campaign with history of the Planeswalkers & Multiplayer

Cons: -> Two-headed giant does not work well with multiplayer, always presenting bugs especially when you try to play with a friend in steam.
-> Few cards, even with new set every 3 months (theoretically), the game presents few cards.
-> Not possible to complete quests using a deck you built, only works with decks built with help from the wizard.
-> Campaign with slow decks, weak and boring.
-> When an opponent gives up the game, you must continue the game playing against an AI, and if u lose u dont gain any coin. Thats wrong, if the player Gives up in a game he considers that he lost, the victory should be yours, its your right, Magic has always been a Psychological game as well.
-> Game in general, with large bugs.
-> Lack of chat in-game, especially in the two-headed giants.
Verdict: Magic Origins, it is a good game to kill that little taste of nostalgia, but the way it is right now, I recommend playing at most about 4-5 days and to stop there. The game has to be improved enough to handle players, does not bring a lot of motivation to stay dueling. You will, from a moment on, always see the same decks and/or strategies. And the cons outweight the pros after  the first week of gameplay.

reviewText: Magic: the Gathering itself is great, but the advantages of this computer game start and end with the tutorial. Story Mode is fair since AI uses real libraries with random hands unlike it is in Magic 2014, for example. Unfortunately, there are poorly designed decks like the one in infamous Liliana's campaign. As for common duels, progress with collecting cards is extremely slow and too luck-based if you don't buy gold for real money. If you play with AI, the choice of difficulty doesn't affect your opponent's library, so you might easily win on Hard but encounter an opponent with four mythic cards on Medium when you don't own any for your deck. There are archetype decks which are much easier to build out of the starter set than the others, but it quickly becomes boring to farm in-game gold with the same strategy. In personal quests, you often get tasks like winning 4 games with a weak deck and winning 2 games with a decent one, and both have the same award. Community quests that last for several days are usually completed within first 24 hours and then just occupy the slot uselessly. Sometimes there is an impossible goal to achieve, and once there was a quest that didn't work at all, having 0 in its counter for the whole time being. Developers just didn't give anything to care about it. Also, there is no in-game chat (even in two-headed giant games), no any awards for two-headed giant victories, and network games just get stuck from time to time.\n\nI highly recommend playing real MtG and maybe spend some free time in Magic 2014 to have some practice. Magic Duels, however, is pretty poor.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about this game. MTG by itself still has a soft spot in my heart and in a way this game works better than the previous clients done by WotC. Just the fact that we're now allowed to make our own decks is big improvement. But has the gameplay itself improved?

Unfortunately no. Game is riddled with bugs. I've had my combat phase completely skipped a few times and sometimes I am not allowed to activate abilities or stop the clock even though I normally could.

Another thing is the connection issues. Searching for a game is tedious because it seems that if either player disconnects (which seems to happen way too often) the matchmaking will just stop. Who thought this was a good idea? If there's a disconnect, just reset the matchmaking queue and let the player wait for an actual match, no one wants to press that find opponent button all the time after queue failing.

Technical issues aside, let's get to the game design. User interface is a joke! Why is the stop timer, the most important button in the game, in the lower right corner when I need to keep an eye on the centre of the game? Furthermore, if you game designers put the important UI buttons in a bad place, at least have the decency to force the steam notifications to top right for example... In the genral the UI is pretty bad (menus etc) but the actual action buttons are horrible. Keybindings are necessary in this game so thank goodness for those.

Why do I have to finish a game when my opponent leaves? Frustrating and time consuming, tedious is the key word here. And why is the matchmaking so horrible in general? I get matchmade with lvl 9 accounts when I'm 1. Also aside the matchmaking, the business model is off the records pay to win unless you are really lucky with your booster drops. Even in Hearthstone you can at least craft the cards that you want, but here you just have to wish for good cards.

reviewText: I played Magic for years and was excited to find out about this. The game is fun for a while before the downsides add up too much. The interface is terrible in so many ways that I don't even know where to begin. Dailly quests often have to be done using the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ deck builder(God knows why). Despite the pause function, some phases of your turn(or your opponent's) just slip away before you can use your instant spells or abilities. Then there's the appaling matchmaking which keeps crashing, and after about 5 attempts to find an opponent it's hard to convince yourself to try again in stead of just quitting and playing something else. The main story was fun, but so lame at times. Since you don't build your own deck in the main story, it often felt like all that determined whether you won or lost was what you drew in your opening hand(in other words how many times you restarted until you got a good hand, after which you simply roll over your opponent).\n\nThis game has potential, but like many other Free to Play games, they released it before it was ready and it will probably not last long as a result.

reviewText:
Another year. Another flawed MtG product from Stainless Steel. I've already skipped 2015 version. Would have skipped this one too. But now it's free to play, so i've tried it.

* Boring story campaigns (5 fights with the same underpowered generic deck in every campaign).
* Quests not working (or they only work with the decks that are created with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t wizard).
* Achievements sometimes doesn't register with Steam and you have to redo them.
* Network part again falling apart no matter how many patches they release. Still no propper lobby, just a random search for players. Too often not finding anything.
* Many visual annoyances (though they've got rid of that awful menu system of 2015 version, at least), like Block or Combat icons obstructing view. Little pointing arrows telling you what to play. Glow around a playable card nearly invisible when you hover over it. When you play online you see same glitches when you attack like 5 years ago. It's the same engine with a few tweaks over and over again.
* Same flawed RNG which stacks same cards together (whether lands or multiple copies of one card)
* Stupid automatic land tapping (yeah, yeah, you can press that button, wait, which is it? to manually alter it, but com'on, so many years and they can't tackle that)
* 2HG is back, but there is no CHAT..
* The game will occasionally crash (almost two months after a release, forums are filled with reports)
* Will be not surprised if this game has the same bug with disappearing steam cloud saves as with all games in the series (so i have disabled steam cloud for this game right away).

I'm still playing through campaign to find out all the Origins story line and trying to entertain myself by completing few achievements. Have built one deck, but the pool of cards seems limited. Will probably try opening few boosters with the coins i have earned in the campaign (not spending any real money on this). So, after the campaign it is only MP. MP is fun occasionally (with some sort of communication), but i prefer playing offline against AI, completing lenghty campaign with some deck and seeing how it compares to other decks. With only MP i will uninstall it soon.

Missing 2012-2014 versions, with lots of decks to unlock, huge campaigns, some sort of a unique game mode.

P.S. latest patch introduced automatic skipping of phases when you have no creature or sorcery to play. Makes it pain in the ♥♥♥ to play with instants and some intricate abilities as you have to constantly hit pause all the time. They say this should speed up games. Yeah, at the cost of losing battles because of that.

reviewText:
Playing some Magic with free cards sounded like a good enough reason to at least check this game out.  I played through the tutorial and the first Origin story, which is required to unlock the game's other modes, and to accumulate in-game currency.  Then I was prompted to make my own deck by opening some boosters including a few more from the tutorial money.  I included my cool new rares and beat up an Easy AI, then took a break.

When I reopened the game a few hours later, I got a Steam cloud sync error and then somehow an entire booster pack of cards was removed from my collection.  The deck seemed bugged (negative cards in collection, cards grayed out) so I reloaded from the cloud only to find it entirely gone.  There's something wrong with a collectable card game where the cards can suddenly vanish.

Avoid this.

reviewText:
I was very excitied about this game, as with the hype it recieved (and the dissapointment i felt from DotP2015) i was hoping for a game that would be great for new players and more experienced players alike. Unfortunatly, it fails to deliver in many aspects that I feel like it could have easily fixed
+ Is free (technically)
+ brought 2 headed giant back
+ Keeps the fun of deckbuilding and custimization
+ optional tutorials for newer players that are not forced on older players
+Story mode that ACTUALLY goes into the lore of magic (for once)
+ FINALLY allows you to use planeswalkers card types

-Can be pay 2 win as people who buy boosters will probably have more cards and be able to win more (thus getting more gold and getting MORE cards)
-for the momment, very limited card pool to chose from, allowing very limited style (and limited power) decks
- a lot of disconnect issues, although hopefully these will be fixed soon
- if not paying for packs, getting gold to get them can be VERY grindy, and some of the quests dont even work to give you your gold
-types of cards avaiable basically force you into differn't archetypes based on your colors ( if your black green, based on the avaibale cards, its probably going to have to be G/B elves for example)
- Can be diffcult to find opponenets in multiplayer, particularly for 2 headed giant.

One of the biggest issues I have with the game however is that in the story mode it specifcally shows you differn't cards that certain characters will you against you (such as Alhemmerat using fog banks to protect himself to use mill cards on you) However can you use some of these cards to help amplify your decks or give you differn't styles of decks? Nope, in fact the cards are nowhere to be seen, which makes about as much since to me as this game has in general sometimes. Why bother programming the cards to use for a SINGLE campaign level, to then never be touched again, and then just decide to not let players use them? Want to use jace's mill deck or cards? Or how about the eldrazi cards that are used in Nissa's levels? Whelp sorry, even though we programmed them and their here, you cant have them.

The only reason I can think the above statement is the case is if wizards is saving those cards for future expansions and wants more $$$, which honsetly with how this game is, I could see being the case. Although this game is fun, and is technically free, I wish wizards would just go back to the design team for M14 and use that, becouse THAT was a great game, and had tons of fun features and decks to choose from compared to this. Even though this is getting a negative review for many reasons though, I will say that its still something to try out with a friend or maybe even just to play the campaign to learn a little bit of the lore of magic or something.

reviewText:
This game has a lot of potential, and could turn out amazing if the devs listen to the feedback that the fans have! For now though, I suggest skipping this game and picking up one of the other magic games on steam despite this one being free.

Pros:
-Great Deckbuilding! It is really awesome and you can build a deck from scratch with whatever cards you acquire!
-Lots of new cards not in the previous games, but also some returning ones that I couldn't live without.
-Two headed giant is a lot of fun to play. I love the teamwork based strategies that you need to use.
-It's still magic. And magic is... well... magical. Play it if you haven't before.

Cons:
-Matchmaking/server issues. This is a gamebreaker right here for me. The servers are extremely unreliable, which I wouldn't even mind if I could play the campaign while they were down! But you can't. That's right it blocks your progress and gold you made in the campaign if you can't connect to their servers. So that Liliana duel you've spent ten hours on trying to beat and then finally beat it, might just count for nothing if you randomly get disconnected from their servers. *Pro TIp* you will.
- Extremely small amount of gold earned outside of the campaign. Yeah I get that this game is F2P and they need to make their money somehow, but at least let us earn gold in two headed giant, and make the gold gained based on how long your duel takes. Because getting 20 gold for both an hour long duel and a 5 minute duel seems a little unbalanced.
-No chat function. At all. Like seriously. Where is it? How am I supposed to tell my scrub-lord teammates not to sacrifice all of our creatures now. Or even applaud them and give them super high fives when they do something so awesome that helps us win the game? It's definitely not as fun without chat. Magic is a social game... why take out the social aspect of it?!
-UI. The UI is okay but needs to be polished up a lot. I keep seeing cards upside down, damage and defense numbers sideways and floating off the card so I can't see them, and even a couple of errors in the game where cards do not do what they're supposed to do.
-Damage animations. Half the time I spend dueling people online is spent waiting for them to finish watching the damage animations. Please disable them for online play.
-Not necessarily a con but being able to customize your playing field with different backgrounds would be very nice and add some much needed variety into the playing field.

Summary: How long have they been making magic video games now? 4 years? I'm suprised they haven't figured out how to improve on their last games yet. It almost feels like they went backwards with this one. If they fix the little bugs and server issues this game will be very fun for a long time. It would be really great to see them continue updates for this and always be adding new cards/game modes/ etc. My final verdict on this game is to play it if you've never played magic before because it's free, and you can't really go wrong with a free game if you're just trying it out. But if you have played magic before and you're a fan of the series, stick to one of the old ones.
