reviewText:
Magic fans beware... Wizards is afraid to make a decent digital game.

At its core Magic the Gathering is a social game. A game to enjoy with your friends (or frenemies) laughing, talking smack, and dropping game winning bombs. Wizards of the Coast seems to have forgotten this. IF YOU CHOOSE TO PLAY WITH FRIENDS YOU CANT EARN GOLD, and gold is important. Gold is so important that they have implemented a DAILY CAP, understandable considering gold unlocks everything in game. But get ready for a long and boring 1v1 grind against the computer or random oponents, whom you can't even speak to. If you choose to Play for Free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards. With a daily cap I'm not sure why you can't earn gold in 2HG mode or even Free4all with buddies. YOU CANT EVEN LOBBY UP WITH FRIENDS.

Magic Origins wants to compete with Hearthstone, show it who rules the roost of TCGs. Too bad it can't without an overhaul of the system. If you play magic on Steam, you can't play your account on IOS, PS, or XBOX. Meaning you will have to START ALL OVER ON EACH PLATFORM. Another month or two of grind, or cold hard cash. This could be a greed driven decision by wizards, or ineptitude, either way it's bad. Plus Magic is BUGGY, broken cards, broken mechanics, broken leaderboards, and connectivity issues.

Magic for some reason seems to hate letting you build decks with any kind of consistancy, limiting the number of rares you can own to 2-3 and ultra rares to 1. With a total of 256 cards you would assume to see the same cards u see dropping for the paper release. This is not the case. You're stuck with a ton of bad filler cards from past years and then rounded out by a few of the actual origins cards. I hope this isn't the case for upcoming expansions.

In my opinion Wizards is just plain afraid to make a decent digital magic game. Afraid that if they do it will hinder the sales of its real life counterpart. To that I say, warning Wizards. Magic the Gathering is the OG of TCGs, but unless the OG adapts to the present, the young bucks like Hearthstone will bury it. Have some confidence in the franchise and produce a digital game you can be proud of.

Believe it or not I'm a huge fan of MTG, and can only hope that Wizards will update this game. Solving the issues addressed here and adding content like Drafts, Sealed pools, Archenemy, Planes Chase, and Commander/EDH. Most importantly the ability to make a lobby and play with friends. WITHOUT FRIENDS TO PLAY WITH, MAGIC CARDS ARE JUST PRETTY PICTURES.

reviewText:
Giving this a hesitant thumbs-up but the review is more of a PSA. If you're curious as to why this game has such a low rating, I can boil it down for you pretty quick here. It's not a bad game overall - in fact it's essentially the same as every other year - but Wizards has made two pretty aggravating mistakes.

1. This is an online-only game, and the online servers are not very functional. They work *much* better now, but at launch there was simply no playing this.

2. The story mode (which was the main draw for many players, as it fleshes out some lore elements that have been mainly untouched for a couple of years) is pretty awful. You're given a pre-built deck, to fight another pre-built deck, and you do this twenty five times. All fifty" decks involved (most are variants on eachother) are just bad decks and games routinely run into the 30-45 turn mark

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game FOR NOW to anyone who is used to MTG.
As an introduction to Magic this is OK as it's free, and has an interesting (but limited) puzzle campaign and is as good as MTG 2015 when it comes to learning the basics of Magic.

PROS
- It's free (obviously, I know, but when it comes to Magic, free is something you can point out)
- Nice little puzzle campaign
- Finally a 2vs2 mode in a MTG game

CONS
- The UI is horrible
- Plagued with bugs (like first strike resolving or not - depending on the weather it seems - or creature dying in comba for whatever reason)
- Network code is broken. It's impossible to join a game, you get frequent de-sync and even joining a session is a nightmare.
- Bizarre limitations when it comes to deck building. For instance you can't put more than 2 rares of the same name in a deck, but the games never tells you that, leading to non-valid decks.

I hope it will get better with time because right now only the bugs and horrible network code are he real show stoppers for me.

reviewText:
Magic Duels is a complicated review.  I'll start with what works well.  And by that, the entirety of it is the fact that my friend 300 miles away can play Magic with me.  That's great.  Beyond that, there are entirely too many issues to make this game worthwhile.

Firstly, the gameplay is solid on the surface, but suffers when complex combos come into play.  For starters, if I play something that costs one swamp and we'll say one colorless, it will automatically tap two swamps, prohibiting me from using that second swamp for another card.  As well, the instant abilities (and by this I mean activated abilities on creactures or enchantments), only sort of work.  I played a game recently where I attempted to use the Nantuko Husk's acitvated ability to avoid losing it, and it was akin to swinging my arms around and hoping something stuck.  These are just a couple of examples of how the rules have been poorly translated to interactivity.

That being said, if you are hard up for some Magic, this may do the trick.  But I want you to know, going into it, that in addition to the above, the matchmaking is subpar at best, and oftentimes, if you and a friend try to play a match, it will kick one of you and insert an AI opponent.  This game does the trick, only in the sense, that you and someone else can play Magic.  That being said, it's not necessarily, or even often, an enjoyable experience.  I hope that there are significant improvements to matchmaking and simple instant-level gameplay (and by this I include activated abilities) in a very-soon-to-come update.

I want this game to be a good one.  I simply cannot in good concsious say it already is.

reviewText:
As someone who grew up playing M:TG, I was curious to see how they translated it online.
They seem to have done a fairly good job of translating the rules to the computer, but unfortunately they made some design decisions which I found to be large negatives.

Most online card games have a series of continue buttons to click when you finish a phase, or when you have the chance to react to the other players actions. Unfortunately Magic Duels takes the opposite approach. You need to actively pause a timer in order to take an instant" action. You also have to wait for the timer
date: you can't fast forward. This decision made playing games feel too long.\n\nIf you play an hour and that doesn't bother you
recommended: then this might be a good game for you. You can fairly easily earn gold to buy packs and you can play against humans or AI.\n\nJust because I personally don't like the interface doesn't mean it is a bad game. Give it a try and decide for yourself."

reviewText:
(sry if my english isn't perfect)

Pros:
- It's Magic! And Magic is an awesome trading card game!
- Its's free!
Sooo.. there is no reason why you shoudn't download this game and try it out. :)

However, I can save you the time. :/
Cons:
- The Cards you start with are crap. Surprise surprise. But there are even worse than you would expect. If you start playing Magic in real-life, you usually start with a starter-deck for ~10€, so you have sth. that is playable. Here, you have just a bunch of random cards, and almost no good ones. You simply won't be able to get a good deck together the first week you play this game (3h+ a day).
- The whole content seems not be able to support some decent possible deck, since it's rather common (30% of the matches) that the AI (which has access to all cards) does not play a creature before the 5th turn.
- Surrendering Players get AI'd, so you can still lose the match or you don't feel to have won a match against a human. So the key element (PvP) is obsolete since the AI-matches give you almost the same amount of gold (15 vs. 20) while beeing so much easier.

Conclusion: After playing a longer time, and grinding myself to death (due to the 6-Cards-Booster this takes forever) I have no good deck, almost no progress and no fun.
But thats just my opinion.
There are some reasons however, that are not so easily to dismiss.

Bugs
(there are tons of them reportet, but I will only tell about those I had to notice.

- Finish a quest and getting no reward.
- An opponent managed to play 2 Lands in his first turn (without card-effects)
- Card-effects that are bugged (rarely, but this is a no-go)
- Sometimes priorities and the stack won't work like they should according to the rules (Effects are resolving at the wrong time, not always top to down)

Well.. its like an early-access-game. Little content, bugs, pay to win, no, pay to have fun and I will not pay nearly as much for a virtuel card as I would for a real (6-cards-booster for 1,70€ vs. 10-cards-booster for 3€) in a game that isn't even working properly.

Do not support this game.

reviewText:
Absolutely unacceptable and irredeemable.

One would hope Stainless Steel/WotC learned a little bit about last year's Duels fiasco, but it seems they have a learning disorder. Please note that at this time, MTG Duels has many connectivity and technical issues; I am not even going to take those into account, as that is typical of a launch, plus I didn't experience much of it myself.

This game's biggest sin by far here is greed. For now, let's put aside the whole gold cap/microtransaction bit and focus solely on one thing: the god damn cards. They're all HORRIBLE. They refused to use the entire Origins set and instead opted for the most unplayable garbage filler cards. One can only assume this is so people will continue to play paper MTG or MTGO, however this does not make for a fun game. They cannot afford to half ♥♥♥ this when Hearthstone has such a firm grasp on the online TCG market; they really need to step up and be a viable competitor and axing out all the good cards from your set does not make a good game. I can honestly see this being a strategy in order to make their first expansion addition sell better; they simply make the base set ♥♥♥♥, make the expansion amazing and bam, people want to buy the cards NOW to get something decent. I wouldn't even mind if some of the cards were decently playable, but they're just not. You get ONE blue counterspell that costs FOUR mana, two black kill spells that both cost FIVE mana, a white exile that costs FIVE mana, red burn spells worse than SHOCK and absolutely no good green beasts worth mentioning.

Let's move on to the gold system and the rest of the game. There's a daily gold cap, which I understand quite frankly. Unlike Hearthstone, there are no excess cards here. You just get cards until you have them all, so packs need to be more limited by that nature. However what isn't fine is pretty much every facet of multiplayer. There is no chat with opponents, no lobbies with friends (something previous DotP had), and no gold to be made playing with said friends. Gold acquisition falls squarely on random matches against online players you'll never interact with, a one time run of the story, and fighting hard level AI. This makes earning gold time consuming and unfun, a clear push towards purchasing and another check mark on the greed list.

Even as a single player game, this game fails. The story mode has absolutely nothing on nearly every other DotP entry in terms of variety and length. Their existence is there just to pad out more time in order to frustrate you into buying gold. The single player opponents have well put together decks that you simply cannot reliably match with your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ card pool. They will win and you will be forced to draw an absolutely perfect scenario in order to win. This makes victory less about skill and more about pure luck, which is a horrible thing to do to MTG players.

I can't think of a single positive thing to say about this game. The music sucks, the font is harder to read, the buttons in combat are placed poorly, there are no special modes (archenemy, plane chase, etc), playing with your friends doesn't allow you to progress, the cards suck, the AI has unfair advantage, WotC is extremely transparent about wanting my money and despite taking longer to launch on PC, the client still has issues.

WotC needs to get in touch with reality before seriously attempting to step into the digital TCG realm.

Edit: 2HG gold is back. Not all the bugs are fixed. Card pool is very diverse and the meta is great. We need some big fixes but other than that the game is fantastic.

I don't usually do reviews. But this one deserves one as it is F2P and the tweens have come out in numbers because we have had a few days of connection problems. Other problems from the manchild fanbase amount to the game being too hard, grinding being too hard, and all kinds of other ridiculous things among a few valid concerns. Some problems do exist but they are pretty minor, and I will get to them later.

Personally, I have grinded only a bit and already am steadily winning matches and easily unlocking many good cards. I think the key here is this game is complex. You need to be able to build decks correctly and if you can't well you are going to have to learn. This isn't Hearthstone, so if you prefer a much easier and less complex game there is always that for you.

Another thing is the constant moaning about unlocking cards through gold. The game is FREE. Once they sort out community challenges and patch a couple of bugs the game will be very smooth. The so-called veterans complaining this isn't as complex as normal" Magic are full of it. This game has all you need for a Magic veteran no longer interested in paper. I don't have time for paper

reviewText: I really like DOTP 2014 but I gave 2015 a miss due to poor reviews, so I was looking forward to Duels. Unfortunately, I have to say that this game has been a huge disappointment. Aside from all of the glitches/technical problems that others have mentioned, I have found the story mode to be unbearably boring and generally not fun. My main issue is that, in DOTP, you could choose the deck you like at the beginning and then gradually unlock cards that you can use to modify it as you go along. You could also unlock new, better decks as you work your way through chapters. In Duels, however, you get stuck with a new, terrible 'intro'-level deck for each chapter of the story. These decks are not possibe to modify; when you unlock new cards, the game just throws them in there without consulting you. There's nothing fun about playing with a deck entirely composed of crappy 2/2 creatures with no discernable combo opportunities. It basically just boils down to replaying each incredibly boring opponent over and over again until, eventually, you can widdle their life down to zero. This might be an OK model for people who are just now learning to play, but people who actually have a moderate grasp of the game will probably just feel like it's a huge waste of time.

reviewText: I have played every magic game that has been released from 2012-2015. In saying that, I was a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at Magic Origins and I will tell you why. First off, lets start this on a positive note by saying thank you so much for bringing back 2HG. 2HG was the ONLY reason i played magic and was upset when 2015 didn't have it. Now lets go into the negative side of things. Devs what the hell are you thinking? You created a new matchmaking system where it places you into like a queue. It was a good idea, if the ♥♥♥♥ worked. You stopped the lobby system.... but why? The lobby system actually worked. So why change something that didn't need fixing. Well guess what, it backfired and your matchmaking system is so freaking broken it literally took us 20+ times for me and a friend to finally get into a match together and sometimes it even put us on opposite teams. Thank you for the 450 gold that was generous, but you couldv'e kept that, and fixed the servers so we can actually play. Fix it or lose your loyal customers!

reviewText:
I have played magic since 5th edition and have several MTGO accounts. Hasbro has a reputation of not funding magic products appropriately or otherwise short-changing or whoring out the franchise. In that regard - they do not dissapoint here. They live up to the hasbro name. This game is ready for a technical alpha - it should not be released atm. There are many issues from crashes to bugs- some more annoying bugs might be the inabbility to earn more than one fifth of a single booster pack in a day because the game cannot accurately keep track of how much gold you have earned.

I do not expect this product to be properly supported at all. This is not the type of game which will recieve regular patches and updates. It is the type of game which hopes you buy a bunch of boosters and suffer through buyers remorse when one content update occurs a year. Do not fool yourself into thinking the game is or will ever be more than it is currently.

This game is a cash grab. It does not hold a candle to hearthstone in any way. It has less cards, it doesn't reward ranked play (hearthstone pays dust and gold cards based on monthly rnaking now), it is covered in bugs, it has irreputable companies involved which are not known for good digital products, it hasn't recieved a single update since I have played. There are no plans for the expansion of this game; there is no information available for any direction it is supposed to take. This game is not supported in any way (no future, no lore, no story, less than 5 paragraphs on the damn wizards website). Hasbro should burn to the ground for what they have done with the magic franchise.

The game is a complete let down for me. Heartstone will continue to lead the trading card game market into the future and hasbros share of the market will continue to shrink compared to the mamoth blizzard entertainment. It is evident they do not want this game to succeed; but stingy lazy hasbro will pretend this was a good effort and pat themselves on the back as they sink. Jesus do these companies need new ceos.

reviewText:
The game has so many connection problems it makes it really unusable.  Since all progress in the game (ranking, gold collection) is tied to being connected, the game really stunts itself by this issue.  There are other issues that seem to drive MTG players like myself crazy, .. okay they brought back Two Headed Giant.. then got rid of the chat room.. and it doesn't appear to be a way to invite someone you know/friend to play against two other people... at least at the buggish beginning stages of this game.

The connection issue, the no chat room issue, the lack of a lobby, the problems with invites.. you would this this was the first time MTG came to Steam.  2015 was just as bad, even worse in gameplay, but at least it connected.  I am sorta not shocked that the game designers have screwed this up, since they have done such a horrible job in the past.  2014 was the last good version of this game.  The ones before it were okay, but UI was so bad in so many places.

Steam, step in and set these folks correct for us will ya?

A veteran MTG player.

reviewText:
So as an old MtG player and a Duels of the Planeswalker player, this is by far the worst version of MtG to date. This game has tons of bugs which have been around since the launch of July 2015. The progression system is purposely slow to encourage you to dump actually money to unlock cards. They also removed the option to manually progress each phase which can cause problems as the game will sometimes completely skip a phase even though you have a legitimate action to take.

It used to be in Duels of the Planeswalker, you could grind bots for your cards. Each game versus a bot would get you 1-3 cards depending on the unlock. Now you earn 6 cards after 15 games and no I'm not counting quest coins because half the time the quest rewards bug out and refuse to progress. This isn't the worst part though. They have also restricted the number of gold you can earn each day which you use to unlock cards. Each pack costs 150 gold with no price deals for buying multiple packs and a cap of earning 400 per day. This is all to wear people down with a crazy grind and tempt/force people to spend actual money to unlock cards, but it gets worse. It used to be when you spent actual money to unlock cards, you would spend $5 to buy a key which would unlock all the cards assiciated with a particular deck which would usually involve 30ish cards of which about half were rares or better. Now $5 gets you 500 coins which is enough to unlock 3 packs and have 50 coins left over netting you 3 rares or better, 6 uncommons and 9 commons. Thats a considerable drop to what you used to earn overall on all fronts of unlocking cards. This s clearly purposeful to milk players of cash.

They have removed the option to require players to manually progress each phase. I have on several occasions had legitimate plays stolen from me because the game would skip the second main phase and go immediately to end phase. I've also had the game deny me legitimate plays when I stop the timer at end phase. For example, I have a black/red steal sacrifice deck. If I use all my mana to steal your creature, because I have no mana left the game assumes I want to end my turn before I can sacrifice your creature to my Nantuko Husk so you don't get it back. Sometimes it even glitches out and when I stop the timer in my end step to try and do this, it removes the highlight around Nantuko Husk now allowing me to sacrifice the creature while the timer is stopped which means my only recourse is to start the timer again and as quick as I can activate the sacrifice ability and if I mess it up somehow and the timer finishes, they get their creature back. MtG isn't a game of rushed responses, it's about making tactical descisions which this game doesn't seem to like.

And finally theres the bugs which have been in this game for almost a year now since the launch. The Quest rewards don't work half the time and the only work around is to play with a deck made using the Deck Builder Wizard which sure is decent if you have no clue how to build a deck, but to those of us who have been playing MtG since Legends/Dark/Antiqueties, the pre-made decks are a joke. Also there's a bug in the store when you buy coins that can force you to have to deal with customer service to get what you paid for. Finally, there is the in-game mechanic bugs. When I play 2 headed giant with a friend of mine and go to activate fire breathing on my enchanted flame-kin, half of the time the ability just completely bugs out. It will activate but then sits there with the timer almost in a frozen state. After the timer ends it will use only one mana completely wasting my time as I do this 5 or more times without once popping up the menu that asks how many times I wish to pump up my creature.

In conclusion, I don't recommend this game to anyone as to me it feels like a giant buggy game designed to scam you out of as much money as possible.

reviewText: To be quite honest, I would rather they had charged a price for this game than for it to come out a broken freemium always-online piece of garbage. I understand that most, if not all, online games launch with some server issues. But come on, none of their DOTP games launched with this many issues. I'm thinking that WotC didn't really care all that much about making sure this game ran at least semi-smoothly at launch because it was free. Also, making it so you can only earn gold coins while online can  be problematic for users when the game disconnects while you're in the middle of a match, so even if you win you don't get what you've earned. And now I can't even get online at all. And to top it off, I mean, why is this game available for Steam and ipad users, but not available on android? WotC just seem to have handled the entire launch of this game very badly. I am sorely disappointed in it. I wouldn't recommend this game to my worst enemy. And that's a shame, because I love MTG.

reviewText:
Magic: Duels is an electronic collectible card game (CCG) based on the Magic: The Gathering physical card game.

What is Great about this game:

- This game is a pretty faithful recreation of the Magic: The Gathering card game, likely the best collectible card game around for a few decades
- Unless you are deep into Magic already, this is by far the best entry point into the game as a whole and generally the best way to play some quick Magic duels
- Over the decades, Magic has become a deep and sometimes complicated game (which means lots of rules to track), and playing it electronically allows you to focus on just playing such a deep and strategic game - rather than focusing on rules adjudication
- The free-to-play mechanics of buying boosters is generally fair (if a bit grindy), but one huge improvement over the physical version of the game is that you cannot get more than the allotted cards, so the more boosters you get, the more likely they are to have few commons and more and more rare (i.e. better) cards

What is Good about this game:

- There is decent variety in the types of games you can play, but they could certainly stand to have more - perhaps have the campaign available to go through with your own deck
- The campaigns and tutorials are generally good at onboarding new players
- Good use of Steam features such as achievements, trading cards, etc

What is Bad about this game:

- The game is quite stingy in the way that it hands out coins to buy boosters.  It doesn't award coins for playing against friends or playing two-headed giant.  I think they are fixing the 2HG issue, but it still seems dumb that I can't earn even 5 coins for playing against a friend
- The amount of cards and card sets available to play with is fairly small right now.  It has plenty of gameplay possibilities just with what it has right now, but it's hard not to want some more of the vast number of card sets available in the physical game
- For such a relatively simple game graphically, the performance is generally a little slow both in connecting to the network and in gameplay

Conclusion:

Unless you are already a Magic afficianado, this is simply the best way to get into and play Magic which is the best collectible card game around.

9.5 / 10.0

reviewText:
Honestly... It kind of depends on the audience...
But their main audience is likely for people who have already played Magic The Gathering.

I don't recommend it for any experienced player. This means anyone who has done actual serious deck building in the past and not rely on starter decks.
The grind is dumb and slow. It's like hearthstone where you need to purchase booster packs with in game currency.
But LIKE hearthstone, and unlike real life, you can't purchase singles or trade with other players.
Anyone who's experienced at the game knows what cards they need to make a good enough deck to beat any of the computers (since the computers appear to be mostly scripted)
But the problem is that it takes so long... and there are so many concepts that the game takes forever to explain.

The intial pool of cards is SO crappy, you can't even build a proper 60 card deck with it...

However, the tutorial system is probably very good for people trying to first learn the game. BUT I said at the beginning that I was a very experienced player, it still forced me to go through all the tutorials...

Grinding for gold in this game is long and tedious... Seriously not worth it.

reviewText:
So I love magic the gathering. This is magic the gathering. So why the thumbs down?

Well, for starters, the campaign is short, gruellingly annoying, and so stacked against you its replayability is simply waiting for the AI to be land or creature screwed so you can win. Half of the cards you are give NOBODY would EVER use. They are the most terrible decks you can build, and then the AI you fight has a deck specifically designed to counter yours. Its not hard, its quite litterally impossible. (Unless the therefore mentioned land or creature lacking hand)

This isnt what magic is about and the developers of this game should be ashamed to have created this pile. I dont even want to get into the numerous cheaty bugs the AI have pulled. Attacking without tapping without vigilance, card effects without the prerequisite action happening, and sacrificing a creature after its dealt its damage and received fatal damage for its effect.

I would love to see a hard but fair mtg game in this, but simply put, its designed to make you grind it to win. With 15 land cards being pulled in a row, or you have 1 land and 12 useless cards in a row. While this happens yes, it doesnt happen every hand. When you do finally get a good hand, and your deck plays as well as it possibly can, the AI always has the perfect counter that not only shuts you down but kills you. Like a 7/8 flying trample on turn 4..... Against a water deck with NO COUNTER SPELL....

Also just found out, you can not build a deck with fewer then 15 land, period. (When you have land draw and mana providing creatures less then a dozen land is a valid build) You ( or atleast I ) can not play against people as the game either times out one side or the other.

Imho, you want a good magic game, welp keep looking cause this aint it.

reviewText: The concept for the game is fine. However, with such a simple design, you would expect being able to play with others should be simple and easy to do. You can find an opponent but the game will spend ages trying to connect the two of you only to get a message saying they cant do it. Two headed mode is also a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. You can invite a friend to play but you cant decide if you play together or against each other. Instead of making the game playable the developers want to release new content when the current content is broken. Nobody wants new broken stuff. It also has a pay to win mechanic. Either you spend money on the broken game to get a chance of having decent cards or you have to grind through an unplayable game which exits randomly in the middle of a card game regardless of it being AI or human. You dont get to complete. You only get rewards for a win. I do not reccomend this game to anyone because even if you pay for lots of booster packs, you cant use them anyway. With the recent expansion you can clearly see which way the developers are going as no bugs were fixed and im sure many new ones have appeared instead. Releasing new content to make you open your wallet without even bothering to fix the game is utter disrespect which is a problem with game developers as of recent times.

reviewText:
Product received for free

This game first came over as an appealing game. It was free, and consisted all standard decks with good lore in the tutorial, very easy to get a hang of. In fact, contrary to the other Magic games, this one actually gave you a vanilla liberty to create your own deck.

But as I grew accustomed to this game, I noticed how AWFUL this game is. Here are some points that you, as Magic player, really need to be aware of:
- You are not granted full deck-creating liberty. The developpers have excluded many cards from the sets (like Stasis Snare or Stone Haven Outfitter).
- On top of the point above, they are disallowing you from using more than 3 uncommons, 2 rares or one mythic each type of card. That's absolute BS.
- They will not add any cards Pre-Origins. Even cards from high-demanded sets like Modern Masters, Tarkir or Ravnica, are not going to be in there.
- The start for experienced Magic players is extremely frustrating. It takes a lot of time (-or money) before you finally get a good card for your deck.
- The matchmaking in a game is horrible. Here you come with a few matches played, with your 90% starter deck, expecting to be able to fight a rank 18 player with a full custom deck.
- The worst, worst, WORST thing of this game, is that crashes are EXPLOITABLE. There LITERALLY is a way to make the other person's game crash (or permanently stall), and the developers have STILL not fixed it! People can make you lose deliberately if they were on the losing end. I can't believe the developpers are not seeing this!

This game is absolutely broken. It's either grind- or pay-to-win, the game is horribly easy to abuse/exploit in terms of making the other person instantly lose by letting their game freeze/crash, this game has SO many no-go's in what a game should be like.

I had my time done on this game. Time to head back to my local game store and play some real MtG there.

reviewText: There has been a lot of complaints recently about Magic Duels program. Some people are having difficulties in starting/launching the game. My problem is having poor graphics (black background) although the cards are visible making it unenjoyable to play. I fulfilled the requirements, read every single forum and tried every troubleshooting available but still the problem remained. Wizards has been saying they want to rectify the issue, as of now all they say is just words and I don't see any action taken yet. It would be good if they can update us about the situation from time to time. Hopefully it will be better but I am certainly not recommending this to anyone out there. Which is sad because I love playing Magic: the Gathering a lot on paper and online. Please rectify all problems before (not after) releasing the game in the future. Thank you.

reviewText:
I don't normally write reviews, but I've been so frustrated at trying to play this game over the last few weeks I wanted to take some action to feed it back

The main issue I have at the moment is that this game is really buggy. After finishing games and quests, I don't seem to receive gold half the time. Sometimes it jumps up the next time I log in, but I'm sure there have been occasions when I haven't received gold for quests at all. I'm also not receiving new daily quests at all at the moment, which is annoying as I wanted to build up a few more cards before properly playing in versus mode. Hopefully they have fixed the connectivity issues now, but I've lost gold several times due to losing connections with the servers after finishing a match, which is also very irritating.

For the actual gameplay, I feel that the layout and the way games are played works well enough. I think there have been some really bad decisions made for the campaign and quests though. The campaign is supposed to help new players learn to play the game, but even though I've been playing for a few years now I had to repeat a number of the campaign missions over and over again. The decks you are given aren't very strong against the decks you are facing, and as you can't change them you just have to keep starting over and over again until you draw a perfect hand and then draw the cards you need for most of the game.

I also think the deck wizard is terrible. Any decks I've built with it have been really weak, and you aren't able to amend them afterwards. I don't understand why they didn't stick to how it was done in the previous duels of the planeswalkers games. Duels 2014 was the first of these games I played, and it was a much better way for new players to learn. You got given several pre built decks, with a few extra cards you could add or remove, and as you unlocked more cards you could make bigger changes. That way, you started out with a decent deck, and could fine tune it as you played with it to make it fit your style. I think this game would have been much improved if it just had a template deck for each colour combination, and let you add to it and take cards out as you unlocked new cards.

What I hate most about the deck wizard, though, is that you have to use decks built with it to complete the daily quests where you have to win with a certain colour combination. As half of the fun of Magic is building your own decks, I don't see how they thought this was a good idea. Every new quest you have to build a new deck, with the wizard withholding cards you know you want in the deck and making a mess of your mana curve and lands. I pretty much only play these decks against the AI on easy, because they just aren't good enough to play any other matches.

With regards to the cards in the game, I think the decks you can build are fairly balanced, nothing is going to be too poweful, and I don't feel the game is pay to win. I haven't played a lot of versus mode games, but I've never felt I was beaten because the other player had cards I didn't have.  The problem with it is that they seem to have done this by removing any interesting cards and leaving less powerful cards. After looking at the cards you can collect, there don't seem to be many at all which are over 6 mana. I guess it means that you can't keep buying packs until you get game winning high mana cards which other people don't have, But I always felt a lot of the fun in this game was managing to play your expensive and very powerful cards.

I think the game does have potential. But even though I was looking forward to this for weeks before it was released, most days I just can't be bothered to play it. The bugs are annoying, the daily quests are boring and grindy when they actually appear, and there just doesn't seem to be much interesting to do with the cards available. Without any kind of communication with the other player, the versus mode is a bit dull as well, and half of the time players will drop out after drawing a bad hand and you play the match against the AI anyway.

Overall, I think the game could be decent in future, but at the moment the bugs and weird design decisions make it really difficult to just have fun while playing it.

reviewText:
Glitchy. Bugs. Giant oversights.

Good potential but this game hovers between borderline unplayable on a good day to infuriaring frustrating on a bad day.

First of all, it's been plagued by connectivity issues since the first day. The developers offered some coins recently to make up for it and have made some strides to fix the connectivity issues, but they don't make up for the multitude of lost matches, lost coins, lost progressions, and simple inability to play two head giant with your friend.

Second of all, the UI is atrocious for the PC. It's clearly a port from the mobile versions that came out before the PC edition, and there has been little to no attempt to take good advantage of the mouse and keyboard a PC player would use.

Third of all, there are many, many glaring oversights. There have also been countless times where either an oversight or glitch has caused the match. If you didn't turn off easy targeting in the gameplay options, and you're running a deck with black cards or that involve sacrificing, you'll find (at the time of writing) that easy targeting doesn't allow you to attack yourself or heal an opponent (valid strategies for the more advanced players). There would have been no mention of this until you tried it out in mid battle. There have also been countless times where the game has skipped my main phase (usually the second one, but also the first) or my battle phase. I've been unable to choose my blockers after having pressed the pause timer button and resuming.

All the pros to this game are due to the card game itself. There has been no time where I thought to myself, Wow
date: that was a really nice implementation of the card game." In case you're wondering about the hours I've put in
recommended: keep in mind I've played the physical card game before as well as played the iOS version when it first came out. All of the glitchiness that version had when it came out got ported right to the PC version
hoursPlayed: and all the complaints I've mentioned have come from the PC version. I was hoping the PC version would have had the time to fix a lot of these issues
voteText: but they haven't. It's actually worse off

votesTotal: I cannot recommend this game. It's too buggy with many oversights on the basic fundamentals of the game. The few good times I've had do not make up for the intensity of the frustration of losing a match due to a fault entirely on the game itself and not due to your skills
votesFunny: or going through an annoying campaign mission only to find out that the game lost internet connection (on an always connected PC) and none of your progress will be saved. A lot of people I know have complained about the lack of cards
commentsCount: but I'm more worried and upset about the very bad foundation they've set up to worry about any future card expansions. I would recommend to wait until they fix these fundamental issues."

reviewText:
I personally like this game. It is a great FREE way of playing Magic when I am stuck in a place where I don't have anyone to play traditional Magic ( you know...the cardboard variant ;) ) with.

I feel like it gets alot of hate from people for the lack of different things and bugs and so on. But most of these I haven't experienced myself. With a good, stable internet connection it should be fine, and I feel like bugs have gradually been removed. And if we are lucky they might add more things as time goes since wizards hopefully stick with this game for a while.

It can be a little boring in the beginning learning how magic works ( as a irl magic player I knew it already, but you got coins for the tutorials so...) but it is explained really well for a beginner and Gideons storyline gives a more interesting approach than just basic tutorials. I do wish there were an choice i the beginning where you could choose if you where an already experienced player or a beginner though, but you can't have it all.

The gold earning in the game is fair for a F2P game with the possibility to buy coins if you WANT to.
5 coins for an easy opponent, 10 for a medium, 15 for a hard and 20 for a player vs player win (with the bonus of an extra 20 for your first win of the day against a player) on top of the quests and the gold you get from the storylines. I have never felt that I needed to buy coins, some diligent playing and deck building experience will make it easier to earn after a while. (It goes ALOT faster than heartstone in my opinion!!)

Some people say that the AI is sometimes too good even at easy, but as always in magic a good hand is a good hand no matter if you are an AI or not. It is a game of luck in some sense, as these games usually are.

So my final conclusion is: Magic Duels is better than no magic at all. And as a F2P I think it is an OK one! :)

reviewText:
Before testing the game, i thought all those negative reviews could be explained by some reason, like bad RNG, or something. I thought.

I thought so bad.

After testing the game... story mode is not so bad. But the game IS a cash grab, even more worse than Hearthstone, which Magic Duels claims to have followed the same model. I'm sorry, but in Hearthstone... you actually have SOME GOOD CARDS to start. On here, it's just awful.

Oh, and getting boosters (By defenition, a Magic the Gathering booster pack is 15 cards, but on here it's 6 cards, so who cares!) is a drag. Battle mode easy AI are equipped with cards you would DREAM to have - but won't until you play 60 hours of those.

Playing versus players is simple - either you are against people who paid 50$ to get 32 boosters (which is 192 cards... i think i'll buy real life cards, they cost less, thank you), or either you are against the same people as you - which means 20 turns games... for pocket change.

As the game is now, you lose either way.

Oh, and there's daily quests to get coins! Yay.. or not. Because it requires ARCHETYPES deck - so you can customize it A BIT.

Honestly, i'd rather pay 10$ like for Magic 2015 to get the same type of unlocking (get a booster after clearing a story mode mission OR winning a ''random encounter'' in a plane) than this.

Only good point : It was free to test.

As the game is, I CAN'T and WON'T recommend it.

EDIT : After giving the game a second chance, i found out that sometimes, when you manage to do those hassles that are the quests... the coins they give is not always given. Just to add to the list of cons already big enough...

UPDATE (As of 2016-01-27) : Six months later, is the game better?

THE BAD

- Still not getting the right gold amounts from daily quests, or it simply erases what i had saved up to now and gives me the ''correct'' amount. Must have lost like 600 gold this way up to now.

- Hard AI as NO diversity (I do not play against Easy and Medium now.. i mean, 5 or 10 coins a game is so few). By that, i mean : Always splashes white, always play control, as soon as you know which cards do what (Looking at you, Gideon's Reproach), hard is... well, it's 15 coins. When it doesn't bug out.

- Both me and a friend opened a ''phantom'' booster. It shows the cards you got from buying... then no cards in the card collection. Kinda mad since i had finally a Kiora...

I can't believe such bugs still exists many months after the game's launch. Seriously.

THE GOOD

- Battle for Zendikar added some diversity AND some good cards that are actually usable.

- That's it.

Yes, i played about 55 hours because i had faith it could become better. The people managing this game (if there are any other than ''Mod_Chris'', because game content updates are as rare as black lotuses) could probably do much better... or just change the people managing the game. A passionate community managed to do over 3000+ cards over a few months that are all working, why can't a game company paid to do so can't?

Anyway, still not really worth it. Try it if you want though, it IS free-to-play, but i won't ever consider paying them a penny for the game as it is.

reviewText:
Magic Duels: Origins is a great introduction for beginners and not much else.

Pros: Story, Graphics, Sounds
Cons: Controls, Value

Magic Duels: Origins takes players through the lives of the five most iconic characters in Magic.  The gameplay and story weave nicely together to create an interesting and exciting campaign.  The graphics and sounds are mostly great: not much artistic or technical prowess is needed for a digital card game, but the few cutscenes definitely could have been more polished.

Controls work well enough, but some elements of the game's earlier mobile design leak through.  For example, many gameplay controls are placed in the lower righthand corner where a quick thumbpress is perfect for some hardware, but rather clumsy for others.

However, the biggest problem with Magic Duels: Origins lies in its value.  While certainly worth playing for the story, Magic Duels has so little worth beyond its campaign.  Every card could be collected given enough time, but in-game transactions speed the process tremendously.  Why spend the money?  To reach the top rank of this year's beginner program? The money would be better off spent on Magic: the Gathering Online or on the actual cardboard.

Not as terrible as Chimney Imp, but not as terrific as Storm Crow.

4/10

reviewText:
Review written ~2 Days after release. First impressions are Bad.
Pros:
1. It's Magic: The Gathering. If you like that, or similar games, you'll probably have fun with this.
2. There's plenty of tutorials which seem helpful (If a little heavy handed at times) to help new and unfamiliar players.
3. It's FREE!

Cons:
1. The servers are terrible, and you will be frequently disconnected, or offline.
2. The game is effectively unplayable while offline.
3. Number of cards available is relatively small.
4. Prepare to grind in order to get more cards, unless you're willing to fork up some cash.


At the moment, I would not reccomend this game. The biggest complaint I have about the game is the fact it requries you to always be connected to their servers, even for the singleplayer content. reviewText:
I was waiting until the March 2016 patch to write this review.  I felt it would be fair to give Stainless and WotC the extra time to produce a passable game.  Sadly, this has not been the outcome.

Magic Duels is a game that has so much potential, that it fails to even approach.  Free to play card games are generally well recieved in the video game market of 2016, and the amount of money that well made ones make is staggering.

However, for some reason there seems to be a lack of desire or funding on the part of WotC or Stainless, or both, to put together the nessecary resources it takes to produce a functional video game.

Magic Duels has the shell of a great game, but once you look inside you see the blemishes.

Numerous bugs still permeate the play experience.  The netcode is slow and frequently does not match players correctly.  The game does not allow players to accomplish things that they should be able to do in a game of Magic (such as Transforming a planeswalker with an activated ability in the second main phase).  The shuffling algorithms seem off.  The game doesn't even teach the correct rules of Magic, instead making stupid conscessions in the name of simplification that instead only serve to misinform.

I really, really, really wanted to write a positive review of this game.  I was waiting for the March update and resting judgement until they had a chance to get it released and tuned up.  I have given WotC and Stainless every chance to remedy this buggy mess of a game.

Unfortunately, considering the current state of the game, I cannot reccommend anyone play this game, unless you are completely desperate to play Magic on your PC and you don't have the money to play MTGO.

Not recommended.

reviewText:
What an honestly terrible game. I have played the magic card game for about 11 years and nearly all of video game versions they have released over the years. Not only is this version the worst one yet, but also a game with terrible design trends. It's like they looked at their Competition in the market and tried to copy them without thinking why those aspects were implemented in the first place. Hearthstone has booster packs with 5 cards, now so does Magic. Hearthstone uses a daily questing system and gold rewards, now so does Magic.

It makes me sick, it’s just lazy game design. The tutorial as well is horrid, even for this series of games. Ever wonder how trample worked? Well there is a god damn 5 minute long training game dedicated to holding your hand through it.

If it wasn’t free, I would say burn it. But it is free, so if you have an interest in the game and are just starting out, I guess give it a shot. Only until your eyes start bleeding though.

EDIT: Well in light of this review actually getting some attention, allow me to go through some simple pro's and con's to give some qualification behind my silly rant.

Pro's:
+The user interface is probably the best in the series. Considering the last installment's was slow and unresponsive, this is a good thing.
+Plot is kinda cool, everybody like planeswalkers
+It’s beginners magic, so that could be good

Con’s
-Tutorial is terrible. Like really, are player’s not supposed to read cards anymore to figure out what they do?
-The cards they give you in the starter have very little synergy for play, resulting in extremely basic decks.
-The actual games of the story missions are fairly dull and pre-set. They are more challenges of ordering and playing cards correctly, than a real game of magic.

I have had some issues connecting to their servers as well, but that could simply be up to chance. It should also be noted that there really aren’t too many improvements since the last game. The odd thing about this is that some features that were good have been taken away. Any video game player would know the feeling of a rushed production, and this game oozes it.

Hopefully this brief break down helps some people out in understanding my frustration with an overly simple and uninspired game.

reviewText:
So far, it's not a whole bunch different from it's predicessors, but I must admit, it's somewhat annoying that a player from a previous game has to sink in money to try to rebuild decks they once had.

With this aside, the story mode is what I can concerntrate on. I played though each line and I must say that they help flesh out each character, Jace, Chandra, Nissa, Gideon, and Liliana. It's also the initial way to earn coins which can be used to purchase boosters.

Somethign else that is a bother, all the cards in teh story decks stay in those decks. You will not have the chance to add those cards to your personal collection, nor can you modify the decks. In this case, every in per story releases more cards for that story deck.

When I actually get decent cards maybe I might try multiplayer. But for now, there's little much past the story mode.

I have to say compared to the previous games, the UI is slightly imrpoved, but when the UI zooms the table out when there are more cards on the field, I admit that I feel a little insecure. I laugh at this, but it's an effect that I just don't care much for.

I love the music. I do bemoan the fact that the soundtrack for this game is not available. The main theme is catchy and tends to be stuck in my head for hours on end.

I won't do multiplayer in this game at all, because any game that is Pay to Win is just not worth it in my book. earning you first 1000 in coins isn't too terribly hard, but after that, you;re all on you own. You either have to grind or play against other people.

But this is where the game is more like the real one. Honestly, even with the real cards, it is pretty much Pay to Win. However, with a terribly limited selection and the fact that I invested heavily in the previous interation, I find myself terribly reluctant to drop money on this one. Especially when packs are selling in this game slightly more expensive. A pack of 5 cards sells for $1.99 Real cards sell 15 for about $4.50. You'd do better to buy the real cards and play with friends.

reviewText: This game is sadly a very poor attempt at an MTG game.  The decks you are forced to play are poor (in both design and mechanics) and the main story quests are badly unbalanced. The annoying, un-skipable, pop-up, interrupting tutorials are boring, un-necessary and deeply irritating (especially when you are forced into one mid-game). I have thoroughly enjoyed all the previous MTG games, so this was a huge letdown.  In what appears to be a badly mis-directed attempt to be more like Hearthstone they have created a badly structured game, with an awful appearance, slow clunky behaviour, frequent crashes, badly flawed deck design and an obvious thrust toward extorting as much cash out of the player to make the game even semi-playable.  Whoever is responsible for the design and implementation of this abomination should be thoroughly ashamed of the disgrace of a game they have produced.  Utter and complete tripe.  If it were possible to give a lower mark than 1/10 I would definitely do so here.

reviewText:
TL;DR at bottom. Only recommend for particular kinda of use.
First of all, I haven't experienced any of the technical issues reported by many other users. (GTX 970, 4th generation i5 and 16GB RAM on Windows 7.)

Now, on the good bits: they've finally got the interface to work well, unlike in previous renditions. It's clean, easy to use and easy to understand. (Both with and without a lot of the gameplay automation.) The tutorial system is excellent, and its monetization system is very fair (10 wins per pack just playing hard Bots + loads of money from story mode and skill quests.)

BUT: the card pool is VERY limited, and the options you're given in the story mode are kind of misleading. A lot of fairly simple cards, like Lightning Bolt (3 damage to player or creature for a red) which appear in skill quests and story mode, don't appear in the game itself. This makes a lot of archetypes rather difficult to play, and restricts deck building options to the point where there seems to be little point in playing quite yet.

TL;DR Overall, I wouldn't recommend this for longterm players, or anyone who already plays MTG. I would, however, recommend it as a free learning tool to get newbies into Magic. Might be worth another look in a year's time.

reviewText:
UPDATE 2 APRIL 2016: So since I made this review in october 2015 quite a bit has changed. (well at least the meta has) Also I made it to 20+ rank at some point, I get maybe it wasn't clear from my review that I got further than lvl 1 ;) I will update/delete this review once I get to play the new expansion extensively.

UPDATE: I am not saying my problem is fixed but at least somewhat of a solution is to play mono aggro red or sacrifice/aggro black/red deck. I can pretty easily beat hard AI with these kind of decks even if the AI is pulling Planeswalkers, Legendary, Mythics etc etc However my point about progression and variety still stands in that because of the mana screw issues and limited card pool it seems that a lot of other 'slower' deck strategies do not seem to work.

I really am trying hard to like this game but it is such a frustrating thing to get any progression towards a better deck!! Online there's only a handful of people and even though I consider myself a pretty good player there is almost no way to win from high level people that have either earned or bought better cards. It is really unfair because the people that have already build up a good deck will have a super easy time playing online, I regularly got matched up with lvl 10-15 even though I was level 1 myself.

So the only other way to earn credits to buy more cards and improve my deck would be singleplayer, which I've already finished and got pretty useless cards for in the boosters I unlocked. So now there's only AI matches which are frustrating but doable (see update). The AI cheats. I get consistently mana screwed every match and there's just no way you'll win if you only have the 3 mana in play that you got in your opening hand. (my deck has 24 mana)

Either fix that or let me earn coins for playing a duel with my friends or in two headed giant because now all I can do is grind which is just awful! :(

reviewText:
This is Wizard's poor attempt to ride the reigns of Heartstone's success. The only problem? It's so much a Pay to Win scheme that it's sad. I mean I have no issue with the pay option to get boosters, but the rate to acquire them are just plain atrocious. If facing against AI opponents, a victory garners 15 coins, a booster pack is worth 150. That's an average of 10 duels for 6 cards. Really? You guys couldn't just give us more to work with? The AI are jacked with decks with strategies that clearly outclass you in various degrees. Maybe it was my luck, but playing the same AI through story mode 10 times is not what I call thrilling or enjoyable.

But I will say there is one aspect I deeply enjoyed, Planeswalkers. Finally, it has only taken so many years to get this point. The custom deck builder is fun and user-friendly, but not the deck wizard, it's an abomination of a deck building alghorithm for new players.

Not only that, these Quests (which are like daily things) where the Archetype ones involve using decks from the deck wizard are utterly annoying and not fun at all. But they give you free coins if you can just grind through them. It becomes a chore especially when they are using color combinations where you have not so great cards in those areas.

There is also one other feature I really was ticked about, in the older iterations of Duels, you could stop and pause the clock as an actual setting feature for every phase. Now? They got rid of it. You literally have to have the spazziest hands on this planet to hit either the Space Bar or the Mouse button on the hourglass icon. It's upsetting and while I understand that it streamlines the experience it really takes it away from the more experienced players who want to not worry about missing a chance to react to an effect or spell.

I know I do not have alot of hours logged into this game, but that's because I play physical MtG. And this game does exactly that, it frustrates or inspires players enough to actually buy real booster packs and play the actual game. It's sad when you know that at the end of the day, that's the true aim and goal of this game's current incarnation. I just wish they had actually done some more material with actually more card options besides just Magic Origins. It's a good game to teach new players, but to keep tormenting yourself for enjoyment? No thanks.

reviewText:
It breaks my heart, it really does. I used to play the original card game when I was a kid, and I recognize so many cards. The nostalgia and challenge can make me look past the pay-to-win nature of the game, but the connectivity issues. Oh my god.

Get wrecked, opponent gets you down to 4hp. Recover, build up a small army. Play a bluffing game, full of suspense and hard decisions. Eventually you manage to get him down to your hp level and for a moment, it seems that you might be victorious in a few turns if...

Disconnect.
No message, no apology, just a game that stops responding. Your calculated attack blinking in your face.

I didn't pay for any cards (although I might have, in the future) but if I had, I'd want my money back. This game is UNPLAYABLE. My score is way off because 20% of my games end in some disconnect or other.

They say they're fixing it, but after weeks, nothing has happened. What a shame, what a dead shame.

reviewText:
Let's be clear. MtG has quite some reputation.
It's a complex game and and has established a dedicated world wide fan base.
It is by no means a bad game!

But this game, Magic Duels, lacks everything most people like about the paper version.
There is no player interactions like a chat or emotes.
The tutorial is awful (in over 10 years you should be better at explaining your game. there is no excuse for this mess), and the grafical presentation is bland/spare at best and very unintuitive.
The next huge drawback is the very tiny cardpool which is probably credited to the F2P model.
To be fair, the pricing of cardpacks is atleast reasonable.

To sum it up:
A fantastic and rich Trading Card Game which is ruined by it's bland presentation.

reviewText:
Short summary:
Give it a go if you haven't played before and are curious, or if you just feel like killing a few hours with some MTG. Otherwise, or if you're a veteran of the game at all, probably best to stay away and stick to the cardboard.

Pros:
- Free.
- Easy matchmaking (although buggy atm) to allow you to play a game whenever you want from home. Convenient.
- Not heavily Pay to Win. Feels a lot like Limited with a new Cube.
- It's Magic (...buut, read on.)

Cons:
- Game loves to help you out, by skipping steps when it sees you can't play anything in your hand, and not skipping when you can. This telegraphs that you do or do not have something to the opponent.
- Game loves to help you out, by assuming that the sometimes-critical upkeep step is for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and skips it entirely unless there's something already on the board that has to be done.
- Each step gets the same amount of response time" regardless what's happening. Play a tapped land on turn one: Takes just as long to progress as when your opponent plays a boardwipe when you have a counter. Now you can pause whenever
date:
but you have to be on your toes or you might miss it (A real-time reaction speed "skill" that should never be present in MTG). Amounts to anything from a boring nuisance that you can't go faster to a real kick in the nuts when you lose the game because you're not lightning fast with a mouse.
- Lack of any priority whatsoever. You want priority? Click faster than your opponent.
- Artificial card limit restrictions based on rarity that appear nowhere in any regular formats of the game.
- No chat.
- If an opponent concedes
recommended: you don't win yet. You have to waste your time playing against an AI. If you happen to then lose
hoursPlayed: both of you end up losing rank and nobody wins in-game currency.\n- Card pool consists of a static starter box and the non-overlapping origins set that you get through money/playing. Static start results in a lot of similar decks and some rigidity to customization.\n- 2HG sometimes puts your friends on the other team. Doesn't really matter though because unless you're connected with another program
voteText:
you can't chat anyway as already mentioned.
- No FFA or other multiplayer modes beyond 2HG.
-  Rank system appears to be a linear win/loss counter. That's alright though because there's no way to view leaderboards anyway.
- Bugs and connectivity issues. Hopefully these won't be a long-term thing."

reviewText:
I love magic the gathering, but cannot recommend this game.

The campaign is boring and frustrating. You have to play with a premade deck vs decks that are only there to counter your every card. Best example is in the campaign of Nissa where you get a new treefolk card, only to have the enemy deck contain a card that specifically and exclusively kills treefolks.

The artistic design of the game is very lacking, you play every game on the same boring metal plate background. Everything except the cards is also just looking very boring.

You can build your own decks as you please, but the card pool is very tiny and aquiring new cards via gold feels more like doing chores.

One of the biggest issues though is the connectivity to the servers and to other players. Servers will randomly decide to be offline whilst you are winning - thus nullifying your victory. Also i will never understand why if a player concedes in a PvP versus battle he is then replaced by an ai - where if you lose, it will count as a loss and you will lose your rank and not get any money. Why should the game continue of my opponent gave up? I dont want to play against an AI if the other player just quits.

Also the game is expensive if you want to pay to win".

I can only see total beginners playing this game since it is free
date: but i fear they quickly will just become bored with it."

reviewText:
I started off enjoying the game but soon the fun started slowing down. After awhile the bonus's of this free game started to fade.  Here's why I can't recommend the game.

1. They have no chat system in place and as far as I can tell they don't plan to add one. Major downfall. Some times the games are slow and boring and at times you can't tell the difference between a person or the useless AI.

2. They limit your decks. Once I built a deck of cards that cost 2 or less and it was a one color deck. The game wouldn't let me have less then 17 mana. Even though I had the 60 cards required. They have other restrictions as well.

3. No reward for playing two headed giant. Why they discourage you to play with your friends is ridiculous. It also has no FFA. It's 1vs1 or Two headed giant with no reward for winning.

4. The biggest reason of all, in 20 plus years they still havent fixed the issues of getting mana screwed plus or negative. It's an ancient flaw that they seem to ignore.

It's free so it doesn't hurt to try but I think it's a lost cause. Definitely don't spend money on it.

reviewText: Hear me out: This game is very fun. It is. Magic is great and fun to play. However, this might just be the worst thought out game ever. If you are playing against a human opponent and they concede to you, you do not win the game. Instead, they are replaced with AI. This wouldn't be that bad, except the fact that despite your opponent literally conceding defeat and quitting the game, you will get no gold if you end up losing to the AI or if you leave because you want to play real people, not AI. Think about that: IF YOUR OPPONENT QUITS, YOU STILL DO NOT WIN GOLD. In what world is your opponent conceding not a win?? Why are we able to possibly deny our opponent gold just by quitting the game?? Who designed this crap??

reviewText:
In short, this is a game that should be good but isn't. All the mechanics work very well. The UI is clean and easy to use. Tutorials are in depth and quite helpful but....
its a micro-transactions pit.

The decks in the game start off as awful. They range from terrible to very terrible. Luckily you can unlock booster packs and build a better deck. Unfortunetly these booster packs are locked behind pay walls and an impossible to beat single player campaign.

Each booster pack can be bought for in game coins. The main way to unlock these coins is through the horrid single player. In campaign mode, you are given a level specific deck and cannot use your own. These levels are intentionally designed to be almost impossible. I tried 30+ times to beat the second set of levels. THE SECOND SET. I am an avid Magic player and know the game quite well. But that means nothing when you are given a Bulbasaur and your oppent has a Charizard. Of course you can skip the campaign and just buy these coins. For $1.99 you get 6 random cards.

reviewText: The multi-player aspect of this game is pefectly fine, and if you only want to play against other players I highly recommend this game.\nIf, however, you want to play the single player campaigns, you will find this fatally flawed. The story decks are utter garbage (especially for single colored decks) and the game pits you against perfectly constructed decks which can very quickly flay you apart when you are relying heavily on the next draw. The boss decks are sporadically difficult and non-difficult. The green deck boss, in particular, is insanely difficult with the deck they give you and the black deck boss is not if you have the right starting cards.\nThe developer really needs to examine the decks as they upgrade and evaluate how they play against the decks they face off against. (You guys CLEARLY know how to build a tournament level deck. Why you give the player utter garbage against it in the same breath is a total mystery to me.)

reviewText:
Name: Magic DuelsDeveloper: Stainless Games
Date: 2015
Genre: CCG
Orientation: Multiplayer
Population: Crowded
Perspective: 2.5D - Isometric
Timeflow: Match-Based
Setting: Multiverse
Universe: Multiverse
Style: Tabletop
Tags: 1v1, Competitive, Cross-Platform, Dailies
Model: F2P
Content: Collectible
Platforms: PC, iOS, PS, Xbox
Review:
As much as I love real MTG, this game couldn't give me anything but negative experience.
The game is too raw and clutchy EVEN compared to other Stainless' MTG games (which are not perfect either), in just.. all things. Like, really all aspects. Starting from small visual glitches (like 'unsynchronized' pictures shifting in lines) and menu inconveniences (like 'frozen' loadings until you click) and ending with things that actually hurt gameplay (below). I even thought it's 'Early Alpha Access' (this new Steam category which allows developers to sell Alpha versions to players x)) and went to check - no it's not. Just THAT many things are not done / done poorly, it looks like game was done in a rush.
Menu is constantly throwing same promo dialogue windows welcoming you to visit the shop. When you visit shop and/or buy a booster you get same promo dialogue window about new set, EVERY single time. Every time you visit deckbuilder, you get another window. Every time you visit 'versus' menu you get a window that you should probably play campaign first (when obviously all campaigns are finished). Since some windows can redirect you to other menu sections when you click 'OK' (and you can only click 'OK', obviously), once I was literally 'lost in menus', since one menu window was constantly redirecting me to the page where other window was redirecting me back. I had to ALT+F4. Hilarious. But that was probably the only fun moment in here.
Deckbuilder is realised as badly as one could possibly do. Cards are all stacked in two rows (top row - cards not in the deck, bottom - cards in the deck) with no possibility to even sort! You can only watch through those rows by dragging them with mouse. Filters are all grouped up in a single button on top of the screen, which opens fullscreen filter menu. And OF COURSE there is no search by name. Because WHO THE HELL IN THE WORLD WOULD BE SO STUPID TO SEARCH A DAMN CARD BY ITS NAME.
In game things. Camera can't be controlled by any means. It is locked to isometric from your POV. When the table is full of permanents camera moves further away on its own. Turn phases are skipped or not skipped unpredictably. Even with all settings set to 'full control' (that any MTG player should do: free targeting, asking about 'may' abilities, skipping), I can't say how many times I skipped attack phase just because game already skipped first main for me. There is a 'mana tapping' hotkey yet I couldn't get it working every time - in some cases game actually lets you choose mana, other times just lets hope my grey land with tap ability doesn't tap for mana now". Choosing blocking order just doesn't work

reviewText: Firstly, Wizards had no community interaction in committing to a PC release date, which was then leaked by a third party source, showing little respect for their players. Second, an easily-reachable 200-gold cap was put in place for mobile devices, giving little incentive to play once the cap was reached. Thirdly, 2HG, one of their most acclaimed DotP modes, does not give gold. Now, the servers are unavailable which does not allow for campaign progress, despite knowing the inevitable large player-base that would be downloading this game. Even worse, the games that I was able to play were affected by a black playingfield and the equivalent of 480p textures. GG no re.

reviewText:
Tedious.  Worst of the Duels Games.  Going  free-to-play sucks.

This game commits numerous sins.  Probably the worst is that the process of unlocking new cards is incredibly slow.  The points earned versus the points required to unlock cards make Magic Duels a frustrating, tedious grind, even if you focus on the relatively lucrative quests.

Or, you can just buy points, because of course you can.

It doesn't help that the flow of the games while you're playing them is also painfully slow.  The combat phase especially is littered with unnecessary pauses.

The campaign mode is also kind of a mess, but whatever.  It has no replay value.  The meat and potatoes of the game is the free duelling, and the free duelling is the perfect example of why free-to-play stinks.


Definitely the worst of the Steam-based Magic Games.  Avoid.

reviewText: I am new to magic and I saw this game and thought that it would help me learn some of the intricacies of magic.  It did do that, to a limited scale.\n\nHowever, I cannot recommend this game because of a terribly broken AI.  It reminded me of my childhood and having to deal with a rubber band AI".  No matter how good my hand was or how strong my battlefield looked
date:
the AI would always play the exact and only counter to what I had in my hand.  It made the whole experience extremely frustrating.  If I had based the entire TCG of Magic on this poorly done game I probably would walk away and never look back.

The Good:  Looks good and does teach you about different mechanics and strategy that can carry over to the TCG.

The Bad:  The game moves slow and it felt like I spent more time waiting on countdown timers then actually playing.

reviewText:
After putting nearly 30 hours into Magic Duels, I feel that I can safely conclude that it represents a tremendous step backward from DOTP 2015.

Had the game just featured Magic Origins as the card pool, it would have been decent (if unremarkable). They instead removed most efficient spells at common or uncommon, replacing them with complete duds. I'd like to slap the person who thought Siege Mastodon would be more interesting to include than War Oracle. Ugh.

Had the game given, say, a single card for each victory, then grinding for cards would have been tolerable. Even playing only ranked matches (ignoring quests, which require you to use the incompetant deck wizard to vomit up something for you to try and use) will give you a pack of six cards for every 7.5 victories. Victories. With a 25% loss rate (still decent), that's ten games of Magic for every six cards, which may or may not be of use. Playing against the AI will take ten VICTORIES for a pack of six cards. Again, this grinding might be tollerable if there were anything worth pulling in these packs. There generally isn't.

Had the game even worked as WotC intended, it might have been barely passable. Instead, it's as if Stainless is trying to emulate the stability of MODO servers. Not a good plan.

They even stripped the ability to chat with online opponents, making the distinction between playing against a person or a bot almost meaningless.

It saddens me that, while many of the mechanical aspects of the game itself are decent, and it is still FTP Magic, I can't recommend Magic Duels to anyone other than complete novices (who will find this a decent, if completely patronizing, introduction to the game) or people with far too much free time on their hands. The only reason I've kept with this is that I fall into the latter camp currently.


TL;DR: While this certainly is one of the worst DOTP games in recent memory (even falling short of the 2015 installment due to a completely bland card pool), Magic Duels is still Magic. Magic at its worst is still a decent game, despite Stainless's valiant effort to prove to us otherwise. Take that for what it's worth.

reviewText:
This game is a poor attempt by Wizards to copy Hearthstone's success. It could have been great, but a clear lack of budget and inspiration render this a poor excuse for a game.

Cons:
-Clunky unforgiving UI
-You cannot tap your lands, and must cycle through all possible land configurations
-You cannot interact in anyway before Main Phase 1
-CGI is a decade out of place
-Very limited card pool and even more limited game-mode types
-Tutorials are cringeworthy motivaitonal speeches by some generic voice actor
-Tutorials are seemingly random in their placement and you are expected to win a full match before the first one plays

Pros:
-Magic is still fun, even when it's in a hideous container

If you love magic, you'll enjoy this game with some frustrations. I encourage you to vote with your wallet however, do not buy any of the DLC for such a poorly made game.
