reviewText:
I absolutely hate to be THAT guy. I really do. I have never before this posted a negative review on Steam; in fact, I have never posted a review on Steam period. But this game. THIS GAME.

Honestly Wizards/Stainless, you had ONE JOB. ONE DAMN JOB. See the success of Hearthstone, copy the formula and rake in the mad profits. Which you could... had this game not been a broken mess devoid of any content.

More stuff that sucks about this game:

- The shuffling mechanic is borked beyond belief and if that you don't have more lands than the average you will probably get mana screwed 6 out of 10 matches and forcing to build decks based on low mana stuff so that you actually don't lose often.

- The fact that an opponent conceding a match and leaving does not award you the win and instead gets a broken AI to beat your ♥♥♥ afterwards.

- Very few cards and tangible content aside from a very weak competitive scene.

- No tournaments at all or any sort of events (seriously the Pokemon TCG got that part right IN BETA).

As a 15 year MtG veteran my advice is stay away. Stay very far away. If you need to play a good game to scratch your CCG urge, go play Hearthstone, Pokemon or Duelyst. This game is awful.

reviewText:
If you like the depth of Magic and the business model of Hearthstone, this is the game for you.

I played Hearthstone for a while since Beta and found the game too simple for someone who has played Magic: the Gathering for a good few years. This is the game that takes a good business model and improves on it.

Buying boosters with either in game currency or real money gives you 6 card per booster with guaranteed new cards for your collection, up to 4 of each. Gone are the days where you need to disenchant cards to get new ones. This system allows you to pretty much get every card effortlessly with time or money.

There's plenty of Story mode for you to practice the vrious mechanics found in the new Origins block, as well as grtting currency. Finishing the last quest for the introductory Planeswalkers' Story mode awards you currency and 3 Boosters. Battle mode allows you to play against randomized AI with 3 difficulty settings, where you get currency according to AI difficulty. There's a quest system in place which you can win currency with, along with a weekly community quest.

Overall, it's a solid Magic the Gathering game, and in my eyes, for the hardcore MtG fans, the better alternative to Hearthstone.

reviewText: I currently can't recommend this game.  It could be fantastic.  I don't know.  What I can review is the incredibly awful technical support.  I first downloaded this game, achieving a pure black screen that instantly crashed the moment I minimized it.  I then sought out their faq, which told me to fully update windows (less obvious), and then my graphics drivers (more obvious).  This didn't help, but didn't cost me anything.  I then emailed them from the reporting function on their website.  I achieved: an automated reply, telling me to update windows and my graphics driver.  I replied politely that I had.  They then emailed me personally - three days later- asking: had I tried updating my windows and graphics drivers?  I replied, less politely, that I had.  It was five more days before my final response came:\nThank you for getting us that information. Unfortunately
date: I do not have any other technical support to provide at this time. I have forwarded the information you have sent us to our developers. Please check back with us during the next update to see about possible fixes."\n\nPathetic.  I got better technical advice from nine year old redditors when I was first researching my issue.  I hope this game is good enough for me to come back to
hoursPlayed: when they fix this game for me and so many others."

reviewText: When Origins came out I would recommend this game because it was a grind game that actually had end game content. But now since all these sets are coming faster than I have time on my hand I cannot recommend this game. If you notice, I have a good amount of hours on this game and I have Origins,BFZ, and maybe 1/3 Of Gatewatch and SoI unlocked. I Was lvl 50 in origins and BfZ 1v1 rank and had 3000 coins which only unlocked me maybe 40% of SoI. This game really makes you feel overwhelmed and bogged down with money and lack of content. You could buy the packs if you wanted, but what would be the point of buying cards that will be flushed out and have no value unlike MTG:O. I'd recommend this game to players who are new to Magic, but they too may see the Grind too overbearing and the amount of cards that aren't synergistic to be confusing. I think I'd rather them have all cards unlocked from each set rather than 60-70% of the set of all cards of the past 3 sets. This isn't the only game I play and its hard to keep up with the cards since I use this as a casual sit back version of magic for me. The restraint on the game is just too High to maintain fun. 6 card booster packs for $1.99 when you can only unlock 1 mythical, 2 rares, 3 uncommons and 4 commons is just too restrictive. Though I wouldn't mind it if there were more Synergy amongst cards. But now there are 4 sets in the game at this update and you'd have to unlock 60-70% of one set to make a decent deck. I cannot unfortunately recommend this game. You are better off playing cockatrice if you are poor and MTG:O if you want to spend money.

reviewText:
Oh my god this is like poison. I played this game for free and I still feel ripped off.

If you want to play a card game online for free, there are tons of free Yu-Gi-Oh card games online. But I hear already,
'This is Magic, not Yu-Gi-Oh, Yu-Gi-Oh sucks, Magic is better blah blahgblahbshas'
That doesn't matter, what matters is that any of those free games have Thousands of cards to choose from, and this pitiful piece of trash has cards from two sets. Those other games also give you all the cards, so you can just play. I hear more complaints,
'But I want to get the cards, I don't want them handed to me at the begining, that way is for cheaters.'
Yeah, but at least it starts you with something! The starting cards in this game are a joke, and you cannot build a half decent deck out of them. Whatever you do build, will be on par or worse than the easy level ai, and with how you get cards (with coins, 6 or 8 at a time) and how you get coins (by winning, 10 at a time) you have to grind the easy bot before you can get the cards that synergize with each other enough to go onto the medium bot, so you can grind faster.

This wouldn't be too bad, maybe if the game wasn't so clunky and slow. Activating instants during the blocking phase is a chore, and during the damage step, physically impossible. Enevitabilities that you could just get over with quickly take what feel like eons when you have no cards to play and have to wait 20 seconds each turn to play a land and do nothing, while the opponent has a creature and is swinging at you for 2 until you die.
Trying to retaliate with instants that require timing is next to impossible, and the way the game sometimes auto taps lands can really screw over a plan, especially when the system to choose which lands to tap (in the rare times it does that) has no explination on how it works and results in pressing every button on the keyboard until it taps the lands that don't screw you over. The quests can give you an extra couple of coins, but its still a tedious grind to open random cards that may or may not help make a deck that synergizes better than this creature gets +1/+1 if you have an island."

No good cards to use at the start.
Boring grind to get cards that don't suck like a lung.
Clunky and slow gameplay with various greivences.

Don't touch this game.

It's free and its quite fun.
I didn't enjoy haveing to do so much in the way of tutorials as I've been playing magic for quite a while.
I know that earlier duels games asked you how much magic you've played at the start and adjust the tutorials from there, and I wish that this game had done so.

Everything about it is fun, the free to play elements come across as a bit nickle and dime-y but that's to be expected.
I wish they would allow for more options in how the game handles your turn, for example; there have been several times where I wanted to cast an instant on my turn and the game just skips past your turn.
I understand that you can pause the timer but this is a card game, my reflexes shouldn't have to be on point.

Ultimately I recommend it and give it a strong well earned 7/10

reviewText:
Magic Duels: Origins basically does the same mistakes as Duel of the Planeswalkers: It simplifies a game that lives of its complexity.

First for the pro:
- the game is free to play and such easily accesible for new players
- the tutorial is well made and most of the campaign is well balanced to introduce beginners to the game
- all the cards can be optained just by playing
- the game looks kind of nice and the deckbuilding-wizard is a great help to get started

Now the cons:
- the game simplifies many aspects of mtg, losing charm for advanced players
- the campaign is partially really unbalanced which can be really frustrating
- the cardpool is very limited at the moment and it takes ages to afford new boosters
- quests can only be completed with wizarded decks
- the controls are unintuitive

Conclusion:
Duels Origins is a good way for absolute beginners to get into magic, but it lacks way too many features and gameplay aspects to even be remotely interesting for advanced players. But since its free you can still have your fun with the game, playing some wanky cards you'd never play anywhere else.

reviewText:
This game is not necessarily a waste of your time.  Since it's free you should definitely play it just for the story mode.  Wizard/Stainless had one job.  Make a collectible card game(a 'CCG', if you want a TCG play cardboard Magic or MTGO).  They have failed, by definition of CCG.
You can't collect all the cards from the Origins set, and they've said that future expansions won't include all the cards either.  I did not expect to have every Magic card ever made, that would be far more work than I would consider viable.

I expected, wanted desperately, to play Magic: The Gathering.  This is not Magic, you can tell because it doesn't have the cards you need.  They even have the gall to put cards into the single player campaign (which is pretty fun and close to real MTG) but not into circulation.  So it is not laziness on their part, it was a choice.  It is not a choice I can respect.  It is a choice meant to, I don't know.  Presumably usher you toward 'real' Magic.

Dear WotC, if I had the time and patience and money to play MTG, I would already be playing MTG.

So ultimately I suppose I am not the target demographic and it does not satisfy my needs nor was it intended to do so.  However, assuming they are going for newbies, well, play the tutorials and campaign and find out if Magic is for you.  If you stay with this program longer, you will come up against limitations within a week.

reviewText:

The only positive thing I can say at this time is that it is a bare bones MTG game which allows for new players to understand the most basic premise of the game. Unfortunately that same basicness will drive many long time fans of the games/cards away as they can't go and be OP with thier favorites right away.

reviewText:
Magic Duels suffers from similar issues to the previous games, in that the menus are slow to navigate and feature long unnecessary animations, requiring several clicks to reach certain parts of the menu system; skill quest menu, deckbuilding.

The cardplay is floaty and uninteractive, with intuitive motions such as flicking the card back into your hand still playing the card, viewing cards is performed using the mousewheel with a blurry animation lengthening the time to determine what is being played. Certain 'may' actions require a target to be selected even if you do not wish to perform the ability.

Interrupting gameplay to 'counter' or perform actions when you receive 'priority' features a very fast timer with inconcistent confirmation menus when the opponent plays cards.

Deckbuilding uses a carousel menu to display selected and available cards, meaning once you reach ~20 cards in the 60 card requirements it will be frustrating to determine what you are using. Selecting a card will initiate a brief loading period as it displays the next copy of the same card or puts a different card in the slot you last clicked on so there is a lot of waiting to add 4 copies of a card to the same deck. Also building a deck features a missing save button so you have to attempt to quit from the deckbuilding screen to alllow the software to remind you to save your deck changes.

Singleplayer gameplay is nothing more than trial and error to receive the opening hand that will win the game. While internet connectivity will ensure any other gamemode is at risk of wasting time.

The sound in the game is dominated by music that drowns out gameplay sounds to prevent the acknowledgment of the game making progress, and blurs the menus and gameplay together.

Wizards of the Coast do not hire competant programmers or have the managerial environment to allow large software deployments to occur for the complex game they have developed. Do not expect a digital version of Magic the Gathering to ever provide an experience you can be proud of. You do not have to pay for this version, so their incompetance cannot be rewarded.
voteText: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There is a lot I have to say about this game so it will be easier if I make it a list:

- Good intro for new players to magic. Downside is that experiences players can't skip this and it's longer than it needs to be.
- It's relatively limited in the card selection. It's only one set of cards, so they make the currency grind way slower than it needs to be. In the F2P market you need to keep my attention and not giving out SOME currency for EVERY game type and giving out SOME reward for a loss is just wasting the player's time.
- There needs to be more options to speed up the animations and combat. There are some times that this is WAY too slow even after messing with the options.
- Obvious mobile port. There are too many extra things that can be done on a PC platform for a straight mobile to PC port to be acceptable.

reviewText: As a die-hard MtG fan for 20 years I usually go easy on digital releases. DotP 2012-14 is fun to play and despite the serious criticism it's got for the lack of previous game modes like two-headed giant 2015 still beats Duels. All of them beats Duels actually.\nIt's the first time I uninstalled a Magic game on purpose. The game punishes you in every minute and absolutely not fun to play. I don't say it's cheating, computers doesn't cheat, but the decks are tuned to punish you. Richard Garfield was admittedly a fan of 'skill & chance' style. It's in the game, fundamentally. But Duels is biased toward luck on purpose. I like hard challenges. I used to play on the hardest game modes whenever possible. But in Duels it's not a challenge of skill but a challenge of patience. You have to replay duels over and over against vastly superior decks in hope of a very lucky opening hand and a series of sh*t draws for the AI. The reason I guess is to encourage you - or rather force you - to buy more cards form the ingame shop which happens to be another letdown full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and overpriced cards. I'm very disappointed.\nIf you are new to Magic download it for free to learn the basics. Then buy a real deck and go play real Magic with your friends. Don't waste time and money on this one.

reviewText: As a die-hard MtG fan for 20 years I usually go easy on digital releases. DotP 2012-14 is fun to play and despite the serious criticism it's got for the lack of previous game modes like two-headed giant 2015 still beats Duels. All of them beats Duels actually.\nIt's the first time I uninstalled a Magic game on purpose. The game punishes you in every minute and absolutely not fun to play. I don't say it's cheating, computers doesn't cheat, but the decks are tuned to punish you. Richard Garfield was admittedly a fan of 'skill & chance' style. It's in the game, fundamentally. But Duels is biased toward luck on purpose. I like hard challenges. I used to play on the hardest game modes whenever possible. But in Duels it's not a challenge of skill but a challenge of patience. You have to replay duels over and over against vastly superior decks in hope of a very lucky opening hand and a series of sh*t draws for the AI. The reason I guess is to encourage you - or rather force you - to buy more cards form the ingame shop which happens to be another letdown full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and overpriced cards. I'm very disappointed.\nIf you are new to Magic download it for free to learn the basics. Then buy a real deck and go play real Magic with your friends. Don't waste time and money on this one.

reviewText:
Side Notes:
*I know it says I only have 0.3 hours on record but I've played a few more hours of this on Xbox One.*
*This is my first Magic the Gathering digital game. But I play the card game so I know my stuff.*

Pros:-Good tutorial for beginners.
-Nice deck building.
-Deck Helper works okay.
-They have all the standard cards and plan on just adding new cards into the game as they become available.
-Long Campaign with nice cutscene animations.
-Two headed giant mode (2v2 battle)

Cons:-No option to skip tutorial if you already know how to play.
-Terrible Gameplay (I'll discuss that more later).
-Campaign is boring and long. With no option to use your own decks.
-Gameplay is 'chunky' and frustrating and takes a long time to get used to.
-Limited Settings
-Bad value for your money (yes I know it's free).

Conclusion:Magic Duels has some nice new features that are nice but don't overrule the fact that it's just a bad game.
Absolutely horrific gameplay, that feels sluggish and slow and at the same time too quick and consfusing.
Campaign that has nice cutscenes but is long and repeditive, where your forced to use the game's decks.
Settings that annoy and did I mention all the server issues.

Don't clutter your harddrive with this 1.5GB download keep it clear and download a different free to play game. (Dota 2, Team Fortress 2, Soldier Front 2, Realm of the Mad God)

2/10

reviewText:
The best MGT Game so far.

reviewText:
Senselessly missing features present in old games, wildly inconsistent and wholly disappointing story mode, and - biggest of all - necessary online but no working server since launch day.

I downloaded this game on release excited as hell for the newest installment of the series. I was met with a message that it couldn't connect to the server, so my progress couldn't be saved. That was July 29th. It is now August 3rd, and I still have only been able to play once, and only for a few laughably easy story matches.

The game locks out all the game modes until you complete an arbitrary number of story matches and custom decks, but gives you almost no indication that that is what you need to do to progress.

tl;dr: Even if you COULD play the game is kind of garbage anyway.

reviewText:
Four weak had elapsed since this game was realized in steam before it started work properly. After a short spell of being servers down, I must say I was most impressed with whole thing.
The first of all, we have a real freedom in deck-building. Anyone can manage your own deck using cards from pool that he/she already own. All cards are free to players, but, at first, you should collect them.

The way to expand your own collection is to by boosters which include three common, two uncommon and one rare or mythic rare card. There are six cards in each booster, and you never become overloaded with any card. The cap for commons is four cards, for uncommon - three, rare - two, mythic rare - only one. So, when you reach a maximum level for any specific card, you will never receive it again. Hence, sooner or later you collect whole set. Card booster you can buy with in-game currency, which you can receive just for playing the game or buy with real money. To buy at least one booster per day is not hard task.

Game have comprehensive tutorial and it would be easy to lean all basis for everyone. AI is sufficient to make a challenge, moreover, it is hard to run into the same deck when you playing against AI, because they are randomly customized at the beginning of each battle.

However, game have several cons. The first, the graphic in videos is really obsolete. I think, developers should have made a slideshow rather ugly video. The second, and the most essential problem is deficiency in communication with other players. There is no opportunity to send any message to other players or to invite them to be fiends. Lack of feedback is unpleasant, because chatting with an opponent is an important part of fun which we want to receive from board games.
Overall, this game deserve a high marks, and I believe it would be improved soon.
7/10

reviewText:
No, just no. This game runs an oversimplified version of the original card game while cutting corners. The original phases and steps of the turn are not in place for proper interactions with the cards, especially story mode cards. The game also lacks mouse key binding functions, something that I really wanted so that I could twitch my thumb to prevent the game from speeding out of control.

On top of those issues there is a bug where your enchantments fall off of your creatures when they are stolen, which is again devestating. I also want to know who designed the story mode decks. While each opponent you fight against has a flavorful themed deck, there is severe imbalance with the decks you are forced to pilot through out the mode. Seriously, I want to know which designer thought that having a mono-green morbid creatures deck going up against the second stage Lilianna was a good idea?

Even though this is free I highly recommend that you skip this game, ESPECIALLY if you are a fan of the physical game. Not a fan of the physical one? Still don't bother with the download, connection issues still plague the game as well as the quests failing to properly track progress.

reviewText:
Update (8/20/15):

Finally the game worked and I got a chance to play. My review is still a non-recommend for this game. I just played the story mode for a few hours... Please save yourself the pain. The enemy has finished decks and you have unfinished non-counters to their deck styles... yet you can not pick your own deck. So they force you to be gimped while their npc is O.P. The second level of the story mode is more about getting absolutely lucky with your draws while the enemy get highly unlucky... so get ready to start your matches by chosing a new hand and when it penalizes you by not giving you 7 cards accept the hand and restart duel. I had a blue deck that was focused on making the enemy discard cards... but the deck seems to have at most 6 cards that have anything to do with discarding cards... I really do not feel like rambling and fully explaining. All i can say is the game just for me was not fun at all. I love magic and have played it for many years. This will not be something I play. It just seems like the devs are either way off base with the customers or they are way too elitest in the set up of the game. either way when it comes to me and probably a majority of the demographic I come from I can play magic in real life and from many other games forms.

BTW your game does not play full screen windowed so i enjoy greatly not being able to play this absolute headache of a game fullscreen with part of the bottom of the picture cut off when using 1920x1080.

I will review what I experienced. I was excited about the change to play a Magic: The Gathering game... I added the game to my library, Loaded it up, and got a beatiful view of the games Magic symbol. The screen then went black for about 20 seconds. With a woosh I was brought back into the light from the black screen to my normal desktop. In a confusion I looked around the screen trying to figure out what had happened... Oh wait what is that?" I wondered. The game is opened and shows its symbol at my botton screen taskbar. I click it thinking it will open the game. "Oh wow the screen went black... the game is opening! WooHoo!" I said with happiness. To my surprise about 20 seconds later yet again the black screen goes away and brings me back to my normal desktop. This journey of Deja Vu was done multiple times and attempted over longer than needed periods of time. The happiness faded and now all I have to say is I do not recommend this game. It does not even look like anyone really replies to forum posts about this game breaking issue. I do not like it when a company does not reply especially on issues such as this. Sooo I do not recommend this game and if the way the company is handleing this issue shows anything I do not recommend this company. Sorry
date: but not sorry. Maybe if you fix your game in a timely manner I will be happy to play it and change my review to a review about the actual game and not your unplayable game."

reviewText: I've played Magic for over 20 years, and I really really hoped this would transfer all the fun and interactivity of the game into a reliable computer client, since MTGO is a buggy eyesore. While Duels certainly looks cleaner than MTGO and isn't full of rude people, the support it seems to be getting from its publisher is pretty pathetic. Constant delays, incomplete sets, poor communication from the developers, no apparent mechanism to lodge bug reports or file comlaints... given that this barely feels like more than a reskin of the previous annual computer releases, the overal product is quite dissapointing. It's easy enough to play and they've increased payouts significantly lately, presumably to retain what players haven't been scared off yet, but given the competition games like Hearthstone provide these days, the most venerable CCG could--and should--have done way better.

reviewText:
(I waited to write this incase they fixed some connectivity problems. They didn't.)

- Heavy server problems and constant connection issues.
- BUGGY (guess how fun that is when you do your math and plan your moves out?)
- MTG is fun, but the level of grinding with such a small pool of cards eats at your previous praise of the card game.
- The more you play, the more you lose. Losing grants nothing.
- No trading
- No reward for 4 player multi aka 2HG (because it's more fun...???)
- No communication of any form in multiplayer (even if you name your deck... only you can see it)
- You can force a player to conceded and then lose to the replaced AI and recieving nothing. (Generally, it blows when your opponent is replaced by ai. Why not give a small reward for playing a game out even if you're losing?)

- Total cards in MTG: 13,000+... Total cards in Magic Duels: <300.

reviewText:
As a whole, the game isn't bad. The story mode is kinda cool, gives you a bit of lore on many of Magic's most famous characters and you earn enough coins to get a decent amount of cards.

HOWEVER, the multiplayer sucks, the a.i.'s in 'solo battle' are extremely strong relative to your available cardpool, and the only way to fix that is to (of course) buy gold/packs with currency or coin...

It's a good way to kill a few hours but, I wouldn't play it past story mode.

reviewText:
4 out of 10, and it decreases the more you play it.

Ok, so time for a review for Migic Duels Origins. My first impression of the game was that it looked great, very catchy to the eye, so I decided to give it a try. I am not a Magic the Gathering player, so the tutorial was really detailed and fun in my opinion. I got hooked... I played it for a while, grinded a little for coins, got some nice cards eventually, and made a decent white-green elf deck. Sounds great right? Well it was for some time, but eventually some serious flaws with game became obvious to me.

First of all, grinding for coins kills a lot of the potential this game could have. Each victory against another player only rewards you 20 coins from the 150 required to buy just 1 booster pack, and each booster pack only gives you six cards (mostly common or boring rare cards unless you are very lucky). When you star playing the game, you get gold from tutorial quests and story mode. There are 5 campaigns on story mode with 5 missions each, and if you complete one the game rewards you with 150 gold (a booster). This is good and all, but you can complete all of this in a single all nighter. Which brings me to the last way in which players can earn gold in-game: Daily and weekly quests which can give you 20-40 coins depending on their difficulty and your luck.

Yes, you can buy coins and not grind  at all, but I am adamant against  it at the momment,I don't know if want to be playing this in the future yet.  Months from now I might completely forget about it, so why spend money on a game that was just released and I am not so convinced about its play value yet? So I played and tested it out a little to see if it is worthy of the time and money I usually spend on games that I really love to play. My conclusion on this matter was: No, or perhaps not yet. Stainless games and wizard of the coast need to improve 3 fatal flaws in order for me to recommend this game:

1) Most quests I mentioned before can only be completed with decks created through the deck wizard feature. For those of you who do not know anything about this game yet, you can create your decks in two manners: Full Deck Builder, a beautifully crafted feature that allows you to freely configure your deck while you can sort and filter your card collection, and Deck Wizard, a godamn-awful-restricting feature that I can't ever imagine wanting to use it! So why make it so that you require to use this feature in order to complete the archetype decks quests? I cannot complete quests with my carefully crafted green and white deck, I have to use the green and white deck recommended by the awful deck wizard feature. This wouldn't be so horrible if there werent so many archetype quests, but I got three of them in a row (and remember you only get 1 daily). You can still complete these quests if you play against the easy AI, but it is just awful to create a deck to use twice for a quest and disregarding it afterwards.

2) The game needs to be more rewarding and varied, it is awful to have to win 8 battles (sometimes against people who have paid real money to buy cards which is okay but admitedly harder) to buy a single pack which will likely have cards that you won't use (either because you don't like them or they simply don't synergize with the cards you already have). Yeah, the quests help, but after you complete all campaigns and tutorials it all feels so slow... Two Headed Dragon, an awesome game mode which let players go on 2 vs 2 matches doesn't give you anything when you win... It is the only alternate game mode and it is not rewarding to play it, fun at times, but doesn't help me improve my collection at all.

3) The bugs and glitches... I know that it is new a game and that they already admitted on their twitter page that they are still working on these, but the game gets stuck from time to time. Yes, this third point is understandable in my opinion, they didn't have a beta testing as far as I know, but it is an issue. I had games as good as won when for some reason it doesn't let me play my cards and gets stuck, this glitch happened twice and has made me concede games when I am winning (The other opponent had 2 of health and no monsters at the beginning of my turn ugh). Also, game sometimes gets stuck on the loading screen, I had to restart my laptop once, As I said, it is a new game so I try to be patient; nonetheless, it is still a flaw that needs to be pointed out  until it is solved.

As it is, this game is just a tutorial for new players and a clever commercial for the physical and the online complete version of this trading card game. Not rewarding enough and slow paced at times. It feels like the more you play it, the less enjoyable it is. They need to do something drastical if they mean to flip that curve.

reviewText:
Well, I'm pretty addicted to mtg, so I was enjoying my time playing despite the crashes, bugs and disconnects.  But I'm going to have to find a new game for my relaxation time. The straw that broke the camel's back: I win game, but continue gives me a black screen hang.

I reboot my computer (as this is what I end up having to do eventually each time this happens since force quit doesn't seem to work, and the game leaves my laptop wonky if I can even get rid of the duels process).

When I restart duels, it tells me that there is a mismatch in my local and cloud saved decks, choose one and it will delete the other. No clue what the difference was, so I assume its a case of the cloud save not being up to date and choose local. Oops, my bad.

Apparently the difference was the local had NO DECKS. Now all 11 of my custom decks are gone. The 'customer service' website requires a wizards account login, and my system is lagging to hell because the game is still running, and I'm holding on to my temper by a thread.

To the devs who omitted any safeguards from the process of deleting all your decks: thanks, you guys! Maybe I'll get some work done now that I've deleted the desktop icon!

To other users:
- lots of frustration
- seems like not as much mana screw as in previous games (yay?)
- horribly annoying default gameplay options (most correctable in gameplay options)
- still easy to miss your chance to respond to a spell or stop the timer (how hard would it be to let us check a box so we could always stop at opponent's end of turn?)
- very buggy, frequent crashes, black screen hangs and disconnects
- runs terribly on my crummy laptop (though most steam games are fine)
- deckbuilder was pretty fun - but not so fun I want to recreate all my decks... :(

I give it a 4/10.

reviewText:
While the idea of a free way to earn booster packs and build decks is extremely appealing, the fact is that there are limitations to the program. For instance, you can't play instant spells during the draw step. I also don't believe it let me react to all activated abilities.

So the game mechanics didn't translate perfectly. And also, the boosters are only half sized. But the orgin stories are fun and the cineamatics are pretty good, though short.

I can't recommend this game as a substitute for real mtg. But if you do enjoy lore, go ahead and play the stories of the different planeswalkers.

TLDR: Not an MTG substitute.

reviewText:
Been playing magic since the year 2000... and this is by far, a good example of how a modern magic game should be.... and also the worst example of how a magic game should be.

Cons ( First because i think of this game more negatively than positively )

-No chat, no comunication possible even in 2 Headed Giants.
-No Archenemy.
-Expansive Boosters.
-No way of making gold except one time campaign loot and playing a random dude online. Playing against a bot, pays so little you're beter off selling your sperm to buy gold with cash.
-No reward for playing against friends or with friends against bots... you know, the most fun thing to do in magic? Playing with friend, testing out decks, playing together.
-A huge grind since boosters are expansive and only give 6 cards. in my experience, of the 4 boosters i bought, i got 4 cards of the same type. So 1 of the 6 cards, were always the same card i will never use.
-You can do quests to gain a little gold... but most of them are the ''Win 4 match with a B/G or G/W deck'' So if you don't like G/W  or B/G decks.... ♥♥♥♥ you!
-HUGE server instability
-No sorting options for yur hand.
-Deck editor interface is awfull.
-Cards lack variety and most tactics are pre planned.
-Wait till you see the cinematics! Will make Diablo 2 look like Crysis!

Pros

-Excellent tutorial for new players. Voiced and detailed
-Simple controls
-Full deck building ( Finally... )
-2 Headed Giants is back!
-It's magic... so it's still fun i guess.

What it needs
-CHAT!!!!!!
-More cards ( duhh )
-Archenemy
-Multi man FFA
-Some sort of gambling minigames or anything that would make gold a more maniable resource.
-Minimal gold for friends on friends matches. Seriously, even 5 would be acceptable. An easy bot gives 5, it's hard to lose to an easy bot. And even if people farm and abuse, you ask 150 gold for 6 cards, which has duplicates you already have. It would still be a boring grind and would at least make it worth for people like me, who hate playing Magic online.

Final Verdict
-Wait a couple of months... this could be a fun game... if they listen to the comunity, and add wanted features.

reviewText: I was so excited for this game and I was severely disapointed. It has the potential to be an ok game but its awful at the moment. I've been playing Magic for 8 years. There was no need for me to go through the tutorial, yet I was forced to. There is no way to skip it. And the tutorial continues throughout the story mode. It was slow and bothersome. I was also having problems with the graphics. The textures worked fine throughout the tutorial stages but as soon as I got to a level where there was not one, background under the cards became gridded and grey and would flicker every time the mouse would move. I adjusted the graphics as much as the game would allow, which was much. It has an option to turn graphics from low to high and change resolution, but there were no ther graphics options. My computer can run most other games so I was highly surprised to be having such issues with a card game of all things. I would not recommend this game to anyone. Its terrible in its current state. A lot of work needs to be done before I will even consider giving it a second shot.

reviewText:
Pretty straightfoward MtG card game but so many glitches and bugs still. Rewards works... well sometimes but not completely and there is a limit but you can't know when. I do not know what was the goal of that game but I'm pretty sure it hasn't been achieved yet...

Pros:
- Magic the Gathering in Free-to-Play form. (No pay-to-win but patience is required)
- Smooth game flow, animations, and sound effects. (a bit tight on the instant" side)
- I like that the story is intertwined with the game
date:
even if it is a short storyline it give cards flavor text more meaning. (I always wanted to read all the novels from MtG but they are hard to get a hand on)

Cons:
- Some mechanics don't work well (or don't work at all)
- Connection issues (specially in multiplayer duels)
- Reward system not true to what is displayed (often coins doesn't get added unless you restart the game)
- Can't get most rewards with your own deck builds (need a flagged deck created by wierd semi-auto builder)
- Duels simply has no real outlet for competitive play.
- The simulated perspective of the game board need a zoom function or something
recommended:
cards are already hard enough to read/target when the board gets cluttered. (even truer when doing a double-headed giant)

I don't recommend it yet unless you're okay with ALOT of swearing (note: there is no in-game chatting function so it will come from your own end).

Waiting for it to be fixed..."

reviewText: The game seems rather good, untill you actually start playing it. Dont get me wrong the gameplay is good, building a deck it kind of fun (not as much as in RL but hey) But be ready for Random loss of conection to the servers (resulting in losing any and all progress on whatever your tryin to do) And fatal errors resulting in crashes also forcing you to lose progress, I had to do the starter story 9 fricken times before i was actually able to complete it. Untill  they fix these game breakers Im gonna say F&^% No to this game and suggest everyone else does the same> If they do fix them i will remove this negative review and post one the game should be worthy of.

reviewText: While it's nice to have an experience that isn't as clumsy as MTG Online, the inability to actually connect to any matchmade games makes this a pretty solid non-recommendation. The story battles are kind of okay but ultimately boring and devoid of any of the cleverness that made Magic 2014 an enjoyable game. This whole thing seems like a cash-in to try to beat Hearthstone, without anything that actually makes Hearthstone a desirable experience (despite HS being far less strategy- and content-rich than MTG).

reviewText: I love MTG and I love these annual games on Steam and mobile.  This version appears unplayable on a vanilla Windows 10 install.  In the 5th Story Mode duel, your guy vs. Erebos Titan guy, the game crashes as soon as the opponent double blocks.  Repeatable every time, and stops me from progressing past a basic point in the story.\n\nCombine this experience with the bugs previously reported in earlier reviews, and I cannot recommend this free-to-play title.

UPDATE: I've been able to sink some hours into this on my lady's comp. It still won't run on my laptop. Still giving it a thumbs down for that.

- Right as I won my first PvP battle, I lost connection and quest progress. GODDAMIT!

- A bit lifeless. Cool foil animations from previous games appear to be gone. ( Grave Titan! =[ )
- Elevator music, limited sound effects. Theres a lot of the same roars over and over

reviewText: My experience with Magic Duels can be summed in two words, but before I do allow me to tell you a story. In those halcyon days of 1996, just before Alliances was released, I played Magic for the first time. It wasn't my first time seeing the game, but the first time I actually bothered to learn the game and play it. Not long after that, I started playing in tournaments, and not long after winning those local tournaments. I made friends, I made enemies, and my life was linked inextricably with characters both colorful and shady. Magic: The Gathering has since devolved into a rich man's game, and I'm no rich man. Now, my sole connection to the game is through Magic Workstation and the occasional prerelease. I kid you not when I tell you in my time playing this game, I've come across every kind of person from criminals to porn stars and FATAL ERROR

reviewText:
I'm giving this a non-recomendation.

The perspective doesn't help the game.  It would be much easier to read the opponent's cards if it was a top down view of the card table.   Having the opponent smaller looks neat but does little to enhance gameplay.

Combat animations for each damage step are time consuming.

The play for the storyline games seems like the draws are very scripted, not a random deck draw.    I've found, to breeze through the storyline battles, just concede each match 4 or 5 times.    It seems like they make the first couple of passes impossible to give the impression of a challenge or AI ability.

The decks in the storyline use totally bad cards.   Heavy Infantry?  Does anyone use that card IRL?

No way to preview your deck prior to play in the story line.    How would I know that I want to take a mulligan if I don't know what the deck has in it?

I'm still trying to muscle through the story line.   Don't know if I'll make it.   Seems like a chore.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I really gave this game the benefit of the doubt. I wanted it to be good. I didn't want to listen to the other reviews. The story mode was short. But I liked it. After that, it takes forever to rack up enough coins just to get a six card pack of nothing really useful. Which sure, could just be dumb luck. But why, in all that is good, does the Easy Mode computer have mythics? The Normal Mode used two Planeswalkers on me. I can't even get one good rare, let alone doubles of a good uncommon. If I could get any decent cards, or get the packs with more ease, I wouldn't mind. I can't even play online. The server cuts me off or something every time. So I'm wasting my time. Or was. I give up on this game. I might check back after the Zendikar Update, but otherwise I have better games to play.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Fun to play with friends
-It's free
-Opening boosters

Cons:
-WAY TO MANY RAGE QUITTERS on versus mode
-No punishment for rage quitting
-No rematching or best of 3. There's nothing that irritates me than muliganing like 3x and still no mana, so I end up losing a game (or even my opponent) and there's no way to replay in a fair ground. Best of 3 would more likely fix this.
-Limitation of cards (Common=4 cards, Uncommon=3, Rare=2, Mythic=1)
-Cards that you playing in the campaign is not available to unlock, which is extremely annoying since it's obvious they are in the game
-Can't unfoil card. Foiled my cards and regretted since it doesn't look that great
-Some Daily Quests are bugged
-Time to reset the limit of coins is inconsistent (though it says I reached my limit and needed to wait 24hrs, it didn't reset till it was almost 30hrs after the fact)
-Two-Headed Giant doesn't give coins


Not entirely sure if I could recommend it or not, it's fun and all, but if you plan on playing against other people and not AI, be prepared for a LOT of people quitting mid match.

reviewText: Do not recommend! Not convinced? Continue reading.\nAs a player of Magic 2014: Duel of Planeswalkers I was interested in any sequel or DLC's to game. When I saw this game on Steam I though That is what I was looking for. And it is for free..." Well
date: now I know why.\nFirst of all
recommended: game is unplayable due to bugs. A lot of bugs. If you remember The Witcher 3 or 2 version 1.0.0.0 - this game is even worse. You can get error/crash/disconnect at any momment of the game despite is far away from v.1.0 and gameplay variety that can Witcher provide. The most annoying thing is when you are about to win and game lost connection or got desyncronized. Sometimes (each time) it feels like developers have written some code to not let you win (and get coins) if you haven't donated real money to the game.\nSecond problem is game syncronization. How bad the code should be that in such a step-by-step game (not real time shooter or whatever) I expirience hight latency and often desyncronization? When you press on any card to play it - it takes about 0.5-2 seconds to actual cast animation. That is very much affecting gameplay
hoursPlayed: especially when your deck is full of instants or flash creatures.\nThird one is social part of the game. There IS NO CHAT! How should I communicate and cooperate with my partners in Two-Headed Gian game? Also there is no room-browser (or server browser as you wish) when I can pick host to join to. It is searching automatically and always throws errors: "User left the game"

reviewText:
- Slower than previous iterations - the feel of the gameplay -- artificially feels slowed down
- Removed the lobby since DoTP 14, I don't know why but it's very frustrating
- Too many clicks to changes decks and restart a match, especially in 2HG
- Bug, bugs and more bugs. Often crashing, can't build some decks (Elf), can't play if Magic is offline, which is a lot of the time
- It's F2P, and while i'm not a fan of that model I could have looked past it, but this has too many bugs.

I've gone back to 12, 13 and 14. those are more fun IMO. 14 can be modded to include the decks from 12 and 13 with a quick internet search.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Tried Playing 2-player Co-Op, after 3 failed connections to the game I was placed on the opposite team as my invited friend. Kept at it afterwards, was able to connect once after another 4 attempts.

Got matched on the same team as my invited friend. Both of the opponents ended up leaving around 10mins into the game, and the Turn Timer bugged out (It froze). We weren't able to continue so I conceded the duel, the game then resumed for my friend for a another 10mins until the AI I was replaced by refused to attack, thus freezing the game for my friend.

Other than these issues, a fun game.

reviewText:
So my friend and I got this specifically to play 2 headed giant (ie:2vs2) with each other against other human players. At the launch of the game there were issues connecting and timing us out on each other. This wasn't an issue on our end as many other players have experienced similar issues.

Reinstalling the game today, he and I hoped to play a match thinking that the months that had past had been enough time to fix this mess but apparently not. Wizards of the Coast are completely imcompetent in providing a satisfactory product that doesn't have intrusive pay walls and identifying issues within their own games and actually getting onto them to fix them.

I'm sure I'm not alone when I speak these words.

Wizards; GET YOUR ♥♥♥♥ TOGETHER!

reviewText:
It's a real shame Wizards can't deliver on MtG because it's such a fun game to play.

The campaing is rather short but fun. The tell short stories about the popular planeswalkers gradually evolving their decks. While this is a step back from previous duels games it's still nice to play. The short tutorial turns are a nice way of introducing basic mechanics to new players. Overall the gameplay hasn't changed much since the previous installement and is pretty well polished. It's fast and smooth once you get used to some gimmicks. The introduction of unlimited deckbuilding brings us closer to magic proper although the card pool feels rather small, but that will change with time.

So why the negative review? Well:
* The interface is basically designed for tablets. The player has to scroll through rows of cards, icons, etc with 'swiping' moves to do anything. It's tedious and irritating and does not suit mouse controls.
* The multiplayer is kinda meh, no interactions (ways to congratulate or taunt your oponent) makes the experience dull. To top it off there seems to be no penalty for idling which is often exploited by oponents. Also when an oponent ragequits the AI steps in and you still have to finish the game.
* Some campaign missions basically require you to restart until you get a decent hand because they're practically unbeatable otherwise. Not a big pain, but still looks like a balancing issue.
* But the worst offender is the deckbuilder. No way to search your freaking library in any meaningfull way! What the hell? It's so frustrating to build a deck when all you get are color and cost filters. If you want to find anything you have to scroll through rows of cards with 'swiping' moves. There's also no way to see your whole deck at once which is ♥♥♥♥ if youre trying to build anything with some sort of synergy. It looks like no thought was put into designing any of it which is inexcusable in a pc game, and frankly a game where deckbuilding is the most fun. 0/10

To sum it up, the game shows potential but until someone steps in and fixins the UI and multiplayer issues you're better off playing hearthstone.

reviewText:
Magic the Gathering has been a game I've enjoyed for over 15 years and the DoTP series has been (except for last year) one I've quite enjoyed despite its shortcomings. I've looked forward to what the developer could do with the next iteration.

Well, this developer has done a poor job. As others have mentioned the series has regressed, losing features. The series is obviously mimicking Hearthstone but doing a bad job of it.

My main gripes:

15g per win (20g vs online opponent) and 150g to buy a booster pack of only 6 cards. No discount for buying packs in bulk. Plus a weak card pool (not just the rares, but even more importantly the commons and uncommons) for every archetype (aggro, midrange, control, ramp, combo). This means a long and rather uninteresting grind.

A frustrating beginner experience because of the above. Its not much fun to use a very limited, weak, and uninteresting pool of cards against more interesting decks played by the AI.

The AI has not improved in this series for over four years. It doesn't seem to have been worked on.

Removed different gameplay modes and challenges from the campaign.

Can't get gold from 2 headed giant games? So you put in a feature and penalize players who enjoy that feature. Again, these players already have to slowly grind for gold. How does that make sense?

Can't save account/game data across platforms. Their excuse for this was lame. Hearthstone can do it and its been out for a while. Who cares if its out on iPhone, iPad, Steam, and console if you have to create an account for each one? Discourages players from long term play and investing $$ in the game for gold and packs. This is a major, major flaw.

Can play a 30-40 minute game against an online opponent, right before winning the opp quits/disconnects and you lose connection to the game and will not gain any gold for the win. This just happened to me. The payout is bad enough without this disconnects.

Solutions:

Increase the amount of gold per win to 25g.

Quests should give at least 75g each. These massive worldwide coop quests should be even more. A worldwide quest today has a 40g reward. Not even 1/3 of a pack.

Increase booster packs to AT LEAST 8 cards  per pack, but preferably 9-10.

Do whatever coding you have to do to make it cross platform compatible.

Hire a new developer.

Give free packs to all customers for all the grief with the servers and all these letdowns. This costs you no money but makes the customer base feel listened to and happy. Happy and loyal customers is a good thing.

reviewText:
I have been playing Magic: The Gathering for the better part of 20 years.  I play casual Magic in real life very often, I am familiar with all the rules to a high degree and have played approximately 1000 online matches of the Duels of The Planeswalker games in years past.

Although it had some weird drawbacks--namely not being able to remove any unlocked cards from your deck--the first iteration of this game was awesome.  It got me back into the game: here was something that was easy to play, had a good mix of different card and deck types, and was just a really streamlined, accessible way to play casual M:tG games without having to get a group together and worry about deck balance.

The next two (or three, I forget how many now) were similarly excellent.  Rudimentary deck editing allowed seasoned players much greater control over how they played, and was a much more managable way for new players to learn the ins and outs of what makes or breaks a deck.

Magic 2015 and this new Duels have just taken huge strides backwards.  Forcing players to build their own decks without actually providing any information on why and how the old archetypes were constructed makes the gap between pros and newbs that much wider, and makes for a much more narrow metagame than previous years.  Add in the lack of extra modes, the inability to skip a patronizingly hand-holding tutorial for advanced players, and a cap on how much you can progress in the game ON YOUR OWN TIME to further encourage spending extra money on the game, and in my opinion you have the worst game Stainless has put out yet.

Obviously I haven't played it very much, and I may go back and slog through the intros to sink my teeth in a little deeper, but this game is exactly what no one was asking for.

The ones who just don't get it are the ones who scream the loudest."  I've heard WotC say players have been clamoring for open-ended deck editing for years

reviewText: As far as a game that accomplishes a modicum of representation for the variety and spirit of the original trading card game, Magic Duels does well.  Deck customization is enjoyable, there is both synergy and versatility, card sets are rolling out and casual play is rewarding.  I own three previous MtG titles from Stainless Games, which I still play, but this one is a fave that I play almost regularly, more than once a week, sometimes coordinating to play with friends.  A lot of my expectations were met by this game, and I look forward to seeing many more cards.\n\nNote of edit: It seems that whether you prefers a single color, multiple colors or colorlessness in your deck, this game accommodates virtually equal footing if you are using a carefully built deck.

reviewText: It seems that this game REQUIRES money to even work.  I played a good deal of the game casually, for about 11 hours, but could only make it about 2/5ths ot the way through liliana's campain before i gave up.  After that, I tryed 1v1 PvE.  out of the 25 games or so that I played, I only won 1.  I tryed making a better deck, but that one, which acording to the game, it was better than the first one I made; played about the same number of games and didn't win once.  Now, you may be wondering how was i able to finish about 50 games in about 8 hours, seeing as the average game of magic in real life takes about 1 hour. I'll tell you how because it only took the computer 10-15 minutes to beat me, a magic player that has played this game for nearly TEN years now. first of all, i must congragulate Stainless games for making the world champion, magic-playing, dream-crushing AI that is this game's EASY MODE! This game is so hard, i dont even think my deck, my Magnum Opus of a magic deck, the deck that I have been shaping since 2006, could win a match in easy mode! EASY MODE!!!\n\nAll in all, this game deserves to rot and burn forever in the 9th ring of hell.

reviewText:
At first: My english isn't the best. :)

Until now I played 30 hours and will continue. I really love this game.
But there are huge problems: The AI loves to cheat and the deck building assistant is somehow useless.
For myself I still recommend it to me, because I love ist. For others I wouldn't recommend it because of a high frustration level after some time.

I'll start with the big problems in my eyes and attach the pros at the end.

1) The AI:
I built a deck destruction deck mere to check which cards the different difficulty level uses. Mostly the easy ones and they're the biggest cheater. Normaly they use 3-5R and maximum 1M, nearly half of the hard AI. But the last duel showed me again that they're even worse.
My last duel in short: 23 cards played: The AI got red, green + black Planeswalker,  Erebo's Titan,  Gae's Revenge, 2 Gilt-Leaf Winnower and Evolutionary Leap! ( 4M + 4R )
More R and M than a hard AI in less turns. As if that is not enough: the AI also gets the perfect destruction and takeover skills just in time.

You want to finish your dailys with easy AI? Bad Idea. Use medium AI instead, they tend less to cheating.

2) Deck building assistant:
Well, it's good for beginners. It's a good variety of play types.
But if you in possession of nearly all cards the final deck is getting worse. Why? The game tends to give you a selection of your best cards you have, but not the best for this type of Deck. At the end your deck contains strong creatures and spells, but they're expensive. Also good cards for combinations you can't use because the 2nd or 3rd part of the combination is missing.
The product makes it harder to win against the AI and finish your dailys. Even with a restart (bad hands guaranteed!)

But like every game there are a lot of good things.
- good graphics and the paintings of the cards are always good!
- the devs promised: time to time new cards
- insights of the story of the planeswalker
- a good reward system (not to much or less coins)
- smooth animations
- well-balanced variety of cards in the beginning


I hope the devs will use the huge potential of this game and rebalance the AI controlled features so it wil be MORE Awesome.
But to recommend it to others who may be new to this kind of game it's not enough. it'll definetly scare some people off. There are also small issues I didn't mention because I know the devs will fix them.

reviewText:
I tried. Honestly, I did.

Magic Duels feels like it's still in closed beta testing. Give it a year, and maybe it will be a professional quality game.

There are some good things. The tutorial is a good way to learn the rules if you're rusty or new, and long time players will appreciate some fan-favorite planeswalkers as your campaign heroes.  The interface is relatively intuitive in games, there's little need to micro your lands or other inane things like that. Smart-targeting is pretty spot on.

But the bad is so much worse.

First, because of the single-expansion run, combinations and deck builds are prohibitively railroad tracked.  Oh

reviewText:
Fun game.  It has the potential to be great but is not quite there.  I'll give it a strong good though.

Getting cards is a grind.  They have taken steps to improve the daily rewards by adding easier means to getting coins.  Expect to open one, maybe two, packs per day if you play for a couple of hours.

If you spend a little money, the fun goes way up.  You will be building a lot of new decks and learn all of the new cards schemes fast.

reviewText:
My biggest problem with this game is that it tries far too hard to extract money from you with the free to play" model.  In previous installations you'd get 15 cards for beating a real opponent and in this game you get about 0.8 cards for beating a real opponent.  Even this wouldn't be so unbearable if they started you out with more than a very limited pool of remotely usable cards.

The end result is like fighting to the death with foam swords... hundreds of times just to unlock a fraction of the set.  It's so frustrating because the game is otherwise good.  I expect that "earning" the cards rather than buying them would take at a minimum hundreds of hours.

Things they did well:
-Theoretically far more diverse than older installments--I just refuse to pay 45 dollars to try out that feature
-Plays better than previous games
-Skip-able snippets of tutorial that explain both the card game itself and specific points pertinent to the digital version.

I only (very barely) recommend this game because it is the current installment and so is most relevant to a player that might be wanting to pick up the physical game (which by my understanding is the entire reason these games exist)."

reviewText:
Magic Duels is quite similar to all the Magic 20XX titles that came before it, but with a more open deck builder (yay!) and a very limited card set (boo!)


The campaign missions are enjoyable, but fairly short, and the solo play experience is much more limited than was available in the other titles.  However, the actual style and quality of this experience is pretty much every bit as good as the other titles, with the benefit of being free.


You will quickly discover that it takes a long time to build up a decent collection of cards to work with, as the play-to-unlock approach is very slow.  This mostly doesn't matter, but there comes a point where the game decides you've played enough, and starts equipping the AI with high end chase rares in all its decks.  At that point you will need to either just make your decks more optimized (the AI is ok, but not smart), or switch over to playing more against humans for a while (who likely have decks like yours, except for the occasional paid guy with a ton of chase rares).


The card set is quite limited, but does offer a decent range of potential strategies.  Once you do unlock some cards, you'll have fun making a few decks.  I am guessing this is meant to be some sort of MtG starter experience.


If you enjoy MtG, then give Duels a play for some free quick enjoyment.  If you enjoy CCGs but haven't played MtG, then if you haven't already disappeared in a puff of broken logic, play it for a nice tiny taste of what MtG can be like.  And, if you don't enjoy CCGs, then don't bother, you won't like this either.

I don't see why so many people give this game negative reviews. Here are the pros and cons I saw:

Pros
- Best deck building system to date
- Hundreds of cards can be obtained without paying any real money
- Tons of card variety
- Fun and interesting story mode
- Brought back the 2-headed Giant battles
- Daily Quests to complete
- Fast PvP matchmaking

Cons

- On rare occasion it has crashed on me
- Grinding for cards can take a while
- Unplayable if servers are down

Verdict: 8/10 - One of the better MTG card games I've played AND it's free! So as far as I can see there is no reason to not try it out! :)

reviewText:
I've played magic for years.  The experience I've gotten out of this game so far has been dismal at best.

That day one grind
To initially earn some gold to purchase a few card packs a player will naturally start with the story mode.  In story mode there are some instances in which fights at the beginning of a character's story are considerably harder to win than the fights at the end of their story.   You will be completely at the mercy of the RNG gods and they will frown on you numerous times.  Then when you win a particularly difficult battle you may find yourself being told to reconnect which 50% of the time will result in your win not being recorded, you receiving no gold reward, and you having to repeat that battle if you want to progress.

When you move on to playing real people you will be a level 0 player with barely more than the base set of cards and will find yourself being matched up with players as much as (and possibly more than) 15 levels higher than you.  They will have all the advantages you would expect them to have (greater card diversity, better combinations, higher value to mana cost).

This is not the magic you play with real cards
You are not able to pre-shuffle sort your deck.  This means you cannot follow the common practice of spacing out your mana across the deck and as a result you will find yourself either drowning in mana but starved for cards to cast with it or drowning in cards to cast but starved for mana more frequently than you would playing the real game.  You will of course also not be able to place relevant cards beside each other in hopes of increasing your chances in getting a good shuffle.

For fans of drafts this game has.... nothing.  There is no drafting at all.  Even if it's implemented in some way in the future consider the following:
The effort and time required to grind the cost of playing will of course be designed to encourage you to pay rather than grind.
If you do decide to but cards then you'll find a 6 pack is $1.99 USD. That makes the per-card cost for these virtual cards more than the per-card cost of real physical cards.  Unlike the real physical cards these ones have absolutely no resale value, no collectors value, and can't be traded with other players.

(TL;DR)So basically...
If you've never played magic before, this can teach you about the basic phases of a turn and about different card abilities.  After which you may as well uninstall it and check online if there are any game stores near you that host Draft nights for the real game because:
It will have a greater return per time invested ratio.
You won't spend 4 hours grinding out the same amount of cards that an hour of going to work can earn you.
Cards you actually pay for will cost you less money.
You will learn more about strategy and deck building from talking to the other players at a draft night than you will from playing this game.
You will be able to trade cards with other players.

And finally....

If you eventually tire of it you will be able to sell your cards and recoup some or all of your investment (if you pull some rare/valuable cards from packs you might even get back more than your initial investment).



10/10
Would fight a battle with the odds stacked against, finally win after over an hour, find out I've been DCed and the results weren't saved, and then go play hearthstone again.

reviewText:
ok first up i played around 48 hrs of this game since launch and its august 2nd 2015 right now.

TDLR at bottom.


Pros:
-its free to play. Takes like 76 boosters with 6 cards per booster to finish collecting all the cards atm. They said they will be adding more cards every 3 months. Boosters will not give repeats which is a plus. Even though playing against players with a more fleshed out deck could be a little more challenging there is no reason you can't win with this starting pool.

Ppl say u can't manually select the lands, they are wrong u can select them. Also there is an option to turn off auto blocking. All this they would know if they have completed the story properly.

There are 5 campaigns for story mode with 5 missions per campaign. You get 150 gold total from ea campaign.  During the campaign you'll be given the option to do skill quests which teach you the intricates of the game and also award you with ~15 gold. So total of 750 + 250~ = 1000~ gold which you can buy boosters with where ea booster is 150 gold. So around 6-8 boosters.

-Good learning curve for beginners of magic. Yes ppl say the campaign ai  has pre built flavorful decks and even some veterans find it difficult to overcome. That is the whole point of story mode. It is there to teach new players how some tactics can be overcome, and it also sheds more light on how a lot of the mechanics can be used differently. If it was easy, beginners would come out of story mode fighting veterans of the magic community not even having a clue how they were defeated and blame the balance on a small starting pool. Expect to lose and retry a lot in the story mode. You don't need to finish it for veteran players, you just need to finish the first campaign to start building your own deck.

-Deck building. Utter free reign on your deck building as opposed to previous planewalker installments. You can use a deck building wizard or do it manually.

-UI. I just want to touch upon this since I read a lot of the negative reviews are from this category. Yes after like 3-4 iterations of this game the ui should be polished. I haven't experience any of the problems they have touched upon in the negative reviews( like black screens and unresponsiveness), but I'm also using a more up to date pc compared to what some ppl are using, The game when it came out had a lot of server issues disconnecting which could of infuriated a lot of the players, it most certainly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off when I finally defeated lilliana's campaign after 3 times beating her just to find that I have been disconnected and the results haven't been recorded. But I didn't let that affect my review which a lot of ppl were mostly complaining about. It is around launch so I'll give them the benefit of the doubt.

I'll list the cons of the ui in the cons section, but atm I have no problems with the visibility of the UI and it's responsiveless, with only a few gripes on the available options.

-earning boosters. Vs hard ai for 15gold, probably the fastest way since ai's don't need to think and make you wait. With a good deck you can prob knock off an ai every 10 mins~. Vs human you get 20 gold.

A lot of ppl complain about the coding of this game not being done properly, but I find it decently well programmed since I have been through programming courses, when fighting the ai and looking at how a lot of cards demand a lot of what if and what not commands I find that the programmers have done very well in all the special situations that all the cards demand. Not to mention the ai are actually hard, they will fall for some more complex human tactics but often then not if you let your guard down they will kill you. A lot of times I find myself beating the opponent human to find him rage and replaced by ai just to get beaten by the ai later on. I have only seen one or two coding errors within my 40~ hrs of play time, when using a destroy target artifact enchantment spell I removed the creature along with the enchantment aura it had, and when an opponenet killed my creature with an enchantment aura that gave me life, my opponent got the life boost too when it was already used.

-Don't want to look like a nerd while playing the paper version in public? You can be a nerd at home.



Cons

-UI, they have removed chat from the ui. There's no voice communication either. This goes right up there in ways to ruin a great a game.

The skip atk phase button is in the same position as the continue button so after spamming continue because you have nothing to do on main phase but you want to atk on atk phase you can screw urself over.

The option to skip when human player quits in the middle. But most of the time I would welcome the free gold, but there should be a quality of life option to leave the game as well.

Taking the time to think on main phase but running out of time automatically skips you through atk phase and 2nd main phase after atk phase. There should be some sort of flashy mechanic to draw ur attention when ur about to run out of time and also to not skip thru all ur phases.

-earning gold. Max 400 gold earned per day so 20 games of winning against humans. Even though it's very hard to win more than 20 games considering the time it takes for a human match, the limit should be bumped a littler high for those of the community that want to enjoy the game f2p so they can unlock more cards and bring their dream deck to reality sooner. With that being said I do find the grind a little slow to unlock more cards to unlock more flavorable plays, but I do respect the gold earned per a play since the game is f2p.


2 headed dragon doesn't reward gold. To me this is very weird. Considering this mode is a fan favorite and it takes a much longer time to finish compared to single vs, I don't see the reason to not add gold reward. Hopefully this will be changed later but atm this is probably the main reason to not recommend to a friend.

No 4 player ffa. I know some argue that the current iteration of cards are probably not suited for a ffa brawl but this mode was a lot of fun in it's previous games and options would definitely not hurt the community but vice versa.




TDLR.

with the basics of a mtg game covered and free to play but without the quality of life options, communication with ppl, and most important of all U CANT EARN GOLD FROM PLAYING TWO HEADED DRAGON, I don't recommend this. With that being said you can enter this game and play for free, but the grind will not be friendly to new comers.

reviewText:
It really amuses me to read all of this so-called reviews about this game, made by people who didn't invest at least 10 hours into the game and not recommending it to anybody.

I am a Magic player, and despite not playing that much past couple of weeks, you can trust me when I say that this version of Duel Planeswalkers is the best implementation up to date. It is an expandable (Battle of Zendikar is live now on PC) free-game (which alone is very rare, regarding Magic: The Gathering), in which you are finally able to play with Planeswalkers and make your own deck to play versus others, or AI.

The game has microtransactions (you buy boosters with in-game money), but you can earn that in-game money playing for free (like other games out there), by doing quests or finishing storylines events.

And to make the story short here is a list of PRO and CONS:

PROs:
- expandable free-game with microtransactions (like other games popular right now: see Marvel Puzzle Quest for instance).
- enough methods to earn free money in game (If you play regularly, you can buy a booster every 2-3 days).
- expandable storyline
- unlockable cards according to the real set of cards (as of now: Magic Origins and Battle for Zendikar).
- planeswalkers (you can play with them, and the current creature-planeswalkers are a great fun to play with)
- battle others online
- make your own decks with Wizard and Advanced Deck building (in other variants you could only play with certain decks or make 1 color decks. Now you can make any deck you want with the cards you have in your collection)
- gives you motivation to gather the cards needed so you can improve your decks.

CONs:
- the archetype deck-building (Wizard) can be improved. It limits you to choose between the first 5 possible cards at a certain time in the building phase, and only when you chose one of them you can choose other cards. It should let you choose from all the cards that are available for the restricted archetype build in any order and amount you want to draft" them.
- It lacks the ability to play with friends (battle versus specific opponent or play 2 Headed Giant with a friend).

The game has lots of potential to grow
date: and it certainly has more room for improvement. It maybe is an 8 out of 10 right now
recommended: but it's going in the good direction
hoursPlayed:
and with more expansions it can look better and better.

I am very glad that I now have a way of playing Magic for FREE with most of the cards in the real core sets and I think all of you Magic fans should be.

I recommend this game to any Magic fan. It isn't as high as Magic online yet
voteText: but in some areas it really is doing a better job."

reviewText:
Product received for free

I tried to play Magic Online and I told them during the registration process that it had been a while since I'd played, so I got shunted off to this game instead of being allowed to download the actual Magic Online.  Apparently I'm not good enough for the real game, you know, the one where there's no animations, a terrible UI consisting of separate windows popped out for weird things, minimal sound, and zero explanation as to what's happening as you mash your way through interrupt opportunities via the tiny OK button off to the left.

No, instead I'm forced into the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Corral of Magic Duels, with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ rock-sounding OST, minimal animations without any sense of impact or importance to them, minimal sound (though slightly less minimal than MtGO), and a plethora of features designed to make me feel as though the game itself is calling me stupid for playing it.  Is it the mandatory pause of 2-3 seconds between each phase?  Is it the narrator who reads verbatim all the help text, that pops up explaining things like the concept of what a turn" is
date: at a rate of about 1 word every 2 seconds?  Is it the insultingly easy "challenging and fun skill quests"?  Is it the way all the cards zoom up to the screen when played so I can take my sweet time in seeing that yes

reviewText:
Look, I really want to like this. I love Magic, and they really tried with this one. It has the potential to be the best online version of this game so far. So what's the problem?

1. The UI is ugly.
2. The UI has some serious awkwardness occasionally.
3. Certain cards are bugged and simply don't behave the way they should.
4. Inexplicable crashing.

There are a bunch of other minor grievances too, like... The music sucks, but when you turn the music off, it mutes all the sound in the cutscenes. WTH? Or, it gives you quests to complete with specifically colored deck archetypes. You make a deck with the deck wizard and it will count, but if you make the exact same deck yourself, it won't. You can't create your own decks for quests - you're forced to use the deckbuilding wizard. WTH?  Etc, etc. In the game's current state (And this isn't accounting for the server issues), I can't recommend it.
