reviewText: Magic Duels is a potnetially fun game burried under a moutain of hassle and problems. The game itself, when it works, is great. Basic magic, but it looks pretty and has that adictive quality that magic is famous for. Unfourtunitly, most of the time I don't actually get to enjoy the game. It launched with a crippling server issue and since you must be online, even to play single player, the game is esentailly unplayable in it's current state. Trying to power through the server issues often means all you progress is not able to be uploaded and you're forced to replay the same story mission over and over until the game decides to sync. If you do manage to make it past that, you can't earn any of the achievments with home brewed decks. You have to use the deck wizard currently, and the deck wizard has no idea how to build a good magic deck. That, combined with the severly underpowered starting set of cards, means you're forced into grinding low level opponents for hours to earn a few more card to hopefully improve your deck (again, asumming the server connects and the game even decides to recognize your progress).\n\nHopefully in a few weeks this review will be obsolete as all the major bugs will be resolved, but until that happens, avoid. This game is not fun, or even functional in it's current state. A shame, since the Duels series used to be such an easy and enjoyable way to get your magic fix.

reviewText:
This review is coming from someone who has never played paper Magic. My MTG experience started with DoTP 2015.  I will say, the most awesome part of these games is that they introduced me to the world of MTG. I had no idea of the depth of story and how everything fit together. With that said, I likely will never get into paper Magic past the lore. That endevor will just take too much of my time. Life is simply too busy.

As far as Magic Duels itself, I do enjoy it, but I'm hesitant to recommend it to others. It feels like Magic Duels is a game put together by a few dedicated highschool kids in their free time. Overall the quality of the interface is not very polished. There are a few glitches here and there, as well as some interesting features left out from previous iterations (hold priority just to name one).

The biggest issue I have is that I would feel much better with some sort of account system. Currently I have not spent any money on this game because I feel that if I needed to format my computer for any reason I would lose all progress. I'd feel much more secure in spending money if I had this confidence. Another big deal for me, though not quite as big, is that I cannot play on Android. If I was able to apply the same account to both my PC and Android device I would have no problem throwing plenty of money at this game, even in its unpolished state.

I do enjoy playing Magic Duels and will continue to play it. I probably won't spend any money until the major issues listed above are addressed. Here's hoping. I also cannot recommend anyone else spend money on this game if I myself cannot.

reviewText:
After some time waiting for a fix, the game finally works on my primary PC:

It is quite grindy, as you need to put in lots of effort to unlock cards. reviewText:
Some 2HG impressions
First of all, the free deck building may sound very appealing, but there is a controversy here.

Previous games had solid prebuilt decks and it was very hard to ruin them.
Now making bad decks is easy and people are even showing signs of ingenuity at that!

Imagine playing with a person who randomly throws cards into a deck and calls it ready.
Play this game and you no longer need to imagine such things!
(At least it is freebies while dueling, but in 2HG, oh god no!)

Second larger issue is the lobby.
Actually there isn't even a proper lobby system. No ready button. Nothing!
You just invite a friend and hope the game starts and you get into the same team with him.
You absolutely can't kick people you dislike either!

Then there are some other issues.

Would you like to communicate with your teammate? Too bad.
Would you like relatively stable and lag-free online matches? Too bad.
Would you like to get a proper reward from 2HG win? Too bad. (The coin rewards sometimes show up and disappear after)
Would you like short and fast turns? Too bad.

Despite all the shortcomings, there is still some light in the horizon.

There are some cool decks you can make, although the card pool is bit too small.
More cards will come and at least the future patches might actually fix more problems than they cause.

In conclusion.

If you are a 2HG enthusiast, give this game plenty of time to fix itself.
If you like playing solo, this game is relatively good stepping stone to MTG.

(Why is there no Give it some time" button in Steam?)"
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wow that's alot of hating I see skimming through reviews. Perhaps my expectations for this title were a bit low considering I have not actively played Magic in any form for more than a few days at a time for over a decade now. Also the last iteration of converting the godfather of collectible card games into digital format was horrendously disappointing. For me there are enough steps in the correct direction here to give this a recommendation especially if your new to Magic or have been away from the game for a long time.

Pros

Deck Building Assistant and Skill Challenges to help with learning curve for New Players
Decent amount of Single-Player content for a PVP focused title
Free-to-play and Unlock Slowly - No hidden paywall that I can see
Game runs smoothly
MGTG launched a genre for a reason its an insanely deep and nuanced game full of intersting tactical decisions
Artwork looks great

Cons

Graphically its pretty boring and extremely plain compared to other digital ccgs (Forgotten Realms CCG is an indie project still in beta/alpha state and it looks pretty similiar the Origins)
Need to be online to play/collect gold which is understandable given F2P model However.....
Disconnection Issues are a pain right now really hope to see this improved soon
The complexity of the game can still be an achilles heel to newbies

I'll reserve my rating until I've played a few more hours and had a chance to play some of the more exciting features in lenght (two-headed dragon I am looking at you).

Overall though more than worth your time if you've been wanting to get back into Magic or are a new player especially.

reviewText:
I have heard alot and seen many reviews being very negative about this game, so i didnt really have the motivation to try it out.

But since i began, ive been having alot of fun with it. Yeah sure, you cant build your own deck by ALL cards, but you can build your deck anyway you like it, and i mean ANY combination.

So there is this thing with the deck maximum amount of each cards, in real magic, its 4 no matter the rarity, but here we see it with 4 as commons, 3 uncommon, 2 rare and a single legendary.
Thats what most people are upset about, that you cant build the deck like real magic, and i get that, but i dont see it as a flaw or faulty game design at all.

It really helps balancing the game out, so we dont se 2-3 decks completly owning every single game, instead, the small common/uncommon decks actually have a chance, since you see one planeswalker, you only have to worry about that single one.

Its both ends decks build around a single overpowerd card, but also balances decks power out. In addition, it really forces a player to make his own deck rather then search out the top 3 decks, sure you can do that, but every deck has a rather good chance by itself because of this 4-3-2-1 rare style.

And here is what i absolutly love about Magic Duels:

- Whenever i buy a booster, i get cards i DONT have, thats right, no extra copies to dust off" nope

reviewText:
My credentials: I've played this game for about 20 hours; I've played other games in the Stainless series (2012, 2014) for several hours as well. I have also competed in pre-release events of the actual, physical card game, which I still play regularly. I even own the Heroscape-like boardgame --it's a blast! I highly recommend that last one.

I am not sure where the hate for Duels is coming from -- perhaps from a sloppy launch? In its current condition, Duels is probably the best M:tG game out there, and certainly the closest to reproduce the real-life collecting experience outside of M:tG Online. And it's free. Story Mode is fun, and every chapter gives you enough gold to acquire at least one booster; by the end of Story Mode, the average player should have a decent enough deck to win most hard-mode duels against the AI. By combining those earnings with that of daily and weekly quests, even a very unlucky person should be able to expand their collection at a satisfying rate. I've certainly not grown tired of the game, and I've only unlocked about half of the achievements.

Future updates should increase card selection and add Story Mode chapters, and there's every indication the development schedule will keep pace with real-life M:tG releases.

Of course, the game is not without problems. The UI takes some getting used to, but it's more forgiving than in 2014. For some reason, the cinematics are buggy and have no sound (but that, I think, is a fairly minor complaint). Legacy formats like Planechase and Archenemy are not available. Randomly-assigned multiplayer matches are undeniably unfair:  folk willing to pay will definitely get a leg up on the competition. But playing against friends and/or the AI is always fun. I would especially recommend this game to casual players who want to stay abreast of the M:tG world but can't afford to maintain a standard deck.

reviewText:
Deffinetly maybe.

I really like the franchise, but this was far out what i wanted from it.

- PVP seems to always lose connection, the game itself seems quite unstable.
- Alot less game modes, from which Planechase was my absolute favorite.
- Communication has been removed between friends, and still no way to communicate to your enemy.
- Needs alot of more cards, even after the BFZ fun of never knowing enemy deck seems still a dream.
- Lack of deck types, there is still no way of playing EDH or anything else fun and goofy.

After all these negative attributes and simple problems, I still find it enjoyable to play this game.
Even if this Magic Duels merely scratches the surface of the Magic universe, I find that the only major problem with this game. Nowhere near enough cards are included in these games and it is in my oppinion the problem
With more added depth this game could easily be the best MTG game on steam.
But taking in consideration that there is already a MTG game that can be played online, even if it costs real money to play it makes these games seem far from what they could be. Well I think these are actually just bite sized sweets to feed people so they would either start playing MTG. Online, or in it's prime kitchen table with friends and a couple cold ones.

reviewText: The game as a whole is a nice virtual interpretation of the cardboard version, and there are few negative things I can say about it. At one point the game was so buggy as to be near unplayable but as it's grown older on my shelf the bugs have grown less noticeable and much less frequent. The free-to-play nature of the game drew me in aswell as the personal history I have with Magic. The game has offered me a nice alternative to stretch my magic muscles when I get the urge, and it has offered me the ability to play my favorite card game from a place wherein there is not a sanctioned Modern event within 100 miles. The few gripes I have for the game are thus: The game- unless you're sporting a wallet filled with gold- is a massive grind. Recently there have been a few changes to the gold rewards on the quests and vs battles that have helped the pacing tremendously, but you still must have an impressive amount of patience in order to finally booster your way into the cards you want for that deck you've been really wanting to build. As of today I've put in roughly 200 hours into this game and I've only recently finished off the Origins Set boosters moving into BFZ. The grinding admittedly however gets easier and easier the more cards you acquire, the hardest part of the grind starting at the very beginning when you only have your campaign gold and a couple of deck builders toolkits, which has led to the discouragement of many would-be Magic Duels players. On the subject of the campaigns, they're fun- very fun. Though short, the different scenarios and decks you are pitted against throughout the story are diverse and engaging, and in my oppinion make up for the choppy cheesy messes that are the cut scenes, and as of today there are plans to release Shadows Over Innistrad which will introduce a brand spanking new campaign with a plethra of new cards.\nThe pacing of each game is one of my few gripes, with slow drawn out turns with timers on them that should last half the time they do, which admittedly may be my inner veteran coming out. Untap

reviewText:
This review is coming from someone who has never played paper Magic. My MTG experience started with DoTP 2015.  I will say, the most awesome part of these games is that they introduced me to the world of MTG. I had no idea of the depth of story and how everything fit together. With that said, I likely will never get into paper Magic past the lore. That endevor will just take too much of my time. Life is simply too busy.

As far as Magic Duels itself, I do enjoy it, but I'm hesitant to recommend it to others. It feels like Magic Duels is a game put together by a few dedicated highschool kids in their free time. Overall the quality of the interface is not very polished. There are a few glitches here and there, as well as some interesting features left out from previous iterations (hold priority just to name one).

The biggest issue I have is that I would feel much better with some sort of account system. Currently I have not spent any money on this game because I feel that if I needed to format my computer for any reason I would lose all progress. I'd feel much more secure in spending money if I had this confidence. Another big deal for me, though not quite as big, is that I cannot play on Android. If I was able to apply the same account to both my PC and Android device I would have no problem throwing plenty of money at this game, even in its unpolished state.

I do enjoy playing Magic Duels and will continue to play it. I probably won't spend any money until the major issues listed above are addressed. Here's hoping. I also cannot recommend anyone else spend money on this game if I myself cannot.

reviewText:
I have heard alot and seen many reviews being very negative about this game, so i didnt really have the motivation to try it out.

But since i began, ive been having alot of fun with it. Yeah sure, you cant build your own deck by ALL cards, but you can build your deck anyway you like it, and i mean ANY combination.

So there is this thing with the deck maximum amount of each cards, in real magic, its 4 no matter the rarity, but here we see it with 4 as commons, 3 uncommon, 2 rare and a single legendary.
Thats what most people are upset about, that you cant build the deck like real magic, and i get that, but i dont see it as a flaw or faulty game design at all.

It really helps balancing the game out, so we dont se 2-3 decks completly owning every single game, instead, the small common/uncommon decks actually have a chance, since you see one planeswalker, you only have to worry about that single one.

Its both ends decks build around a single overpowerd card, but also balances decks power out. In addition, it really forces a player to make his own deck rather then search out the top 3 decks, sure you can do that, but every deck has a rather good chance by itself because of this 4-3-2-1 rare style.

And here is what i absolutly love about Magic Duels:

- Whenever i buy a booster, i get cards i DONT have, thats right, no extra copies to dust off" nope

reviewText:
My credentials: I've played this game for about 20 hours; I've played other games in the Stainless series (2012, 2014) for several hours as well. I have also competed in pre-release events of the actual, physical card game, which I still play regularly. I even own the Heroscape-like boardgame --it's a blast! I highly recommend that last one.

I am not sure where the hate for Duels is coming from -- perhaps from a sloppy launch? In its current condition, Duels is probably the best M:tG game out there, and certainly the closest to reproduce the real-life collecting experience outside of M:tG Online. And it's free. Story Mode is fun, and every chapter gives you enough gold to acquire at least one booster; by the end of Story Mode, the average player should have a decent enough deck to win most hard-mode duels against the AI. By combining those earnings with that of daily and weekly quests, even a very unlucky person should be able to expand their collection at a satisfying rate. I've certainly not grown tired of the game, and I've only unlocked about half of the achievements.

Future updates should increase card selection and add Story Mode chapters, and there's every indication the development schedule will keep pace with real-life M:tG releases.

Of course, the game is not without problems. The UI takes some getting used to, but it's more forgiving than in 2014. For some reason, the cinematics are buggy and have no sound (but that, I think, is a fairly minor complaint). Legacy formats like Planechase and Archenemy are not available. Randomly-assigned multiplayer matches are undeniably unfair:  folk willing to pay will definitely get a leg up on the competition. But playing against friends and/or the AI is always fun. I would especially recommend this game to casual players who want to stay abreast of the M:tG world but can't afford to maintain a standard deck.

reviewText:

As a veteran MTG player, there is so much room for this game to grow. It's good to pass the time at night for me when my usual gaming store is closed and I feel like playing a few rounds. I still prefer the traditional tabletop over this, but still bravo.

For those who are new to the game, I would recommend Magic Duels as it does having teaching tools for anyone interested in learning how to play from home.

For people who never played MTG, I would give this 8.5/10.
For veteran players I would give about a 7/10

reviewText:
I was surprised at how poorly this game was rated here, but apparently there were a lot of problems at launch and major setbacks with updates and patching. Plus a game this iconic and celebrated by its fans is always going to get tons of shade thrown at it by the hardcore/longtime crowd. However, I'm brand new to MTG in general as well as the digital doppelgangers (I also bought Magic 2014 DOTP Gold Complete on sale just prior to trying this out). I don't own a single paper card nor have I ever played any version of Magic, so I was a Magic virgin going into this (pun intended, nerds).

As of 2/22/16, this is a pretty good game. In fact, it's a great game for two types of gamers:

1. People new to Magic (me).
2. Casual/Mobile gamers (not me).

I highlighted that part as the TL;DR version, but I'll add this:

If you are new to Magic, this is probably the best possible way to learn. The tutorial/story mode is very well done and the interface is very clean, intuitive, and looks like it belongs in 2016.

Update on 3/10/16: There are some critical bugs in certain parts of the game, but the devs are serious about Duels going forward for at least two years. It probably won't ever compare to MTGO, but this will be the perfect intro for new players, in a perfect platform for it, free and accessible. Seriously, you can pretty much ignore most reviews from last year. The farming is opened up, you get more coins for everything, and the gold cap resets every 12 or 24 hours like the quests. It's not hard to amass cards if you can play an hour or so a day. My monored aggro (farming) deck usually beats the AI in 5-6 turns. Disable all the fancy animations and such, and a game can end in minutes. That definitely makes the AI look stupid (and it is sometimes), but the complaint about farming was repeated a lot a few months back.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Worst Magic game ever!
This is literly the worst Magic game I have ever experienced (and I have experienced most of them). I was excited about the game when it was announced but that quickly fell apart once I tried it.

I have really tried to like it but there is just no way that I could recommend this over Duels of the Planeswalkers 2013/2014. They are far superior games in almost every single way. Even the 2015 version, (which was the worst one yet), is much, much better than this one. The fact that this game is Free-to-Play is honestly not exactly much of a redeeming factor with a game this flawed.

----------CONS:----------

- The decks you can build are very boring. The cards have very little synergy and in general it feels like any exciting card combinations are just not there. You never feel like you have a truly powerful deck.

- Connection issues - This game will crash a lot and often you can not get progress, which also means you do not recieve coins, (currency for buying booster packs).

- The entire gameplay feels extremely slow for someone having played the earlier versions like 2014 or 2013. The gameplay needs to be swift and responsive. This is NOT the case!

- No lobbies - Why would you remove the most convinient way of getting together to play and select which deck you want to use? This is madness!

- No chat or online interaction of ANY kind. This means that it is impossible to coordinate strategy with you team mate. This is beyond stupid. It makes the online gaming feel like playing against an AI. There is no way of telling the difference. If a player gets replaced with an AI, you have no way of knowing it apart from the message, (which you can miss entirely if you turn your head for a moment).

- 3 & 4 player Free For All is not implemented. Why would you remove this mode from the game? It is just lazy.

- Bugs prevent certain cards from not working as the should. And by certain I mean several.

- Story of the game is boring and more importantly really short. Recently a new campaign was added. It is 5 games long. It feels extremely lazy and rushed. Even for a free game this is completely insulting.

- You can only recieve currency for completing the campaign ONCE. When you have completed a match, you will recieve ZERO coins for completing it again.

- The coin system looks good at first glance but feels more like a massive cash grab once you experience how slow progression is in this game. Makes you want to buy coins for real money (I would strongly advice you not to do this). In earlier games you could pay 1 euro to unlock a whole deck. There is a massive difference to this than unlocking 6 random cards.

- No Plane Chase mode. This is a minor complain because it was last seen in Duels of the Planeswalkers 2013. Makes the game a little more exciting and different. It's a refreshing change of pace. Would like to see this mode return to future releases.

----------PROS (mostly very minor):----------

- Deck building is easier than ever before. There is more support on how to get your deck started and also an auto complete option. This is honestly pretty solid.

- Nice to see good in depth tutorials. Makes it easier for new players to pick up. But why on earth would you force players to get through the tutorial? It is very long and tedious for experienced players who knows all about Magic. Forcing a player like me to get through it is a bit insulting.

- 2 Headed Giant mode is back, (removed in DotP 2015), but how do you invite friends to play? This does not seem to work as intended.

- Nice customization of Avatars for your decks. This is a pretty cool minor feature.

----------CONCLUSION:----------

I would NOT recommend this game at all. Maybe, just maybe if you are completely new to Magic the Gathering and don't feel like paying for the real experience just yet. Although I think chances are that this experience may hurt your overall opinion on Magic.

I would much rather recommend Duels of the Planeswalkers 2013/2014 even 2015 (better chances for online matchmaking). I recommend putting these titles on your wishlist and grab them on the next sale. They rarely get on sale but it happens.

Good luck!

reviewText:
Just got into this, and I have to say it's fun. I've never played any Magic game, I was always more of a YuGiOh fan, but finally I decided to give Magic Duels a try.

There's one thing you need to know- don't listen to people saying this game is grindfest. Sure, you earn just 5 gold for easy AI win (10 for medium, 15 for hard), sure there is a daily limit of 400 gold, and sure, there are only 6 cards in boosters. But there's one thing they don't usually mention- you will never get more copies of a card from booster than you are allowed to use in deck! If you'd play Magic Duels and get 400 gold every day, you could get all the cards from Origins set in under a month! A MONTH. Name another online CCG where you could get every available card in game under a month without spending a penny. (with the Zendikar expansion there are more cards, so you'd need more than a month now to get them all, but still it's not that bad).

Seriously, I've seen much worse grind CCGs (looking at you, Duel of Champions...)

And it's completely free. Give it a try.

reviewText:
long story short: being able to play magic for free is great.

Positives: MTG can be a very expensive hobby, i know from experience. This game gives you the ability to collect cards and play them completely for free. unlocking cards by simply playing magic is great value. Especially so for players who are new to the game, players without the financial capability to play magic on paper or on MTGO, or players who don't live near a FNM gamestore. Other positives are the casual gameplay, and the sleek design compared to MTGO.

Now the negatives however: The game has bugges. It's out for quite some time, and a number of bugs simply haven't been fixed. There are connectivity errors, causing you to lose coins or sometimes even boosters you buy. The coins are deducted from your account, but the boosters are simply not awarded. I'd say this has happened to me around 3-5 times in the 50+ hours i've played. Another problem I have with the game is the lack of communication between players. There is no chat. This is bothersome in 1v1, but simply mages 2 headed giant unplayable. You can't ask your teammate what they're planning to do, who is going to attack and block, etc.

However what made me recommend this game is the fact that I've contacted customer service about the boosters i didn't get awarded, and within 3 hours they contacted me back and refunded me the coins I lost. I found this to be decisive in giving the game a positive review. Also, the ability to play MTG for free is great. If the bugs are fixed in upcoming patches, it could be a truly great game.

reviewText: This is just one of the worst examples of AI cheating.  After playing countless battles against the AI, on the easy level by the way, and after creating and recreating deck after deck, the AI always brought the exact cards it needed to counter anything I had. It plays a destroy enchantment then I get lucky enough to draw another, low and behold the AI plays another destroy enchantment on it's very next turn.  This is just one example of many that happened way to many times to be a coincedence.  It's a pity I really enjoy the game but I can't continue to play with such obvious AI cheating.

reviewText:
This is presumably the final iteration in a long standing series of flavored magic card games; the effort to consolidate the annuals into a single framework.

Compared to it's predecessors it's the closest wizards has come to creating the mtg experience online.

While I'm not fond of the microtransaction model, it's use to permit players to buy more cards has been a staple of the ccg since it's inception.

Sometimes this is a game where you command an unstoppable force of nature to demolish an opponent before they have the land to assemble a defense, let alone dream of developing a counter-attack. Other times, you've lost well before deciding if you should keep your hand or not, and no matter how much skill or luck you are able to command, you'll be losing a short game. Yet it's the vast swath between these that's truly rewarding; where a deck fully designed by the player contends with something just as good by someone else, where the balance of power is constantly shifting, and the whole game comes down to a single health point or two, and a single turn makes the difference between a win and a loss.

So, after about 100 hours or so in the game, I feel comfortable enough to say it's worth a round every now and again.

reviewText:
Story:
There's not much too the story as it's mostly an image with text to read. In-fact you'll mostly skip or ignore it just to get to the game play however would been nice to hear some voices speak the lines of the text then just reading about it.

Graphics:
Wonderful if all you care about is the cards them self as everything else is plain and boring. The animations aren't good in-fact it's something you may want to turn off to increase the speed of the game. The board is plain however at least it doesn't hurt your eyes.

Sound:
The sound isn't awful however it's not great. The music doesn't really stand out at all however the sound effect aren't too bad.

Content:
Story Mode (Origins, Battle for Zendikar)
Battle Mode (Versus Battle, Solo, Two-Headed Giant)
Card Collection {Shows All Cards}
Quest {Achievement Unlocking for Coins}
It's basic which pretty much sums it all up. The modes while are okay for what they are there nothing that really stand out other then two-headed giant which allows you to play with a friend and not against them. There not much to the options of the game just your basic settings.

You are able also to build a card deck quickly without knowledge with the Deck Wizard. The Deck Build allows you to build your own custom deck with the current card you have unlock which is great and able to filter out card by type, color, cost, rarity it sadly lacks a search for card base on name and filter list of cards starting with A and ending with Z.

Difficulty:
It's hard very hard.... I'll admit I'm no expert at this game. I have very little knowledge about Magic TCG however I have played other card games in the past. The AI in the game seems unfair and doesn't help when in story your facing AI which are made to have better decks then the ones they give you to use.

Free to Play Model:
The model is fair to people who don't spend money on the game as their isn't too much of a pay to win aspect to Magic Duels. The major downside is you'll need to grind to unlock booster packs without spending any cash.

The closest it comes to pay to win is allowing people to pay for more booster packs which can lead to people getting cards quicker then someone who doesn't pay as they can still unlock booster packs by playing the game and getting coins. There is no guarantee that you'll end up with any rare card as all packs are RNG.

Extra Information
The game plays very slow like where you will be wishing their is some way to speed up the pace of the game play. You can disable the animations of the game to slightly improve the game speed.

Recommend:
No, While with friends this game can be fun sadly playing solo will make you hate the AI unless your very familiar with Magic The Gathering. If your a fan of card games or magic I do suggest you try it out for your self. If not well there other card games which may be simpler to get into.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Worst Magic game ever!
This is literly the worst Magic game I have ever experienced (and I have experienced most of them). I was excited about the game when it was announced but that quickly fell apart once I tried it.

I have really tried to like it but there is just no way that I could recommend this over Duels of the Planeswalkers 2013/2014. They are far superior games in almost every single way. Even the 2015 version, (which was the worst one yet), is much, much better than this one. The fact that this game is Free-to-Play is honestly not exactly much of a redeeming factor with a game this flawed.

----------CONS:----------

- The decks you can build are very boring. The cards have very little synergy and in general it feels like any exciting card combinations are just not there. You never feel like you have a truly powerful deck.

- Connection issues - This game will crash a lot and often you can not get progress, which also means you do not recieve coins, (currency for buying booster packs).

- The entire gameplay feels extremely slow for someone having played the earlier versions like 2014 or 2013. The gameplay needs to be swift and responsive. This is NOT the case!

- No lobbies - Why would you remove the most convinient way of getting together to play and select which deck you want to use? This is madness!

- No chat or online interaction of ANY kind. This means that it is impossible to coordinate strategy with you team mate. This is beyond stupid. It makes the online gaming feel like playing against an AI. There is no way of telling the difference. If a player gets replaced with an AI, you have no way of knowing it apart from the message, (which you can miss entirely if you turn your head for a moment).

- 3 & 4 player Free For All is not implemented. Why would you remove this mode from the game? It is just lazy.

- Bugs prevent certain cards from not working as the should. And by certain I mean several.

- Story of the game is boring and more importantly really short. Recently a new campaign was added. It is 5 games long. It feels extremely lazy and rushed. Even for a free game this is completely insulting.

- You can only recieve currency for completing the campaign ONCE. When you have completed a match, you will recieve ZERO coins for completing it again.

- The coin system looks good at first glance but feels more like a massive cash grab once you experience how slow progression is in this game. Makes you want to buy coins for real money (I would strongly advice you not to do this). In earlier games you could pay 1 euro to unlock a whole deck. There is a massive difference to this than unlocking 6 random cards.

- No Plane Chase mode. This is a minor complain because it was last seen in Duels of the Planeswalkers 2013. Makes the game a little more exciting and different. It's a refreshing change of pace. Would like to see this mode return to future releases.

----------PROS (mostly very minor):----------

- Deck building is easier than ever before. There is more support on how to get your deck started and also an auto complete option. This is honestly pretty solid.

- Nice to see good in depth tutorials. Makes it easier for new players to pick up. But why on earth would you force players to get through the tutorial? It is very long and tedious for experienced players who knows all about Magic. Forcing a player like me to get through it is a bit insulting.

- 2 Headed Giant mode is back, (removed in DotP 2015), but how do you invite friends to play? This does not seem to work as intended.

- Nice customization of Avatars for your decks. This is a pretty cool minor feature.

----------CONCLUSION:----------

I would NOT recommend this game at all. Maybe, just maybe if you are completely new to Magic the Gathering and don't feel like paying for the real experience just yet. Although I think chances are that this experience may hurt your overall opinion on Magic.

I would much rather recommend Duels of the Planeswalkers 2013/2014 even 2015 (better chances for online matchmaking). I recommend putting these titles on your wishlist and grab them on the next sale. They rarely get on sale but it happens.

Good luck!

reviewText:
The in game prompt said they wanted feedback so here it is: This game is buggy as hell. My friend made an 85 card mill deck and when she tried to play it, in game it gave her a 60 card dck with no land. So it randomly made her deck unplayable. After she had just spent money to be able to make that deck. Kind of a disincentive.
My self I just notice when it skips the main phase if you don't have a sorcery or instant to cast even if you do have activated abilities or other actions to take.

So yeah, pretty good for free, but they have to things to fix.

EDIT:  Oh and for the past week every time I try to play a solo game for the quests it just loads forever so I can't actually play. I mean if you didn't want me to play you should have just not made the game rather than keeping me from playing it, but thats where we are. Again, after spending money on cards, that I now don't get to use since it won't load. Thanks.

EDIT EDIT:  Ok I even tried playing it on my wife's computer, where it works and it still won't let me play solo. it just loads forever. And then when you close it, its still running a process somehwere, so you have to go into friggin task manager to actually close it.

The frustrating thing is its enjoyable when it works, but there are so many bugs. Like I tried playing vs (which it amazingly let me do) and then the opponent played a card that returned a card to your hadn adn then makes you discard a card.  So I have two cards in hand; the creature and a card I want to save, so i click on the creature...and the game says you can't play that its your opponents turn" while the window at the bottom says "pick a card to discard" with a timer running out >_< so i keep trying and it keeps saying no adn eventually the timer runs out and it gets rid of the card i wanted to save. Its that kind of ♥♥♥♥ constantly.

This game is like "this shoe would be really comfy except for that blde you put in the heel. why did you do that?" The fact Magic is fun but the game keeps ♥♥♥♥ing it up to keep you from enjoying it just makes it frustrating. A bad game you could just dismiss but this is a game that is *almost* good
date: and all the more infuriating for it."

reviewText:
As you can see, I've over 500 hours in this version of Magic: The Gathering. I've been a player of the card game since 4th edition. I've played the Microprose version for many more hours than this version.

I like the core game.

However, with the latest update, the game was essentially broken by an intentional design choice on the part of the developers. Namely skipping a players turn unless they have a sorcery-speed or land card in their hand. This breaks a fundamental aspect of the game that instants can be cast at any time. The game will not allow you to do so.

It doesn't speed up the game like the developers insist. It renders a large amount of cards unplayable, including the vaunted planeswalkers.

This is only one of the bugs in the game, but it is the most glaring issue. Other issues abount. Quests do not reward you all the time, or if they do they don't give you full rewards. They revoked (banned) earned cards and replaced them.

Until they revert the automatic priority passing, I would recommend that you play the physical game instead of this garbage.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Lots of problems with the campaign deck design. The game gives you your own collection, and encourages microtransation purchase of virtual packs, but then gives you a sizable amount of campaign scenarios, where in all of them you are forced to use their preconstructed decks, which at least 80% of them are filled with unfun garbage. For a game designed for appealing to beginners, it debuts and shows off a spectrum of bland and unspectacular cards like Drownyard Explorers, Shambling Ghouls, Fire Elemental, Carrion Crow. I was enraged to see Nephalia Moondrakes as Innistrad Jace's 'big' card.

The Origins campaign, spare much less than half the battles, were insufferably boring. Liliana's decks in particular were very bland and very much worse than what you were facing, up until the last battle, which was actually well done. Gideon was boring, Chandra, for a 'burn deck', saw a distinct lack of burn spells, and a lot unspectacular creatures. Nissa's deck was usable, and what should be the bare bones standard for entertaining design, and Jace's campaign managed to have the only consistently fun deck and gameplay.

The Shadows Over Innistrad challeneges were quite bad with a few exceptions: Jace and Tamiyo vs Avacyn had a good decklist, Sorin vs Avacyn would have been a great fight; Sorin had a very fun deck, but Avacyn's deck was very underwhelming and very squishable, I replayed that battle twice, wondering where her threatening cards were and found none. Jace's deck proved to be very slow and bland against all aggro decks, I had no fun with it until a brand new Welcome to the Fold was put into his last encounter.

I actually do not have complaints about the Zendikar campaigns; Gideon's decks were actually good and fun to use, and the very last battle against the Eldrazi titans was very well done and very fun.

The storytelling was adequately executed, I am generally satisfied.

The game engine appears to be the same Duel of the Planeswalkers engine that has been used for years. I think it does have some issues regarding the game atmosphere and feel; the effects and card animations have lingering, floaty animations that confuse or lag, rather than impress, or appear 'magical' or whatever the intent was. They aren't inherently bad, they are well done for the intent to be floaty or slow, but they are frustrating when you are in a boring spot, or losing a match. In particular I feel the drawing animation should be much more concise. Sometimes some cards fly erractically (I experienced this when opponents used cards with madness effects in the Innistrad campaign), linger and wait for your acknowledgement, or don't linger and wait for your acknowledgement when you expect them to.

For magic's complicated design and arcitecture, the engine executes it fairly well, with a few occasional hiccups. I find myself occasionally having just not enough time to respond to a spell or ability that I really intended to respond to as soon as I noticed my opponent's move, while sometimes feel frustrated waiting for priority to tick away while either me or my opponenet have no mana untapped. This is less of a criticism, I imagine priority is a part of mtg that is a nightmare to design for in a game. I feel the use of the space bar handling both pausing the timer and passing priority when appropriate was handled fairly elegantly, and should have been noted at some point in tutorial dialogue.

I had two technical problems: I had some problems with a glitch in the graveyard browser, several times while I tried to make a decision while one of my spells was resolving, I tried to minimze my spell, and when I entered the graveyard broweser, no cards showed up. This happened every time I tried, and robbed me of information I could have used in gameplay decisions.
I had several crashes in Chandra's campaign against the Lieutenant. I am sorry that I don't have any information on what could have caused the crash. It was mildly frustrating, but I managed to make it past the node on about my fourth time. The good news is that these were really the only glitches I encountered in a very expansive and complicated system.

I do fairly often get screwed by the game skipping phases when I have activated abilities I want to use on my turn. I don't have an exact example at the moment, but several times the game skips phases on your turn when you don't havve creatures on your turn, and I have wanted to activate draw effects and hopefully draw a land to drop, but the game will skip the phases so quickly that by the time I can actually pause the timers to activate my abilities/cast my instants, it's already the end step on my turn.

The ingame popups while navigating the main menu are really annoying, and have yet to actually pique my interest in anything they state. The game has spammed me with many popup informing me of a reward for beating the Gideon campaign, which was something I claimed within the first hour of the game, and irrelevant like, 4 or 5 times they informed me of it.

The deckbuiliding UI is pretty bad, filters for only colors, nothing for rarity or card effects. Finding the way to name and change the picture for my deck required me to look online, and was very unintuitively placed. You should be able to favorite cards to find during deck construction. I didn't buy any packs with real money, and I am already swamped with how many cards I have to wade through, the system really needs improvement.

This game makes a critical mistake that is very common in the video game industry, and that is hand-holding new players with tutorial messages. It is very patronizing to players when games decide we are not intelligent enough to figure out mechanics on our own. I am playing from the prespective of a veteran player rather than a beginner, so I am predisposed towards not needing the tutorials, so my criticism will be biased, but I do feel that a better design would be painless for a seasoned player as well as accessible to a novice. I feel the bland preconstructed deck construction is also tied to this 'tutorial' mentality, that starting players cannot handle flashier or more powerful cards for some reason. I feel this decision is not only mistaken, but detrimental towards the starting player's excitement and motivation. I feel that Wizards puts a considerable amount of thought in how to introduce new players, and this overcaution has hindered the game's enjoyability and viability as an introductory tool.

The new design of their pay model is very interesting. Though I tend to dislike freemium-style, free to play games, as they prey on whales, I think it's ultimately Wizards/the dev team's prerogative for how they decide to monetize their game. I think the current design is more advantageous than the previous model of buying the complete game, given that they can use Magic: Duels as a tutorial/introductory tool for bringing in new players to the game in reality. While I feel that duality in functionality was a smart design choice, I think the game is ineffective its execution, as I stated in the above paragraph. I would feel more inclined to purchase packs if I felt owning these virtual cards meant anything; they will be outdated once Wizards releases whatever their next game is. The packs purchasing mechanics also comes with a very slow earning of packs with ingame currency, which for me at least is a bit daunting and discouraging.

In summary, some things about this undertaking were done very well, more things were done very badly. I love mtg, Hopefully the next installment is better executed.

If you're experienced, there is an advanced deck-building mode, but if you're new to the game, it has a deck wizard (no pun intended!) to help you as you build your decks. reviewText:
This Game has potential but lack a community feel

Pro
Mostly Free with decent business model.
Closest you can get to Mtg without playing and arm and a leg.
1 mythic 2 rare and 3 uncommon rule make it less p2w than original magic.
Growing card collection with every expansion.

Cons
No form of communications with other players.
No android Support.
No Cross Platform Support with accounts being restricted to that platform.
A lot of missing cards from each expansion
1,2,3 rules does take away from the original mtg experience
Only 2 game modes.
Many bugs and the game is rarely updated.
Deck builder has limited search features.

Overall I would say not to throw money at this game as I have no confidence in the Dev to address any of the cons.
I feel this game will always be restricted on how good its allowed with fear of being better than real magic or magic online. This game seems to be a half hatred attempt to bit at the heels of hearthstone without trying hard enough to beat it.

reviewText:
1)  Game doesn't actually function properly.  No second Main phase.  (Seriously.  Not a joke.)  (Edit - Recently managed to cast something during a second main phase but there are still loads of bugs and improperly implemented cards.  Really, this is not properly implemented.)

2)  Loads of players already have played a lot, so they're running around in multiplayer, even deranking to kill new players for easy gold.  You can't really win in multiplayer unless you spend a lot on cards, and == multiplayer is where the gold is at ==.   (If you do want utility commons, that still means buying loads of packs until you can fill out your commons collection.  So really no escape from buying packs.)

3)  Limited card library.  There are not a lot of viable decks, and you can't craft specific cards, so A) play gets repetitive after a while, B) it takes a while (or money) to build your collection to the point you can build one of those viable decks.  So you really do have a pay-to-win / grind-to-win for what's a rather limited game.

4) Mods ban people on forums that don't like what they've done, and delete critical posts (even polite ones).  Source - looked at Magic: 2015 to see how people reacted to Magic: Duels as a successor, looked on Magic: Duels forums and noticed certain posts had been deleted.  Well, really.

==

Although there are a load of things holding this game back (no second main phase, really?), even though the developers are pretty unresponsive (not responding to lack of second main phase, really?), mods apparently act shady, loads of iffy things - if you're a dyed-in-the-wool Magic fan, or just sick of Hearthstone or whatever, go ahead and pick this game up.  Why choose the lesser of two evils (Hearthstone) when you can choose the greater of two evils (Magic: the Gathering).  You can have some fun, etc.

But if you start thinking about spending money, take a good hard look at the developers' lack of support for the game, the limited meta, overbearing mod actions - it's just really not good.

Note - there ARE some nice things for new players, like you start off with a load of cards and lands that produce multiple mana types.  Still leaves you dead against anyone with any kind of bank (whether money or time invested) but enough to play around some, anyways.

reviewText: One of many many re-iterations of the MTG trading card game.  I usually like these games, I also rarely write reviews, and when I do it is purely for reccomendations.  This game... however, has caused me to make a exception to that trend.  Most MTG games are fairly straigth forward, and as with most of the games, an eventual purchase is expected to fully enjoy the game.  Either you need to pay intially to play the games, or you will have to purchase some cards/booster packs to play beyond the standard pre-made packs.  This game... however, advertises itself as truly free, and then berates you with annoying totorials, oddly placed buttons that often result in misclicks, and a very liberal use of language.  I began playing and went through the very lengthy, and quite tedius tutorial/story mode because it provides you with enough ingame currency to purchase a few booster packs.  This tutorial is the epitomy of well duh" and takes you through some rediculously obvious and self explanatory game mechanics in a fashion that requires you to constantly load and swap out of your main tutorial into a secondary tutorial scenario that forcefeeds you mechanics as simplistic as casting an instant spell
recommended: using a "tap creature" ability... and many other things that truly shouldn't need clarification.  In fact
hoursPlayed: there are a couple abilities that could do with a bit of explaining
voteText: but they actually seemed to have changed the rules (you can now tap a tapped creature.. which doesn't seem relavent
helpfulPercent: but it used to come into play a lot) and leave out those tutorials until you coincidentally run into them during an actual match..  but back to the main issues.  The starter pack is quite possibly one of the worst starters you could possibly get.  I'm actually wondering if it is truly random
votesHelpful: but many of the other reviews back up the fact that it just seems horrible. reviewText:
( Edited to reflect a more accurate opinion of the game as it is at the time of edit )

With it's initial release, this game was broken as hell. Since the release of their latest update ( fixing the connectivity issues with both their store and with other people online, as well as a few other issues ), gameplay has become . . . bearable. There are still some issues with the game, some of which are still incredibly annoying ( heavy pixelation of cards and a black field for Win 10 users ).

One new issue i've found involves a few specific cards ( of which the names will not be listed in this review in the hopes of preventing people from exploiting the bug that accompanies these cards until the issue is fixed ). Despite the card's clear targetting of a single creature only, will often break the match you're playing and render the remainder of the creatures essentially useless and hand the win over to the other AI/player, regardless of whether or not you were winning.

With the game as it is now, I still don't recommend it.

I wanted to like this game. I did like this game until 1 single mechanic ruined it for me.
When playing against a human player in verses battles, if your opponent concedes they are replaced by an AI.
The AI being BS hax is besides the point, thats why I play against other players; But when some one concedes, that should be victory for the other player. I've played so many games where my opponent concedes and I end up getting beat by AI after tedious battle I should have been awarded victory for 10 minutes ago when my opponent conceded. How do both players lose a battle?!?! I don't care if you drew a crap hand from the start, mulligan or leave and that should be it, victory of the other player.
So frustrated, not worth my time anymore.

reviewText:
Even though I haven't experienced any of the wonderful glitches/features that has made this game unplayable for most people I still can't bring myself to recommend it. Honestly this feels like Magic 2015 all over again.
First of all, the deck building feature would be great if building your own deck was actually plausible. As it stands it suffers from the same issue as its predecessor in that the only decks that you can actually win with are the premade ones. Tweaking them with cards from booster packs is not the same as making your own deck.
Speaking of booster packs, if you've read some of the other reviews than you probably have a general idea of what a pain it is to unlock them. After completing the campaign your two options are to either challenge other players or to grind against the AI. The former is the potentially the most profitable but poses a problem in that it's not uncommon to have your opponent quit like a jackass if you're beating them. If that happens then you get nothing which apparently the developers thought was fair. The latter is just a pain since the AI appears to be the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ lovechild of Skynet and Ultron. It definitly does not care for humans and will do everything in its power to destroy you which it will have no problem doing since it will likely have much better cards than you unless you've either spent about a year grinding for coins or have dropped a few hundred dollars on booster packs. Even if you do manage to scrape out a win the spoils of victory are hardly worth effort.
If they add a larger (I mean MUCH larger) variety of cards, improve the rewards (by which I mean actually provide rewards) from multiplayer opponent rage quits, lower the monetary cost of booster packs (right now they cost more than actual cards!), and add different difficulty levels for the AI (something a little easier than impossible) then this could shape up to be a decent game. More campaigns or story quests wouldn't hurt either.
...
Or maybe they should just try again next year.

reviewText:
Fun to make a deck. Terrible to play.

How do you justify creating a game where a player can bail from the game the moment they realize they cannot win, causing their opponent to play the remainder of the game vs. the AI which doesn't play at all by the rules, but cheats to win, so you can never get the gold coins to advance?

This allows you to never give out the free gold after a match but to rather force players to purchase gold with real money. This is but one of the numerous very large problems this game has… Problems that don't need to be here. Problems that you could have fixed instantly if you cared to. What is worse this, problem actually seems to be there by design.

There are so many more problems with this game that I can't even list them all and I will not even try. This is just the top one for me, since I have yet to finish a single game that I was winning vs. a random player since I started playing the game. Not once…

You will not see a dime from me, wasted on this game with this built in system, designed to steal away a player's chance at earning the gold in game. This game is essentially a scam, because you designed the game this way fully knowing that players would abuse it this way.

So, so not the game we were waiting for!

reviewText: The developers of this game seem to have confused the term 'challenging' for 'frustrating'. The introductory story follows the adventures of Gideon as he ascends to to ignite his spark and become a planeswalker. Those duels were all sufficiently challenging to me as a casual MTG player, but still winnable. I have, since then, tried to play Chandra Nalaar's story, and have yet to be able to defeat the first freaking duel. While I haven't really put much effort into testing the rest of the game? The fact that I have a Chandra Nalaar deck, which is only 40 cards, and has maybe two playsets of burn damage cards? And the rest of them are creatures? I'm kinda beginning to wonder if the developers even know what MTG is, let alone how to play it. I'll probably just delete it and pretend it doesn't exist here before long. The -only- upside to this experience thus far? Is that I didn't spend a cent on it. If I had? I'd be demanding my money back.

reviewText:
While I did like the earlier parts of the campaign /story mode of both Origins and Zendikar, I will say that this becomes not difficult, but unfair in my opinion.

Getting further into Origin's story mode I noticed that often times the enemy deck was made specifically  to beat the ones you are given. What's even worse is you don't have a side board to help you out. This game doesn't even have the excuse of pay to win here, it's just that badly unbalanced.  I understand they're trying to engineer difficulty but when it's to a point of no progression and no way around it that's just plain unfair. What I reccomend is that the story mode be reworked, until then, I doubt I will play anything but online

I have other complaints now.
The game feels too unbalanced and because of that I uninstalled Magic Duels...AGAIN!
While the campaign requires a specific strategy in itself, which became more angering than anything to pull off. Getting right to it, I tried multiplayer after some time the multiplayer is not playable for me. No it is not a technical issue, it is a balancing issue. Everyone has better cards than me, constantly outracing and beating me and I rarely ever win if at all. The ranking system seems to be something thrown in as it imposes no actual system. Instead it just gives you a shiny number to display on your player portrait to show off.
Lastly, for someone who is busy getting actual cards for actual decks I have I will not be getting microtransactions and I will not grind hours on end just to recieve a few booster packs.
Needless to say, there needs to be some ACTUAL ranking system, not just badges to show how futile your efforts will be and how many single player matches you need to do to get something worthwhile to be able to even stand a chance against anything.

TL;DR:Game needs major overhauling for multiplayer

reviewText:
So As a game that is FREE to play it's not too bad and helps you to understand the rules of a larger magic game.

But as a playable game... it falls into the catagory of maybe I should clean my room instead. Several fun aspects have been removed from previous games, such as the chanllenges, rematch, guests, and arch enemy, and have been replaced with a more... monatary system.

Verses, 2v2, and the quest systems are still there but the quest system isn't as involved as before, leaving quests to be future content. As for verses it's become a choice; Play with some of the worst cards available or buy packs and hope that out of the 6 new cards you'd get something that is playable. If you go with the packs you'll quickly understand that you have to pay up some real money for digital fluff or wait, complete daily goals and get a new pack every week or so.

I understand there are real people behind this game making it work and they need to eat so I guess forking over some money wouldn't hurt.

So is this game worth it's price? YES.  Is this a game I'll play more offten? If the improve the cards you can get...then yes...otherwise no.

reviewText:
plenty of game changing bugs that most definitely should have been adjusted by now.

card mechanics do not always work the way they are intended. example erebos's titan states that it has indestructible as long as opponent controls no creatures but, he retains indestructible even when the opponent controls creatures.

in the older games in the series you used to be able to pull the left trigger on the controller to zoom in to the last played card. it is definitely something that should at least be an option.

it seems like it should be a little easier to get cards.

on the plus side the interface, graphics, music and overall feel of the game are nice. its just that the flaws are very blaring and this is coming from someone who has been playing the paper game since revised edition.

it should be noted that the game has very good potential, the devs just need to update and fix it.

reviewText:
Plus Side:
+Story Mode uses real decks.
+Close to real MTG rules.
+Looks pretty.
+A couple cool story matches.

Minus Side:
-*Close* to real MTG rules, for instance sometimes tokens don't have summoning sickness.
-Stupidly long load times.  I mean really, how long does it take to digitally shuffle two decks?
-The grind is too long to open a pack of SIX cards. As opposed to the 15 you would get in a real pack.  If you manage to complete the 3 quests you get you probably can get a pack, but that's the next point...
-The quests suck. They basically so far have been 11 quests to win with their terrible deck builder wizard, 1 to target an opponent directly and 1 to win with my own hand built decks that CAN win.  Oh and by the way you can only abandon one quest a day.
- Poor starting cards, hard to get a decent theme going to even have a chance to win even on easy.
- Awkward timing on play. See each hit against the opponent one by one, but when it's time to counter a spell you cant click fast enough.  Of course you get a timer each time the opponent plays a card even if you can't actually respond with a spell.
- Deck building has very basic filters.  Needs some keyword searching or something.
- Deck building is unintuitive.  Not even a 'save deck' button.  They're really pressuring the deck wizards that can't deliver early game.
- Story opponents are frequently given the perfect counter deck on non-final bosses.
- Edit: Oh forgot to mention, after finally getting a completable quest, completion did not award gold, hence the review/uninstall.

Altogether, rather play Yu Gi Oh on Game Boy Advance still.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I love MTG, but this game is not worth the money. The campaign was fun and challenging but has no replayability. It takes way too long to grind gold to buy packs. The community is all but dead. Matches take longer than they should because of animations (even with all the extra stuff turned off). The biggest problem though is that when someone concedes a match to you, you're stuck playing against the AI when the match should have ended right then. I understand why people quit, I do it too to save myself time, but the match needs to end when someone concedes. One of my smaller issues with this game is milling. I think these online magic games should be trying to take the best of magic and making it a simpler, more enjoyable game. Milling decks should be left to the try-hards at Friday night magic tournaments. Again, the milling is just a small issue I have with the game, and not the reason why I'm not recommending this.

reviewText:
While Magic 2015 was a really good game, Magic Duels falls short in nearly every aspect that matters:
- included cards do not provide enough diversity
- boring quests do not reward enough gold
- cheating, otherwise stupid AI
- manipulated matches (the failed attempt to make the game more exciting)
- matchmaking delivers poor matchups (possibly due to lack of players)
- pay2win destroys multiplayer
- ranking system destroys fun
- no reason for creative deck building

From a technical point of view:
- no anti-aliasing
- poor sound mixing (volume of music & effect)
- Steam overlay pauses the game (also in multiplayer)
- no chat, no lobbies (which eliminates the important social aspect)

I would have preferred paying for a fixed set of cards to enjoy some good, in-depth multiplayer matches. Even some pay-in one-off tournaments (sealed deck, booster draft) would have been a great addition. But instead Magic Duels is dominated by its pay2win nature and its impersonal matches. But in its current state, I am not willing to spend any money on this game.

reviewText:
I've been playing all of the computer Magic games since they first game out.  While this game has some issues I think it's overall good, has plenty of potential and is far better than the horrible version of their last release.

While the game can be slightly buggy at times I believe the patches are slowly taking care of those issues.  I think the deck colors are fairly balanced and the autobuilder is a good help, especially to those learning the game.  While the computer does seem to cheat" at times it puts up a good challenge and is probably the best AI I've seen in a Magic game.

The player matches do drag.  I'd like to see shorter timers and stiffer penalties for people who drop off matches.

I definitely disagree with the people whining about having to pay money to get good cards.  I play sparingly

recommended: along with many rare cards along with 2 of 5 of the Planeswalkers.\n\nAs long as they provide fairly regular patches and content updates this should shape up to be a great game."

reviewText:
TL;DR The game is good but needs some fixing and more cards, but it's playable in it's current state.

If you're not able to play Magic IRL like myself or don't want to spend your whole life savings on cards, Duels will suffice.

The game has it's share of problems. Some of the daily quests are broken, the ones where you have to win a number of games using a specific color combination deck only registers victories when using a deck made in the deck builder tool
and not when using a custom built one.

There are about 300 cards in the game making the pool of viable decks very small. Mirror match-ups are common, and the PvP matchmaking is swarmed by elf decks which are not easily countered due to the limited cards. I imagine as time goes on, if the game has a player base, more cards will be released.

The singleplayer component is short but fun. 5 campaigns with 5 missions each will take you a few hours to beat depending on RNG. Often, you will be stuck on a mission simply due to not getting any useful cards from the prebuilt deck and be forced to restart the duel. The singleplayer awards 750 gold in total which is enough for 5 booster packs.

The price of booster packs is not very high, considering how much gold is won from duels. A single booster pack costs 150 gold, a victory against a real player awards 20 gold and playing against the AI awards 5, 10 and 15 gold respectively according to the difficulty of the AI.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
NOTE: I dont play MTG In meatspace as it were, so all of my experiences should be seen as someone who has little knowledge of the game and that im coming into this after playing Magic 2012/ 2013

This should be seen as more of a first glimpse into the game for now, I may revisit this if my opinion changes.

For a start, I had no issues loading the game at all, booted the game up, worked absolutely fine.

The interface for the game is pretty standard MTG game fare, but theres no need to fix what isnt broken. And the developer seems to have gotten this down to a T at this point.

I loaded up the campaign, and after rushing through all of the tutorial stuff, I got to my first matches in the campaign.
I have not yet started any of the campaigns barr the first one, however I sincerely hope that the difficulty raises, as I did not have a single match in which I dropped below 18, but overall the game ran absolutely without a hitch. I have seen bugs and errors in other peoples reviews that I have not experienced my self, but without a more complete scope of how the game is, I cannot comment on their issues one way or another.

After completing the campaign I went into the deck builder to see what that was like and I was pleasantly surprised to see an assisted deck builder. Of course the builder follows certain deck archetypes that arent neccesary for the higher class players, but for scrubby little noobs like me, it helped me build a deck I was comfortable in using that seemed to work well enough against the easy and medium AI.

So overall the game is good.. However there is one major bugbear that I have.. Microtransactions.
Of course I understand this is a free to play game, and the developer needs to make money one way or another, and thats fine.
To get new cards through booster packs, You need gold, you can earn gold by doing the daily quests in game (In a manner not dis-similar to hearthstone) Winning matches and doing the campaign.
My problem would be that the rate of coin earning seems far too low to keep someone who has no intention of putting any money into the game playing to earn new cards. Infact, if I were to want to spend any money, I would want to spend it on cards in real life.

To summarise. I would say that this is a good game for beginners and newbies to MTG, and in this way it serves its purpose to teach how to play the game and to show what the game can be like.
The downside is a fairly restricted microtransaction for cards system, which could be fixed with tweaking to the ammount of coins you get for completing tasks, or lowering the price of boosters in game.

Would recommend to New players, but am aware that there are better options for more hard core players of MTG, such as MTG Online.

reviewText: Two headed giant is UNPLAYABLE with a friend vs other actual people, it works VS AI, but who cares about that. also, you cant earn gold (the only way to get boosters, getting new cards) at any time you're searching with a friend. Speaking of the gold system, it is the most cancerous thing i've ever seen. You can only earn so much gold from wins every day and the cap for this is WAY TOO LOW, also you have to restart the game to see the gold you got from challenges every time you complete one. Another weird thing is that you can have as many legendaries in your deck as you want now, why did they change that? The difficulties for the AI is completely backwards, Hard is so easy you almost cant lose and easy is suprisingly hard. A good thing is this game has controller support, but every time i try and use it it locks up and i have to do something with the mouse to get it out of the lock. Basically the game is complete trash as of now, but i do see potential after ALOT of updates to fix the countless problems with the main selling point of this game (two headed giant) and they allow you to earn more gold daily or make it quicker to earn gold (i understand its free to play so its to encourage you to spend money on the game but the pricing for the booster packs are way too high for such a buggy game (estimate ~$60 to buy enough boosters to unlock all the card when older magic games go for way cheaper))

reviewText: This game is amazingly broken, the AI always seem to have the perfect hand, the decks you are given are ridiculously unbalanced in campaign, and the cards you get from the free box are also amazingly unbalanced, like this game was made in a rush or somethin gbecause i cannot enjoy a broken game. You earn little currency for the level of bull i have to play through, and not to mention that the game is BROKEN AF. Please please please fix this game, because its not enjoyable when you have to restart every ♥♥♥♥ing match 100 times in order to get a playable hand, the shuffling mechanic sucks for the user, ooh but the AI always gets perfect hands, good land advantage, card advantage, and of course they all have OP cards while you get the equivalent of 3 booster packs, which is nothing you can work with. If you urge me to build my own deck befor ei can do anything else, FFS give me a balanced number of cards instead of randomly giving high cost cards and making me unlock better stuff by suffering a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t campaign. Seriously, i thought this game would be fun and awesome, but the curb is too steep, i love MTG, but this game is an insult to the card game, not even in real life starter decks do i get so royaly screwed like in this game, at least the RL game gives me a balanced deck when i buy it, F2P i know, but come on look at your reviews, more people hate this game for the same reasons im stating than the ones that gave it a thumbs up, and even the ones that gave it a thumbs up complained about how unsatisfying the cards are and how broken it is. Fix this game srsly, 2 hours and i want to throw my computer out a window because of the terrible experience this game gave me. And if you dont fix it you guys really ♥♥♥♥ing hate your costumers, its a bloody wonder youre still making games if thats the case. thanks for the terrible experience, what a piece of ♥♥♥♥ game...I guess we will never find a really fun virtual version of a card game except yugioh with the handhelds, thats how you ♥♥♥♥ing do a card game, no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, just play, earn points, buy, make deck better little by little, but with a starter deck that wont screw you over or be easily countered by the opponent, i suggest you play yugioh on the ds or gba or whatever platform you can find the legit card game in virtual form, so you can grasp on how to do a ♥♥♥♥ing card game in video game form. terrible terrible terrible execution of MTG.

reviewText:
It's not a BAD interpretation of MTG. I just can't recommend it for anyone that actually plays the real thing.

Good

-MTG anytime, by yourself or against a random player online

-Possible to unlock all the cards for free

-Nifty ability to stop the timer and do what you want in response, sort of like in real life (assuming you're not playing a complete jerk) you can tap lands and do something

-Origins is a pretty good card set to start with

-The Quest system. Pretty fun, gives background on the planeswalkers, has enough challenge to make it enjoyable without being super frustrating. Also teaches the game mechanics very well.

Bad
-The online MM is TERRIBLE. Someone leaves? Penalty for not wanting to play out against the AI. Someone drops? Penalty. The wait time is rather long (at least it has been for me) and prepare to get wrecked by people who have dropped the money to unlock as many cards as they can.

-The guided deck builder is just plain bad. Instead of putting up a bunch of dreck, how about providing a list of one drops, two drops, three drops, etc and saying Hey
date: you should have this many of this kind of drop."\n\n-The grind to unlock cards. Seriously this right here is killing me. I don't expect it to be a waltz through the park but it's so agonizingly slow and the quest system just doesn't work right. The need to use the awful deck builder to do half of them makes it even worse

reviewText:
I have a mixed opinion about this game. As it stands right now I have to NOT recomend it. I'll explain briefly why:

- The card collection available kinda sucks.

- In-game cards cost as much as its real life counter-parts

The free alternative is getting gold from quests / story mode / battle (PvP or pvAI).

- Story mode has a set amount of gold to make. Basically you get 1 booster per story and there's 1 story per color. In this story mode you're given a pre build deck to use.

- Battle mode is pretty much a drag. The easy battles against AI award 5 gold each (150g per booster). 10g for medium and 15g for hard. The bad part is: your starting collection is not enough to make a deck that has a decent chance against medium or higher. You only get gold if you win. PvP has the same problem.

- You get a daily quest everyday. This combined with battle mode could be a good alternative, but the problem is most quests are win 2 games using a <<SPECIFIC DECK ARCHETYPE>> deck" and your starting collection doesn't allow you to even build most decks and the decks you can build pratty much awful.

So I would recommend playing the real thing."

reviewText:
As a fan of the card game on paper I find Magic Duels slow, frustrating and unengaging.

It takes too much effort to unlock all of the cards through gameplay, to buy them all is exorbidant.

There is close to no capacity for more complex maneuvers.

There are too many issues with connectivity and the in game currency.

If you want to get involved in the game, this might help however nothing beasts FNM or a prerelease at your local store.

6/10 if you want to kill some time, tear out some hair and really want a magic fix it's okay. Not sure if I'll uninstall.

reviewText: I really dont understand why after a online opponent concedes the duel you dont automaticlly win, but insted they have an A.I. take over which is ok but never makes a mistake and if you lose to the A.I. it still counts as a loss even though your opponent gave up. I've played MTG in real life and everytime my opponent forfeited the game was over, no resolving the match, no playing till someone was at zero hp. This one thing is the reason I am giving this version of MTG a 3/10 if it didnt have this one horrible flaw in it I would rate it much higher.
