reviewText:
As someone that always loved the card games in general but could never afford or be bothered to gather countless cards  I was very excited to try the new Free2Play MTG. I had my doubts after getting one of the plainswalkers game in the past but still positively approached the game.
Me and my friend wanted so badly to get a duel off as we played in real life few years back using some sets bought for cheap but still had alot of fun. Well of course you cant. Not from the start a least. You guessed it, you have to unlock it first. Yep - you have to unlock multiplayer games in a multiplayers card game.
But thats just a tip of the iceberg really. There is so many things that are bad about this game that its just impossibile do concive how a game like this could have been released at all.

I wont make it to list all of the things that wrong with this game but heres just a few from the top of my head:
One of the worst Menu systems I have seen im my 20 years of gaming. I was surprised that I can be that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off about menu but then I realise that its just plain insult.
Wanna play anything? You HAVE to play what game wants you to play first. You wanna skip tutorials cause you played 10 years of MTG? Well to bad for you, you cant.
Connection to steam cloud or any network capability of this game should be reffered to every time you look for a methaphor of an absolut worst one ever implemented into a game. You literally get disconnected all the time losing your wins (dont register), losing achievements (i dont care about those but some ppl do), card pack and lots of more annoying stuff.
Deck builder is so bad I cannot even describe it. It is the most useless, uninnovative, annoying piece of crap my sore eyes have ever glanced at. Honestly you need to witness it to understand how irritating can just putting 60 cards togather in a deck be. Its beyond atrocious.
Pack of course have 6 cars in them - yes you heard right - not 15 as in MTG. And to get one pack you need to do some griding as well. All in all you would need to grind alottttt to not spend money If you wish to have all the cards.
You can get some gold (in game money) with quests daily or weekly but guess what? Yes thats right they bug out to so sometimes you get the gold, sometimes you dont. Like everything in this game, quests are also boring and mostly consist of getting wins with decks that game have created for you.
You play multiplayer. You crash your oponent. He concides. What happens? He gets swapped for AI. This has to be the biggest WTF of card game history. You are literally forced to waste time and play the rest o the game with an AI. Best of it is you can lose to the AI and not get points. I think there is nobel prize winner on this game programmers team and all people who played this game have a special place in our hearts for this guy - its just not warm and fuzzy.
I was going to name PROS but I hardly can? I tought maybe the campaigns but those force you to do tutorials for HASTE or TREMPLE which for me was so boring I couldnt take it as a positive. I thought I can give a game system a pass but after first strike sometimes didnt work (it just didnt, sometimes yes sometimes not) I cant even do that.

Just dont touch this game. You will want to like it but it will just ♥♥♥♥ you off and dissapoint you to the point you cant take it anymore. I played maybe 10 hours last 5-6 cause i really wanted to give it a chance.

It is disgusting.
It is bad.
It is broken.
Do not get near this game.

reviewText: If I could put 2 thumbs down I would. There is a reason this game is free and I cant get those 4 hours of my life back that I wasted trying to play this game. Other magic editions were great. I loved 2014 edition and 2015 had a few bugs but was still very fun to play. I have had zero fun with this game. There is no skip option in the tutorials for people who play magic and the gameplay is very slow. Each turn takes forever. Next thing is coins. This is magic not farmville, why did they suddenly add coins? Another thing is in game play why is there no chat? Are we really that irresposible that we cant chat with our teammates in double headed giant or chat with out opponents? Not only is there no chat but DHG the cards and gameplay are so small its hard to see the cards being played. Now onto the story mode. In 2015 you were allowed to choose and build your own decks for story mode. This game not only starts you off with almost no cards to build decks with it doesnt let you pick a deck for story mode. You have to play with the deck they give you and you are at a disadvantage with the decks. I have tried story mode 5 times now and each time I have gotten almost all manna and no good cards. This game has frusterated me to the point where I almost threw my laptop across the room. I am officially  going back to 2015 magic until they decrappify this game!!!

reviewText: One of many many re-iterations of the MTG trading card game.  I usually like these games, I also rarely write reviews, and when I do it is purely for reccomendations.  This game... however, has caused me to make a exception to that trend.  Most MTG games are fairly straigth forward, and as with most of the games, an eventual purchase is expected to fully enjoy the game.  Either you need to pay intially to play the games, or you will have to purchase some cards/booster packs to play beyond the standard pre-made packs.  This game... however, advertises itself as truly free, and then berates you with annoying totorials, oddly placed buttons that often result in misclicks, and a very liberal use of language.  I began playing and went through the very lengthy, and quite tedius tutorial/story mode because it provides you with enough ingame currency to purchase a few booster packs.  This tutorial is the epitomy of well duh" and takes you through some rediculously obvious and self explanatory game mechanics in a fashion that requires you to constantly load and swap out of your main tutorial into a secondary tutorial scenario that forcefeeds you mechanics as simplistic as casting an instant spell

reviewText:
This games premiss is super weak; discover the origin of the Plainswalkers through playing the story mode.
That would be super fun if they didn't give you really basic decks to not even start with, they just give you prebuilt starter decks that develope as you play each color, and not only that, you don't get them for multiplayer after you finish the campain. The story mode is just bad, it's almost impossible to win without luck, and playing it just feels dragged out.

Multiplayer seems to have a lot of potential with this deck building mechanic, I really like that, almost got me away from Cocatrice, however, it's super freemium, the only way to get more cards, is through two dollar booster packs, that hold six cards instead of the physical original fifteen. The only way to even get them without dumping money is playing with a really weak deck, over and over till it's decent. This is no good. Atleast let us use the decks we built" through the story campain.

The game build is solid

reviewText: The biggest challenge in the game is trying to play with the god awful decks you're forced to play during the story mode. Jaces deck isn't even remotely good until the final boss battle. Nissa's campaign deck is just as bad, forcing land ramp into a bunch of useless cards (With the exception of scute mob) but even worse is the fact that the AI always plays with a stacked deck. You can expect to always play against an AI whose deck will run flawlessly while you struggle to make ends meet with the worse than a literal piece of ♥♥♥♥ deck they force you to play with. I'm sorry but in a 60 card deck, It's hard to believe the AI isn't purposely being fed the right cards when you get your entire board presence removed by Flame slash. All 4 consecutively? Yeah ♥♥♥♥ing right.\n\nEDIT: Further proof of AI advantage. Running a deck with Reprisal (destroy target creature power 4 or greater) and the random" AI has no creatures power 4 or greater

It really feels like its trying to cheat you out of your money with digital cards.

reviewText:
( Edited to reflect a more accurate opinion of the game as it is at the time of edit )

With it's initial release, this game was broken as hell. Since the release of their latest update ( fixing the connectivity issues with both their store and with other people online, as well as a few other issues ), gameplay has become . . . bearable. There are still some issues with the game, some of which are still incredibly annoying ( heavy pixelation of cards and a black field for Win 10 users ).

One new issue i've found involves a few specific cards ( of which the names will not be listed in this review in the hopes of preventing people from exploiting the bug that accompanies these cards until the issue is fixed ). Despite the card's clear targetting of a single creature only, will often break the match you're playing and render the remainder of the creatures essentially useless and hand the win over to the other AI/player, regardless of whether or not you were winning.

With the game as it is now, I still don't recommend it.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game. I did like this game until 1 single mechanic ruined it for me.
When playing against a human player in verses battles, if your opponent concedes they are replaced by an AI.
The AI being BS hax is besides the point, thats why I play against other players; But when some one concedes, that should be victory for the other player. I've played so many games where my opponent concedes and I end up getting beat by AI after tedious battle I should have been awarded victory for 10 minutes ago when my opponent conceded. How do both players lose a battle?!?! I don't care if you drew a crap hand from the start, mulligan or leave and that should be it, victory of the other player.
So frustrated, not worth my time anymore.

reviewText: Two headed giant is UNPLAYABLE with a friend vs other actual people, it works VS AI, but who cares about that. also, you cant earn gold (the only way to get boosters, getting new cards) at any time you're searching with a friend. Speaking of the gold system, it is the most cancerous thing i've ever seen. You can only earn so much gold from wins every day and the cap for this is WAY TOO LOW, also you have to restart the game to see the gold you got from challenges every time you complete one. Another weird thing is that you can have as many legendaries in your deck as you want now, why did they change that? The difficulties for the AI is completely backwards, Hard is so easy you almost cant lose and easy is suprisingly hard. A good thing is this game has controller support, but every time i try and use it it locks up and i have to do something with the mouse to get it out of the lock. Basically the game is complete trash as of now, but i do see potential after ALOT of updates to fix the countless problems with the main selling point of this game (two headed giant) and they allow you to earn more gold daily or make it quicker to earn gold (i understand its free to play so its to encourage you to spend money on the game but the pricing for the booster packs are way too high for such a buggy game (estimate ~$60 to buy enough boosters to unlock all the card when older magic games go for way cheaper))

reviewText:
Stick to the duels of the planeswalkers series instead of trying this game. You'll get way more value for your money that way. This game may be free, but its wayy more pay to win than dotp is. In this game you unlock cards WAYYYY slower, so you'll be at a disadvantage for a MUCH longer time unless you pay for cards. The cheapest you can get all cards in the game is about 80 bucks. Spreading out those purchases will make it cost more.

The duels of the planeswalkers games have pay to win too, but it's hardly as necessary as unlocking cards in dotp takes a fraction of the time it does in this game. In dotp you pay one small fee for the game, maybe one more even smaller one for an expansion, then just have fun for several hours learning the starting cards and after a day or 2 you'll already have them all. In Magic Duels Origins, it'll take weeks.

EDIT: Also the story mode forces you to use premade ♥♥♥♥♥♥ decks, with no customization. So even if you play perfectly whether you win or lose a match is 100% chance. Sometimes (or rather, most times) there's just nothing you can do because your deck sucks, making the story take longer than it would otherwise simply because you're forced to lose at random. This also makes the card rewards from the story mode hardly worth the time.

TL;DR:
Duels of the Planeswalkers is a small one time fee for the game and you can quickly unlock all cards.
Magic Duels Origins is free to play but unlocking all cards takes way wayyy too long to encourage you to spend AT LEAST 80 bucks to unlock all cards instead.

As with any TCG, it's going to be pay to win. Skip this scam of a game and just wait for the next duels of the planeswalkers game, where you can avoid pay to win by simply playing for a few hours with the cards you start with.

reviewText:
I do not recommend this game. Much like it's predecessors, Magic Duels it a closed environment with the tutorial/story mode presented as the tutorial on how to play M:tG. It does several things well, however there are a couple game breaking bugs which the player has zero control over.

Overall the system is improved, however they have shifted to an always online server requirement in order to have any progress recorded. I personally believe that this always online initiative that is occurring is a negative step.  In the little time that I have been playing Magic Duels, the server has gone down repeatedly, which has dragged the game to a standstill. In fact as a player any progress you make while not connected to the server doesn't register, so if there are rewards for the game you player, you are effectively punished for not being online and connected to the server, as all rewards are forfeit. The rewards that are forfeited are the rewards which grant you access to additional cards.  This is a poor facsimile of the real game which has its roots in offline play. While I appreciate the spirited attempt to bring the game into the digital age, this iteration of the game also fails the true test of the game.

In comparison to the real game, you must work hard for booster packs" which unlike the real game are only 6 cards
date: with no guarantee of a rare. This feels rather insulting if you have ever had experience with the real game.\n\nThat said
recommended: the basics of gameplay are there
hoursPlayed: and as an introduction to M:tG its a good way to learn the initial gameplay and get a glimpse into the possibilities of what the real game holds
voteText: but it never succeeds in truly enlightening the player.\n\nDon't waste your bandwidth or your time with this game."

reviewText:
TL DR, If you have never played paper magic, don't bother there are other F2P digital card games that you will enjoy more then this. If you have played paper magic, then this game still is not for you, its like paper magic only with out the social aspect and some how more P2W.

Ok so I said I would change this review if the servers ever started working, and they have. I still cant recommend this game though.

Its just not worth your time.

The game is a supposed to be a digital trading card game, but it is not, there is no way to trade cards with other players. This alone wouldn't be that bad, but the only way to get more cards is through opening packs, which give you random cards. See the issue? You have no control over what types of decks you can make, the only way to build a specific deck list is to open packs until you have unlocked every card in the game (132 packs exactly).

Well that shouldn't be an issue, right? you can unlock packs with out paying. all you need to do is win games against other players. Right?  Wrong you will win a few games against players who haven't spent money. Since you have won a few games your rank will go up, then you will suddenly start getting matched against players who's decks are loaded with the strongest cards in the game, and then you will stop winning.

Now all this wouldn't even be so bad if you could just spend $10 and get a fairly good deck list and start winning again. How ever you have no control over what cards you will get with that $10. If RNGesus doesn't smile on you and give you strong cards that also have synergy and are in the same colors then you will still be playing at a huge disadvantage.

Throw in that MTGO is still a thing and I just cant see a reason to play this game. sure MTGO is pay 2 win, but at least there you could buy the deck you wanted not just dump money into a slot machine. Also there are tournaments in MTGO, many formats and cards from every set, not just one boring core set.

A large number of players are having issues even getting the game to work at all, I am not one of them, but before you download be aware that you might be.

There is also the issue with multiplayer. If your opponent forfeits you are forced to finish the game out against an AI opponent, MTG can already be kind of tedious if you need to actually get someone's life to 0 even in a one sided stomp, and this game has you wait through a lot of timers (I see why they are needed, so players can react to things on the stacks). The end result is that you will spend a lot of time in games that are already over.

I guess a player who is trying to learn magic might want to try this game just since it has some nice tutorials, but as a game is not fun in and of its self.

reviewText:
Magic is like chess. You and your arch enemy (everyone is arch enemy online) sit yourselves down and get an imaginary board between you, where he got his side and you got yours. Then you each got a collection (that you build yourself) of 60 chess pieces, and draw seven random ones. Then you get to beat with them on your opponent, while he beats back. The fun part is, put into chess terms, that you should always try to kill as many opposing pieces with as few of yours as you can. Here comes mind games, trickery, epic turns of events, and conceptually this game goes so much farther than chess. Would you like to play a piece that wipes the whole board, leaving nothing? What about stealing one your opponent's pieces and beating him with it till he succumbs in a pool of tears? Or how about combining a strategy where you got huge crowds of tiny nasty critter pieces that don't really care for whatever strategy your opponent is running, and just overrun him or her, in a true zerg-swarm style?

These are just a few examples of things you can do. You know what I am thinking about right now? Building a strategy entirely based around tentacles. Giant crabs. Weird fish. Entangling. That's right.

Magic Duels is one of many Magic games, and this one serves best as an introduction. It's free, and it's got a nice short tutorial that teaches you all the basics. In fact this game is where it is easier to start if you are interested in trying to see whether this is a game you would like to play in real life.

But it goes beyond that, although the depths of it aren't that exciting. It gives you a pool of cards (the pieces) to play with at the beginning, but if you want more, you have to purchase packs of random cards (which means that sometimes you will open something epic, like a big tentacle creature, and other times you will open something really boring, like a non-tentacle creature). You can pay real cash for them, but you also can do various daily game-play oriented quests to earn them shiny coins. But it is a slow progress: you will end up buying a booster pack maximum every third or fourth day, giving you like 12 new random cards each week. It's not so exciting, really.

If you are familiar with magic, this game only includes the newest sets: 2015 Magic set, and Battle for Zendikar. Oath of the Gatewatch set is set to come sometime during March or April.

So yeah, I recommend this game because it gives a nice intro to Magic the Gathering. It's very basic, there is no trading, no other game modes but simple duels against other people or A.I.

reviewText:
I Thought that things thats have been repeated for 4 years now should be better than the older ones since Stainless have thad time to practice but for some reason this one is somehow the worst.

For the single player campaign: It's very very bad. Your deck from the start is absolute garbage and half the cards you get aren't even playable in your own deck. Your campaign deck is updated everytime but they don't tell you which crads have been replaced and which cards have been added, you can't see the deck you play you just have to rely on chance I guess.

After the single player(wait was that it, so short) you can play the onlkine mode(if it doesnt crash every single time). They brought back two-headed giant thats for some reason doesnt award quests and where you can't communicate with your own teammate for some reason and you can't tell if your teammate has dropped and been replaced by AI, since you CAN'T COMMUNICATE WITH THEM.(seriously wtf).

The time it takes for you to build up some sort of reasonable card collection is just bad, the quest give wayy too little gold, the packs cost too much and the packs only have 6 cards. IRL magic packs contain 15 cards and while they're usually just for drafting this is way faster. There is also no way of trading in any way, every TCG online or IRL should have this.

I honestely believe that this had so much potential, both for seasoned players and as an introduction to new players but this game is so bad I would never admit to playing it.

reviewText:
Dont believe the negative reviews, this game is awesome!

* Its very generous!
3 daily quests, rewards for playing against the AI, a high daily reward cap and you dont draw unnecessary duplicates (!!!)!
You want a CCG where really everybody can compete? There you go!

* Its very complex!
A highly demaning deck-building, five colors and very skill-based!
Oh, and did i already mention that Planeswalkers finally made their way into the game :)

* Its professional!
(Besides the draw-mechanics, there is no RNG involved!!)

* Its just the beginning!
Yes, the card pool is still small, and the game needs polish. But, let us not forget that this is version 1.0! So, many changes and additions are awaiting!

* Update:
In the meantime, the very, very much demanded feature of 2vs2 matches has been added!

reviewText:
Things I do like:

Cards per deck are limited by their rarity along with their name. This, along with the specific card pool makes Duels in essence a new format.

When opening packs, you can't get more copies of a card if you already have the limit of that card. This means as you get more cards you don't want, the chance of getting cards you do want increases.

A reasonably nice interface. While it's quite clunky in a few places, at least it looks better than Magic: Online and Cockatrice.

Avatars. While some people ignore this, you can give each of your decks a face. I can't help myself from coming up with some personality to go with the avatars I choose, but that may be just me. I've also found the majority of players who settle for the default avatar play RDW. An impatient colour for impatient people, I guess.


Things I don't like:

Very short timer. When anything is put onto the stack, you have about 3 seconds to press the spacebar (which works about 9 times out of 10) or click the pause button (which works about 6 times out of 10). If you miss the timer, or your method of pausing fails for whatever reason, tough luck.

Very sensitive casting. When you click a card, you'll play it immediately. If you miss-click, or you've played too much Hearthstone, tough luck.

Grinding speed. One pack of six cards costs 150 gold. Every game you win nets you 20 gold. This along with the daily quests means you can get a pack every 5 - 7 games. While this is a little slow, it's not that bad and I believe the micro-transactions are justified seeing as this is a free game and all.

No chat. This could be there too stop harassment, so there's no chance people new to magic would be driven away by ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s or salty people on a loosing streak. I haven't played 2HG myself yet, but if theirs no chat there as well, then it would be nigh impossible to strategize with your partner unless you know each other personally can  communicate in some other way.


Who I would recommend this game to:

If you are new to magic, then I would recommend Duels. It's free, it's pretty good at teaching you the rules and getting you into the game. Clear descriptions, the Deck Wizard" that lets you pick the type of deck you want to play and guides you through building it
recommended: due to the lack of chat.\n\nIf you already play the magic
hoursPlayed: but mostly casual "Kitchen Table Magic"

votesHelpful: then I would recommend Duels. Rather than see it as another duels game
votesTotal: the ranked 1v1 matches should lead you to see it as another format. Try it and see if you enjoy it

reviewText:
This game blows.  I'm a big fan of the trading card game but rarely play because of cost, and have played other computer based TCGs like Hearthstone and Scrolls to try a fill that void.  If you are in the same boat and hoping that this will feel like playing Magic for real, you will be sorely disappointed.

The gameply is incredibly slow.  Magic is a complex game because it requires interactions on your opponents turn.  In order to capture this in a game, you have pauses between every card played, every phase, and so on.  I get that this is necessary for PvP duels, but do I really have to sit through it all when playing NPCs in Story mode and the like?

While we are on the topic of story mode, let me just say how frustrating of an experience it is.  In addition to being incredibly slow, you have to play with a prebuilt deck that you can't even examine outside of duel.  Not only are these decks complete rubbish (and significantly worse than your NPC oppenent's), you have no idea what cards are included in them.  Good luck forming strategies like that.

And the icing on this horrible, horrible cake is the game performance.  I have a decent laptop that can run popular games like League of Legends, CS:GO, and Skyrim on low to medium settings with around 60 fps.  I rarely exceed 14 in this game.  The interface is really bizarre.  The game table is massive, but the cards are tiny.  The default option for the englarged card view is to scroll up on the card.  And selecting and playing cards from your hand is awful.  I've played the wrong card many times.  This is the most basic feature of the game and even that doesn't work well.

Oh, also, apparently turning off the music also mutes the cut scenes.  10/10

reviewText:
Aside from the annoyance of having to play through the tutorial, which is tedious if you've ever played any form of MtG before, the game is actually quite good.
Pro's:
Two different story modes
Good card selection
Two Headed Giant is back and it actually works (despite what some reviews say, a mate and I play this regularly and can invite each other into games)
Far easier to build a deck than in Magic 2015
I got a Planeswalker from my first booster unlock (shame I never get one IRL)

Cons:
Doesn't always work like Magic is meant too
Mechanics for instants can be clunky
No pre-built decks as in Magic 2014 which means you have to make do with what you can build.

Overall a massive improvement on 2015, not sure if its better than 2014 though.

reviewText:
Hi everyone,

First, people are only cry babies this game really doesn't have the review it should have, here are my points

1- This game is free, YES it gonna have bugs, crashes and silly other thing, but this game is FREE you can now play the 2 latest sets of magic for FREE and more are comming, have you any idea how much it cost in real life to have all those cards? ... a LOTS so to have the chance to get a quick fix of magic when I can't get to my friends is a real blessing.

2- It doesn't crash so much, i had some problems before but it look like they fixed it, and playing in windows mode helped me.

3- In terms of bugs, the only i EVER had was a lag in the money after a duel where i didn't get my money but i just restard the game and Hop, here it is.

4- Some ppl cry abouts AI using legendary,rare, mythic cards ... if you have ever played MTG you would know that NO deck absolutly NO deck are build only on common and uncommon, you need rare cards to save your ♥♥♥ or building a strong win condition, so why could we use those cards and not the AI imo it make the game more intersting to play againts an AI that can put a fight and not only grinding and doing boring fights.

5- It follow a bit on what i just said the AI is FAR from perfect or close to a real player but it is good to have them, sometimes it look like they are boosted and get all they need, like the game wanted you too lose, but those games happen in real life too. Some time if your friends dont crush you out right' it's simply because your friends are not cold blooded computer and dont unleash their full power at you. Where im going with this, is that AI are NEVER gonna be perfect and it is good that way, they are not too tought where you never gonna win a fight and they are not too easy so that you are no just wacking some brainless virtual opponents.

6- The only sad thing about all this is that in 2HG you dont get any money even when you play against real opponents i see why in 1v1 when you invite someone to play you dont get any, that is to prevent farming without playing but 2HG i dont really get it ... hell even only 5G would be fun it would reward those who invite their friends to play the game with them, to give those guys a small candy

And last point, no chat is a good thing in this game because trolls are so toxic and in this kind of game it make your play time really bad to play against those, and we all know that out there we have WAY more trolls that good guys, I would had one in 2HG with your ally but it is not game breaker

I hope my review will help you see past all those bad review because some ppl can't enjoy anything in life even for FREE
Thank you, and have a good day

reviewText:
Magic is one of the best games ever made, and this is a great intro product to that game. The new commitment to doing videos explaining decisions and curating the cards available to provide the best possible experience is a really important step, and encourages me to think that they're really going to support and improve this experience over the long term.

I would recommend it as an intro product to anyone who wants to learn Magic, and if you like it, it's definitely worth paying for packs.

With that said, the game has had a rough start, with a lot of bugs that should have been caught in Beta. Being tied to the paper Magic set release allows you to get in on the hype (Innistrad looks amazing!), but it also means that the quality sometimes suffers due to a fairly punishing schedule by digital standards. They've fixed a lot of issues, but it would certainly benefit them to fix the rest.

Long story short, give it a try!

reviewText: I highly recommend this game. It  is a lot of fun for free, especially if you have ever played with the Magic the Gathering cards back in the day but no longer have anyone near who likes to play. I think the easy and middle levels are pretty similar.  There are so many delightful  perks, like that extra coins are awarded daily for the first battle with a live rather than AI opponent. I especially like that the game awards no cards one may not use (redundant beyond the number allowed in a deck, for example) and enjoyed collecting my first full set. The quests + versus bonus coins are a good way to earn a booster set every day or two.

reviewText:
Aside from the annoyance of having to play through the tutorial, which is tedious if you've ever played any form of MtG before, the game is actually quite good.
Pro's:
Two different story modes
Good card selection
Two Headed Giant is back and it actually works (despite what some reviews say, a mate and I play this regularly and can invite each other into games)
Far easier to build a deck than in Magic 2015
I got a Planeswalker from my first booster unlock (shame I never get one IRL)

Cons:
Doesn't always work like Magic is meant too
Mechanics for instants can be clunky
No pre-built decks as in Magic 2014 which means you have to make do with what you can build.

Overall a massive improvement on 2015, not sure if its better than 2014 though.

reviewText:
Dont believe the negative reviews, this game is awesome!

* Its very generous!
3 daily quests, rewards for playing against the AI, a high daily reward cap and you dont draw unnecessary duplicates (!!!)!
You want a CCG where really everybody can compete? There you go!

* Its very complex!
A highly demaning deck-building, five colors and very skill-based!

* Its professional!
(Besides the draw-mechanics, there is no RNG involved!!)

* Update:
In the meantime, the very, very much demanded feature of 2vs2 matches has been added!

reviewText:
Things I do like:

Cards per deck are limited by their rarity along with their name. This, along with the specific card pool makes Duels in essence a new format.

When opening packs, you can't get more copies of a card if you already have the limit of that card. This means as you get more cards you don't want, the chance of getting cards you do want increases.

A reasonably nice interface. While it's quite clunky in a few places, at least it looks better than Magic: Online and Cockatrice.

Avatars. While some people ignore this, you can give each of your decks a face. I can't help myself from coming up with some personality to go with the avatars I choose, but that may be just me. I've also found the majority of players who settle for the default avatar play RDW. An impatient colour for impatient people, I guess.


Things I don't like:

Very short timer. When anything is put onto the stack, you have about 3 seconds to press the spacebar (which works about 9 times out of 10) or click the pause button (which works about 6 times out of 10). If you miss the timer, or your method of pausing fails for whatever reason, tough luck.

Very sensitive casting. When you click a card, you'll play it immediately. If you miss-click, or you've played too much Hearthstone, tough luck.

Grinding speed. One pack of six cards costs 150 gold. Every game you win nets you 20 gold. This along with the daily quests means you can get a pack every 5 - 7 games. While this is a little slow, it's not that bad and I believe the micro-transactions are justified seeing as this is a free game and all.

No chat. This could be there too stop harassment, so there's no chance people new to magic would be driven away by ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s or salty people on a loosing streak. I haven't played 2HG myself yet, but if theirs no chat there as well, then it would be nigh impossible to strategize with your partner unless you know each other personally can  communicate in some other way.


Who I would recommend this game to:

If you are new to magic, then I would recommend Duels. It's free, it's pretty good at teaching you the rules and getting you into the game. Clear descriptions, the Deck Wizard" that lets you pick the type of deck you want to play and guides you through building it
recommended: due to the lack of chat.\n\nIf you already play the magic
hoursPlayed: but mostly casual "Kitchen Table Magic"

votesHelpful: then I would recommend Duels. Rather than see it as another duels game
votesTotal: the ranked 1v1 matches should lead you to see it as another format. Try it and see if you enjoy it
votesFunny: it is free after all."

reviewText:
For what it's worth you might as well just take up the physical card game.

In Magic Duels the campaign mode is alright but as far as the mulitplayer goes you have to earn/buy booster packs in order to build your own decks in order to play, just like the real game.  Now, the thing is to get a half-way decent card collection going in order to build good decks you're either going to have to spend loads of real money on mirco-transactions or grind for hundreds of hours with whatever barely-usable decks you've scraped together.  Whereas if you were looking at the physical game you still have to buy cards of course, but you have much greater control over what you're getting and you have nicely made, real cards in your hands rather than pictures of them on a screen.

I say either take up the real thing or just go back to Magic 2014 which came with pre-built decks and was actually fun.

reviewText:
Right, I'm writing this review after only 8,3 hours on record, I just can't bring myself to play any more of this mockery of the card game I love, and let's look at a few of the reasons I dislike this game.

1. This game changes magic fundamentals. Nowhere in magic is it a rule that you can only play 3 uncommons, 2 rares and 1 mythic of a certain type. Either the makers of duels are trying to suggest here that the paper card game is broken or they are suggesting that players are too stupid to make good decks if they're not given certain limitations. Just stop it, I've not gotten to know a single magic player on a personal level who didn't dislike this.

2. Lack of cards to start with. Now first I'd complain about the shallow pool of cards to pick from overall, but I realise getting the game to work with a ton of different cards takes time and effort. What I can not understand however is why the pool of cards you start out with is so shallow you have difficulties creating a decent themed deck. Honestly with the promise of this game being the last game and that they would only build upon this game in the future, they should have the players start out at least with all of the common and uncommon cards in the set. Just give the players some tools to work with here to make the grind any fun.

3. The grind and the deck wizard. I was surprised to see I wasn't getting any quest completion when I won duels, then I googled the issue and discovered you only get quest completion if you use the terrible deck wizard. In most card games  that have a deck wizard you can just ignore it, generally those wizards are worse at making decks than the players anyway. In this case however I found myself incredibly frustrated trying to build a fun deck when the deck wizard was making me choose between a handfull of absolutely terrible cards. I'd go as far as to say even new players do not benefit from this wizard. Any player who has taken the time to learn about manacurve and land count will be able to make a decent deck on his own. Stop trying to handhold the players through frustrating deck wizards.

I could continue to complain about other features such as the UI but those three points are the main reasons I really dislike this game. I can't recommend it to anyone who plays the physical card game, it's only going to be a frustrating experience.

This game has a horrible tendency to crash if you so much as look at it wrong.  Or maybe if you -don't- look at it wrong.  Granted, it usually crashed while I was alt-tabbed, but at this point in time any game that can't handle alt-tabbing is really kinda sad.

reviewText:
You have probably just looked at how many hours hours I've played this and thought I must like this. I do in a way but there are just way too many problems with the game for it to be fun. I'm talking about actual bugs and design flaws - things that should not be in the game (I'm not going to judge deck or card balancing here).

A Couple of terrible bugs
- Trying too find an actual multiplayer match can be ridiculous. About 30-60% of all searches for a standard 1v1 game won't work and about 50-80% of all searches for a standard 2v2 won't work. There are a couple of different reasons for this but all of them are utter crap.
- Particularly in 2v2 matches, the game will break and the match wont continue until a specific person has left the game is just beyond a joke and happens about 40% of the matches. Rare in 1v1's though.
- Certain spells also have a chance of breaking the game causing the match the stop until someon quits is again bloody terrible.

A couple of terrible design choices
- Text chat has been removed destroying any communication in 2v2 which is absolutely moronic.
- Removing game lobbies in 2v2, I'll explain this one. Unfortunately you do come across some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who join a game just to quit which compiled with struggling to get a game can really ♥♥♥♥ you off. When you try to find another game you can end up with the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ again. The lobbies in the old games showed who was going to be in the game so if you knew there was an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you could find another lobby. Plus these lobbies worked so much better for actually getting a successful game.
- If you minimize the game or it gets minimized by another program and its your turn, the game decides to skip your turn entirely which heavily punishes you.
- The time limit per turn is outrageous long. Some people deliberately waste as much turn as possible hoping their opponent will quit from boredom and give them an easy AI match victory.

The game itself is fun when things work and your playing against another decent player but thats so few and far between its just not fun.

reviewText:
Great game for learning magic but the grind for getting cards to build a decent deck is absurd. You get 1 quest a day and it is worth 40-120 gold. Basically you can earn one pack of 6 cards every other day if you do them all. Coming from MTGO where you could spend 10$ and build a few decks its a grind and then some. Even if you spend money you still just open a few boosters with 6 random cards so dont expect to build a good theme deck or have a good selection until after you spend a LOT or grind a LOT.

This game needs to realise MTGO is already out there and far better for building decks and playing online. This one should try to focus on story mode campaigns and selling those off to make money. Those were pretty fun and cool but over to fast and replaying them pays nothing. That leaves you to take your starter cards and play online vs people who own every single card from all 4 sets, or play ai which sometimes are good games and others you are playing a bot on easy watching him drop rare card after rare card then some rare legends and gg lol.


The second biggest problem with game is all the pop ups. You are constantly closing them. I got one to write this review. I get them telling me to visit the store after just buying something from the store, and even after reviewing this, I still constantly get them asking me to review it and leave feedback.

Best game for playing vs ai but it has a ways to go before i can really give this a thumbs up.

If you are looking for a great game to play vs ai and not have a single ad let alone 20 a gaming session play Hex: Shards of Fate. Tried it and this game has collected dust ever since.
